POSTINGS: 46 Stories on East 88th; High There, New Neighbor!
LEAD: The apartment building that General Atlantic Realty is erecting on the former site of the Children's Aid Society will be tall.
Not Twin Tower tall, not even Trump Tower tall, but its 46 stories will make it a giant for the southwest corner of the 88th Street-First Avenue intersection.

LEAD: The Security Council today failed to agree on guidelines for a peacekeeping force to supervise elections in Namibia.

The couple were attended by their children and grandchildren.

LEAD: There are four of them, and they dress in a manner best described as bristling: hair close-cropped, heavy boots with trousers bloused, black leather jackets and epaulets.
They wear ties, and the look is neat, but a little Germanic, circa 1939.
Two have earrings, but they say that is not part of the look, the skinhead look.

Telling the Tales of Siena's Golden Age
LEAD: ''Painting in Renaissance Siena: 1420-1500'' at the Metropolitan Museum is a glorious affair.
Even in a season that has seen one great exhibition after another, worldwide, this one is a nonpareil.
Moreover, the art that we see there is in the highest degree an unstandardized art - one that keeps us continually on the alert, thinking new thoughts, dreaming new dreams and on fire with speculation.

A Mission: Hospital Care For the Poor
LEAD: A last-minute agreement by Governor Kean with Senate and Assembly leaders on a two-year extension of New Jersey's Uncompensated Care Trust Fund has averted a crisis for many inner-city hospitals.
This trust fund helps pay the hospital bills of poor and uninsured people by spreading the cost among the 89 acute-care hospitals in the state through a surcharge on all hospital bills.

LEAD: IN New Haven, there is ferment on both sides of Chapel Street, with the Yale University Art Gallery host to two traveling exhibitions and the Yale Center for British Art the scene of a retrospective that will also travel.
The magnum opus at the Art Gallery is ''In Pursuit of the Dragon: Traditions and Transitions in Ming Ceramics,'' which comes from the Idemitsu Museum of Arts in Tokyo.

LEAD: THE communal basement storage room - the apartment dweller's version of the attic - is undergoing a radical transformation.
The traditional mountain of worn trunks, rusty bicycles and other household ephemera is giving way to a neater, more carefully supervised alternative - the personal storage bin.

PINS Laws Don't Make Sense
LEAD: In ''Letters to the Long Island Editor'' (Oct. 30), I read letters concerning the PINS laws.
As I understand it, a child 16 or older cannot be forced to live at home or attend counseling or therapy program regardless of where or how the child is living.
Yet, the parents of this child are financially responsible for it until said child reaches 21.

Who Was Dick Dudgeon?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Endings Can Really Finish a Movie
LEAD: If you have friends and would like to keep them, try never to talk about movie endings.
No greater breach of cinema-related etiquette exists, unless it's recommending a comedy by retelling its jokes.
Endings are sacrosanct for obvious reasons, and also because a viewer's opinion of a film is usually formed long before the ending comes along.

Dolphin Dissection: Serious Subject
LEAD: A story Dec. 11  [ ''Cutting Up Flipper,'' Long Island Journal ]  serves as a source of great consternation to the students, faculty and administration of Bayport-Blue Point High School.
The title blithely implies that a friend (Flipper) was brutalized by our students via dissection.
The tone gives reason to suspect that people may have been running about in a confused state of nausea, looking for relief.

Richard Burton Lierle of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Buchanan Lierle, to G. William Birrell, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
George Andrew Birrell of Greenwich, Conn., and Wilmington, N.C.
The couple plan to wed in June.


Aluminum House Is Dismantled
LEAD: ARCHITECTURE students on Long Island have completed dismantling and storing a three-story, five-room aluminum house.
The house is being kept at the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip until it can be reconstructed on the school's campus next spring.


POSTINGS: S.I. Corporate Park; Culture Goes West
LEAD: Four years ago, Everything Yogurt decided the cramped Wall Street area was no place for a growing frozen-confection franchise.
It opted instead for the relatively open spaces of the east shore of Staten Island and renovated a former bank building in Port Richmond for its headquarters.

Elegant Showcase For Jamaican Crafts
LEAD: SET well back from the bustling junction of Waterloo Road and Hope Road near the center of Kingston is the grande dame of Jamaican architecture, Devon House.
The sprawling mansion, which resembles a classic 19th-century American plantation house, is surrounded by manicured lawns.
Gravel paths lead visitors past formal gardens and fountains watched over by smiling cast-iron cherubs.

Twyla Tharp: Turning Sharp Corners
LEAD: ''This year is an extraordinary set of circumstances.
It's what I think of as a shakedown,'' says the choreographer Twyla Tharp, who for the first time in 23 years, is without a dance company that bears her name or her singular stamp.
This past July, Ms.
Tharp announced that she was disbanding the modern-dance troupe she began in 1965 and accepting the invitation of American Ballet Theater's artistic director Mikhail Baryshnikov to join A.B.T.

Stretching the Weekend: The Pre-Dawn Monday Commute
LEAD: EVERY Sunday afternoon, at our weekend place in North Haven, just outside of Sag Harbor, my wife and I ask each other the same question.
Should we return to Manhattan later that afternoon or leave early Monday morning?
This question and the discussion surrounding it involves a variety of factors - the weather, our fatigue, and our adherence to a well-known principle of physics -that a body at rest tends to remain at rest.

LEAD: As foreign trade goes, the loss of $130 million a year in exports is a minor matter.

Bradshaw Mintener, 86; Helped Eisenhower in Presidential Race
LEAD: Bradshaw Mintener, a Washington attorney and former Government official who helped in launching both Hubert H. Humphrey and Dwight D. Eisenhower into national politics, died of cancer yesterday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington.
He was 86 years old and had lived in the capital since joining the Eisenhower Administration in 1954 as Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  REFLECTIONS ON THE WAY TO THE GALLOWS: Rebel Women in Prewar Japan.
Translated and edited by Mikiso Hane. (University of California/Pantheon, $22.50.) In the Japan portrayed in this book, from the late 19th century up to World War II, young girls work 12-hour shifts in textile factories, poor farmers sell their daughters to brothels, police arrest anyone suspected of socialist sympathies and women are prohibited by law from participating in political activities.


Tea for Two (or More): A Sampling in London
LEAD: IN London, one does not have tea.
One does not merely drink tea.
One takes tea, like one takes a holiday, or a calming constitutional, or a medicine that puts one's health to rights.
English teatime is a social ritual, made fashionable in the 1840's, but it is a quiet and relaxing social ritual.
As Michael Twomey, manager of the Palm Court of the Ritz Hotel in London, says, ''In the middle of the afternoon, when your batteries run down, it is a very nice thing to take tea.

Question Of the Week; Who Was The Best Performer Of 1988?
LEAD: Steffi Graf.
Being in shape, staying healthy, playing at the top of your game, keeping mentally tough from the Australian Open in January to the French Open at the end of May is a season in most sports.
But Graf still had Wimbledon, the United States Open and the Seoul Olympics to go.
Graf's Grand Slam and Olympic gold medal is the best performance of 1988.

In Yonkers, the 'World Is Round'
LEAD: THE world is coming apart in the Hudson River Museum, at Yonkers.
Its fragmentation is the result, not of an explosion, but of the search by 22 artists for another angle on reality.
The findings by these artists, called ''The World Is Round: Contemporary Panoramas,'' were organized for the museum by a guest curator, Marcia Clark, but they have only just arrived there, having spent the last year touring other galleries in the Northeast.

DRESSING DOWN
LEAD: Relaxed formality, fashion's buzzword for the 1980's, was a phrase broad enough to encompass a multitude of trends.
It covered the advent of the ''big suit,'' a wide-shouldered, loose-fitting hybrid of Italian and Yankee tailoring, as well as the return of the double-breasted jacket.
But the final years of the decade that ushered in such hyper-refinements as brocade vests for daytime may have suffered from fashion overkill.

Is there a less expensive way to fix this?

Spare Sparkle
LEAD: Historical objects sparingly placed in cool, modern settings - that is the dominant direction for 1989.
Off-whites and muted shades are de rigueur.
So are antique fabrics, or new ones made to look old.
This season's lighting fixtures and surface materials range from somber, industrial-sleek to those as colorful as confetti.

Unwrapping the New Year
LEAD: It's easier to wrap up the old year than unwrap the new.
Still, the difference between them is only some arbitrary celestial point in the zodiac, picked long ago by a committee of Babylonian astrologers.
On the principle of continuity, the near future will look a lot like the recent past.

THE ODDS ARE YOU'RE INNUMERATE

They generally react without a trace of embarrassment, however, to even the most egregious numerical solecisms.

It is currently inaccessible because of the shoreline damage.

In Switzerland, Wild Roses And an Elegy
LEAD: Jan 2, 1917, was a sparkling cold winter day in Raron, a small Swiss town surrounded by snow-covered Alps in the Valais.

It hurts him to put on skates, hurts him to stand in them, hurts him when they are taken off.
As a result, he is forced to tape his foot with care before a game and ice it afterward.

40,2&gt;Hispanic Groups Seek A Voice in Perth Amboy
LEAD: NEARLY seven months after the shooting death of a Mexican immigrant and the wounding of his brother by an off-duty police detective here, a quiet revolution is taking place in this city of 42,000 people.
Hispanic residents are beginning to organize and demand a voice in government, police affairs and even the naming of streets that is more in line with their numbers, which account for at least 40 percent of the population.

LEAD: NINE HUNDRED Upper East Side residents, during a bitter community board hearing last June, spent hours speaking, cheering and booing plans to open a drop-in center for homeless people in their neighborhood.


Poorhampton No More: Bridgehampton Is Upscale Now Too
LEAD: WHEN I moved to Bridgehampton 25 years ago, it might as well have been called Poorhampton.
Nearly every store on Main Street was vacant.
Potato farmers were worried that their crop was worth less than the land on which it grew.
Golden nematode disease impaired what potatoes they could grow.
They were in hock to the local banks as they used their machinery as collateral to get through the winter.

Bless You, Marty
LEAD: O.K., SO 1988 WASN'T PERFECT.
We had a drought, a flood, a record-breaking heat wave.
A hurricane, a forest fire and, in Bloomsburg, Pa., a roller coaster stalled midloop, suspending 20 riders upside down for more than an hour.
Planes fell apart, people ate flowers, grilled tuna meat half raw.
A large hole spread in the ozone layer, nightmares washed up on beaches and voracious pear thrips ate Vermont's sugar maples.

Encouraged by last year's revitalization of the shuttle and the successful launching of a series of unmanned rockets, the Pentagon plans to greatly increase its arsenal of orbiting spacecraft and to pioneer a generation of powerful rockets.

Business Leaders See Continued Growth
LEAD: WHAT do Westchester business leaders see in store for the New Year?
In contrast to the national uncertainty about the strength of the economy, Westchester observers are anticipating that this year the local business climate will favor economic growth in the county.
There is concern, however, that the lack of affordable housing and of adequate public transportation and the shortages of entry-level workers may pose problems.

Answering the Mail
LEAD: Q. The threads on the outside filler pipe for my oil tank are worn out, so when the cover is put on it does not form a watertight seal.
When it rains, water seeps in, causing the oil burner to fail.
The oil company wants to put in a new pipe, but this is expensive.
Is there a less expensive way to fix this?


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-11


It Takes Two to Weigh All Sides of Prokofiev
LEAD: In one of history's ironies, Serge Prokofiev died on March 5, 1953, the same date as Stalin.
The Soviet press, of course, played up the dictator's demise to the virtual exclusion of the composer's.
Even in death, Stalin and his Bolshevik state cast a shadow over Prokofiev's career - as, indeed, they did over all Soviet composers' lives.


Singers Join in a Lament About Rising Pitch
LEAD: Altitude may be a common metaphor for success, but not with opera singers.
They are complaining with increasing stridency that international standards of pitch have broken disastrously free of their moorings and that the direction they are headed is up.


Taking Stock of Investment Clubs
LEAD: If one of your New Year's resolutions is to get back into the market, you might want to consider joining - or even starting - an investment club.
Generally organized by 15 or so friends in the form of a partnership, the clubs offer a way to pool investment money and knowledge while at the same time lessening the anxiety level.

Nicholas Calas, a Poet And Art Critic, Was 81
LEAD: Nicholas Calas, an art critic and poet who directed attention in his writings to young artists and new art movements, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 81 years old.


Brazil's Economy Slows
LEAD: The Brazilian economy, plagued by an inflation rate of more than 900 percent, showed hardly any growth this year.
Brazil's gross domestic product rose only four-hundredths of 1 percent in 1988, the national statistics office said Friday in its first estimate for the year.
The stagnant economy contrasted sharply with growth of 2.9 percent a year earlier and an 8 percent rise in 1986.


Lotto Prize to Be $26 Million
LEAD: No one picked the six correct numbers in Saturday's Lotto drawing, making the first jackpot of 1989 worth $26 million, state Lottery Division officials said today.
A division spokesman, George Yamin, said if someone picks the correct six numbers in Wednesday's drawing, the winner - or winners -will receive the fourth-highest Lotto jackpot in state history.


San Diego Fights a Utility Takeover
LEAD: Municipal leaders in San Diego are mobilizing to block what they view as a blow to the city's pride and pocketbook -the $2.5 billion takeover of their largest local corporation, the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

Instead of working for the newly acquired organization, the investment banker became a private investor.

Even in Fog, Finish the Game
LEAD: EVER since the Buffalo Bills emerged as a Super Bowl contender, pro football people wondered what the weather would be like here on Jan. 1 for a playoff game.
Surely zero degrees.
Maybe snow.
But yesterday turned up sunny and warm.
At least sunny and warm for Buffalo at this time of year: 33 degrees at the kickoff with hardly any wind.

LEAD: Horse Racing  Cagey Exuberance Wins Handicap: Cagey Exuberance, the favorite in the field of eight and carrying high weight of 121 pounds, rallied through the stretch yesterday to score a two-length victory in the $87,150 Interborough Handicap at Aqueduct.
The triumph in the race for fillies and mares 3 years old and up was the third of the day for Richard Migliore, Cagey's Exuberance's jockey.

Portugal Raises Wages
LEAD: Portugal, the poorest country in the European Community, raised the minimum wage for industrial workers on Friday by 10 percent, to 30,000 escudos, or $204, a month.
The Government also said the minimum wage for agricultural workers would rise by 14.5 percent, to 28,400 escudos, or $193, a month.

Canadian Rail Tunnel
LEAD: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said Friday that it had completed the longest railroad tunnel in North America as part of a $420 million ($500 million Canadian), four-year project to ease the gradient for westbound freight trains crossing the Canadian Rockies.
A limited number of trains are using the 9.1-mile tunnel.

LEAD: An earthen dike broke early today, forcing the evacuation of an estimated 1,500 people for several hours and closure of a major interstate highway, the authorities said.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International 2-8  An Israeli austerity plan to rescue the troubled economy was unveiled by Finance Minister Shimon Peres.
It includes major budget reductions and would call for the layoff of thousands of Government employees.

Moscow Curbs Exports of Scarce Goods
LEAD: In the midst of the worst shortage of consumer goods in recent memory, the Soviet Government announced today that foreigners would soon be prevented from taking such scarce locally produced items as caviar, coffee, television sets, children's clothing, refrigerators or washing machines out of the country.


Debt-Equity Swaps Draw Latin Criticisms
LEAD: As the incoming Bush administration prepares to take its promised new look at Latin America's foreign debt crisis, the one well-tried method of reducing the region's payments - through conversion of debt into equity - is coming under fire in several countries.

Overhauling School Decentralization
LEAD: New York City's school decentralization law was born in the educational, political and racial crisis of 1968 that nearly tore the city apart.
Issues of teacher accountability, union power and community control were dramatically contested in the streets.
The resulting legislation was a rough political compromise, not a coherent educational vision.

LEAD: Leigh Ann Wilcoxson, the daughter of Nancy Stade of Salisbury, Md., was married there yesterday to Harlan Adam Eagle, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Sidney Eagle of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
Cantor Alvin Donald officiated at the Sheraton Salisbury.
Mrs.
Eagle, a graduate of Salisbury State University, is an exercise specialist at the Dorchester General Hospital in Cambridge, Md.


Israel, Hardly the Monaco of the Middle East
LEAD: The recent definitions of Palestinian attitudes will not ''solve'' the Middle Eastern crisis or bring a negotiation with Israel into early view.
But all attempts in Israel and the United States to portray them as worthless or fraudulent have incurred total failure.
Moreover, it is absurd to suggest, as many of Israel's friends have, that the American decision to talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization theatens Israel's very survival.


Islanders Reflect a Positive Image
LEAD: In defiance of a recent trend toward decrepitude, the Islanders have been victorious twice in the space of a week, and Saturday's 6-4 domination of the Washington Capitals suggests that their transformation from chumps to challengers may finally have taken place.

LEAD: Patent battles now beginning could determine which organizations and even which nations control the rights to new high-temperature superconductors, materials that could revolutionize fields like computers and electricity generation.

LEAD: Last week, nearly five months after New York City police officers called to Tompkins Square Park clubbed and kicked scores of bystanders, 400 officers and 40 sergeants who had been there that night stood accused of a new offense: stonewalling investigators from the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

LEAD: Bo Schembechler has mellowed so much that he is no longer impatient with silly questions.

LEAD: George Bush has taken some time out since the election for sedentary activities like picking a Cabinet and preparing a plan to govern.

LEAD: The Bears received good news today about Mike Tomczak, their starting quarterback.
They learned that his shoulder injury was not as bad as expected, and they said he might play next Sunday.

LEAD: When President Reagan took office, environmentalists feared the worst from the man who once said trees cause pollution.
They expected him to dismantle environmental regulation and give away public lands and resources.


Legalized Migrants Flock Home for Holidays
LEAD: Santiago and Gloria Rodriguez have been married for eight years, but neither has ever met the other's parents, his in Mexico, hers in Guatemala.
As immigrants living illegally in California, the couple dared not, until now, leave the United States for fear they might not ever be able to slip back across the border.

LEAD: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth, who the police later learned was a suspect in a fatal hit-and-run accident in June, was shot early yesterday morning by a police officer during a routine stop for a minor traffic violation, a police spokesman said.


GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Vietnam, which is rolling back tight state control to revitalize its economy, said it would put some inefficient state enterprises into private hands next year to increase production and exports.
Radio Hanoi said a National Assembly resolution on the economic plan for 1989 envisaged a 10 percent increase in industrial output, a 15 percent rise in the value of exports and a 6 percent rise in gross national product over 1988 levels.


Courageous Men
LEAD: Vince Newsome of the Los Angeles Rams was Ed Block's kind of guy.
Newsome has never whined or complained in the past two seasons, which were full of stress and strife for him.
Now he is in a position to win the Ed Block Courage Award.

LEAD: Thirty years ago on New Year's Day, Cubans acclaimed Fidel Castro as the youthful liberator who felled the corrupt tyranny of Fulgencio Batista.
Today the 62-year-old Mr.
Castro himself resembles one of those crabbed caudillos in the novels of his Colombian friend, Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

Clement A. Smith, 87, Professor of Pediatrics
LEAD: Clement A. Smith, professor emeritus of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School and a past president of the American Pediatric Society, died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass.
He was 87 years old.
Dr.
Smith conducted studies on the prevention of deaths of babies.
He was a recipient of the Howland Award, the highest honor of the pediatric society, and a chair in pediatrics at the medical school was named for him.

Correction
LEAD: A listing in the Company News column in Business Day on Friday about Tiffany &amp; Company misstated when the company most recently sold shares to the public.
Tiffany, which was taken private in a leveraged buyout in October 1984, made a public offering of shares in May 1987.

Korea Surplus With U.S. Dips
LEAD: The national trade surplus with the United States in the first 11 months of this year decreased to $7.61 billion, down $890 million from a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported Friday.
Under American pressure, Korea has eased import curbs and taken other steps in efforts to reduce the trade excess.

LEAD: Harold W. Zancanata, a scientist who developed some of the first rockets for testing the atmosphere, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Florida Medical Center.
He was 70 years old.

Review/Music; The Philharmonic's Toast to Old and New Years
LEAD: The New York Philharmonic closed its books on 1988 with a festive Pension Fund Benefit concert on New Year's Eve at Avery Fisher Hall.
For the occasion, the orchestra was considerably enlarged and played under a canopy of colorful streamers, interlaced with microphone cables.
The latter were used both for the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast, which piped the proceedings into living rooms across the country, and by CBS Records, which recorded the concert.


Chief Justice Urges Increase In Federal Judges' Salaries
LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, warning that current salaries for Federal judges threaten the quality of the judiciary, today urged President Reagan and Congress to accept the substantial pay increases proposed last month by a special commission.


Eligibility Question
LEAD: A British track official said yesterday that an inquiry into Zola Budd's eligibility for international competition would be reopened if the South African-born runner attempts to return to her adopted country.


BAKKERS ARE BACK IN NEW TV SHOW
LEAD: Jim Bakker, the defrocked minister, and his wife, Tammy, were back on the air today with a new version of their religious talk show, two years to the day after a sex and money scandal forced him to shut down their popular PTL television program.


Our Towns; A Pair of Angels Who've Earned Their Wings
LEAD: Kim Thornton is the youngest of seven children.
The others looked out for her.
They had to; their parents were alcoholics.
When Kim was 8, her mother and father got bad.
Her father sold the house for cash and announced he was driving them to Arizona.

LEAD: They have made it more difficult to toss even one coin into the Trevi Fountain, let alone the Hollywood allotment of three.


'Computer Virus' Joins the Lexicon
LEAD: The term ''computer virus'' spread into use like, well, a virus during 1988, but the outbreak came too late to make the latest editions of Merriam-Webster dictionaries.


Economy Is Bolstered By Exports
LEAD: Fueled by an increase in exports, the nation's economy grew in December at its highest rate in five months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, which is scheduled to be released today.


Talking Business with Schwab, the discount broker; Hard Competition Seen for Brokers
LEAD: Many stockbrokers will remember 1988 as a year they would like to forget.
After the crash of October 1987, a steady stream of money from individual investors became only a trickle.
Nearly every brokerage firm reported sharply lower profits, and many cut their staffs in an effort to compete in a tough new environment.


Careers; Educating Managers In Hungary
LEAD: BULGARIA last week stopped jamming radio programs broadcast from the West, a demonstration of openness.
Hungary also moved in that direction with the announcement in November that an International Management Center had been opened in Budapest.


Still Bullish, With Fingers Crossed
LEAD: Fear hung over the stock market early last year as investors worried that the October 1987 crash would be followed by a 1930's-like depression and market decline.
But the market turned in a remarkably strong performance, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 11.8 percent, ending the year at 2,168.57.


India-China Statement Angers Tibetan Exiles
LEAD: A little-noticed paragraph recognizing Chinese sovereignty over Tibet in a statement signed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi on a recent trip to Beijing has aroused alarm and resentment among Tibetan exiles in India, a spokesman for the Dalai Lama said here today.


Sara Lee Sells Two Subsidiaries
LEAD: The Sara Lee Corporation said it had sold its Lyon's Restaurant chain and the Peck Food Corporation to two separate buyers.
Terms were not disclosed for either sale.


Ghana, Once 'Hopeless,' Gets At Least the Look of Success
LEAD: More than five years ago, when the World Bank decided to make the state-dominated economy here a model for free-market innovations in Africa, Ghana was in the grip of stagnation.
Since then, Ghana has boasted Africa's highest consistent growth rate, an average of 6 percent a year since 1983.


Business Week's Move
LEAD: Business Week magazine has named Ray Hoffman to replace S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman as its lead radio announcer.
Mr.
Hoffman was Business Week's No. 2 announcer.
Mr.
Ruderman last year pleaded guilty to trading stocks based on his advance knowledge of Business Week stories.


No Big Airline Tie-Ups
LEAD: Heavy new security measures at European airports last week produced no major passenger snarls at check-in counters or delays in flights to the United States over a long New Year's weekend of light but growing trans-Atlantic air traffic.


Delayed NASA Missions Prepare for Takeoff
LEAD: AFTER a decade in the doldrums, grounded by budget cuts and the space shuttle accident, planetary exploration by the United States is primed for a big leap forward this year.


What Gandhi and Bhutto Didn't Discuss: Kashmir
LEAD: As the young Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met for the first time Thursday, raising hopes for less bitter dealings between the two powers of the Indian subcontinent, a small motorcade drove up out of history with a cautionary message: Remember Kashmir.


Bridge
LEAD: One of the world's oldest bridge clubs, the Studenterforeningen Bridge Club in Copenhagen, marked its 60th birthday recently with an international pairs event.
The diagramed deal won a Swedish player the prize for best-played hand, and the Swedish expert Sven-Olov Flodqvist suggests it would probably have won a prize for the best-bid hand, too, if such a prize had existed.


Hurricanes Try Harder and Rout Nebraska
LEAD: The proclamation came shortly after the Orange Bowl game ended tonight and, like much of what Jimmy Johnson says, it was not intended to win friends or soothe anyone's feelings.
The Miami coach felt his team had a point to prove against Nebraska and did so emphatically.
Now, he was ready to boast.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Explaining Last Summer's Drought  The 1988 drought was caused by cyclical changes in the tropical Pacific and had little to do with the greenhouse effect, new evidence indicates.
With an improving understanding of the global climate system, scientists have linked cold waters off South America to storms and atmospheric disturbances that drove the jet stream northward, causing drought in North America.

LEAD: Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' founder, general manager and vice president, said yesterday he would ask the league's competition committee, of which he is a member, to look into the question of fake injuries after the season.

Adams Examined
LEAD: Michael Adams, the Denver Nuggets' No. 2 scorer and most prolific 3-point shooter, was scheduled to undergo a bone scan to determine the nature of a painful injury to his right foot that will keep him out of tonight's game at San Antonio.


Backlash on Takeovers Is Feared
LEAD: It was the year of the big takeover.
Even leaving out the still to be concluded RJR Nabisco buyout that saw one bidder raise the ante on another by several billion dollars, there was a record $266 billion in mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts completed in 1988.


Fat-Cell Protein Is Implicated in Obesity
LEAD: IN a major advance in the study of obesity, researchers have discovered that abnormally low levels of a protein produced by fat cells may be linked to the propensity to gain weight.

LEAD: It was hard enough taking on all the Subway Alumni and the Freeway Alumni and the Windy City Alumni and the Sunbelt Alumni.

LEAD: The Agriculture Department has offered to reduce import restrictions on shipments of British swine, pork and pork products to the United States.

LEAD: The population of the United States was 246.9 million as the New Year began, almost 2.3 million higher than a year ago, the Census Bureau said Sunday.

LEAD: The six-story apartment building at 241 West 113th Street, just west of Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
Boulevard in Harlem, is the kind of abandoned ruin that marks all of New York City's poor neighborhoods.

LEAD: Although the economy and the performance of the stock market rebounded nicely from the October 1987 crash, corporations found investors unwilling to buy many new stock issues last year.

LEAD: ''We are in danger of chemical weapons becoming just another weapon of choice.

LEAD: Five African students were tortured by the police in the eastern city of Nanjing, after a week of racial unrest in that city, an African diplomat today quoted the students as saying.

LEAD: In an industry sometimes denigrated for its lack of boldness, J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, stands out in 1988 as the banker who redefined the boundaries of what is acceptable.


Discounting Not on Rise, Retailers Say
LEAD: Post-Christmas shoppers facing a sea of signs in store windows advertising huge discounts off ''our already reduced prices'' might find it hard to believe, but many retailers say discounts since Christmas have been equal to or slightly below those of the corresponding period last year.


Working Woman
LEAD: John Emmerling Inc. has added another member of the Time Inc. family to its client stable.
Working Woman, a publication of the Working Woman/ McCall's Group (which is partly owned by Time), has retained the agency to create a trade campaign that will debut in mid-January.
The magazine, which has a circulation rate base of 950,000, currently has no agency.


Depressed Woman Is Alive After Jump From the Verrazano
LEAD: A 22-year-old Staten Island woman under treatment for depression jumped from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge early yesterday and survived a 230-foot plunge to the icy waters below.


Scientists Track Clues Linking a Bacterium To Stomach Disorders
LEAD: NEW research has produced strong evidence that an S-shaped bacterium causes the common stomach disorder gastritis.
And scientists say there is increasing though inconclusive evidence that the microbe is linked to many stomach and duodenal ulcers.


Rain in Pennsylvania Found Most Acidic
LEAD: RAIN at a monitoring station in central Pennsylvania registered the highest acid content of 131 sites in 46 states, according to a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council.


Jersey Mayor Is Sworn For the Seventh Time
LEAD: Mayor Thomas G. Dunn was sworn in today for the seventh time.
It was also for the last time, he said.

He is Steven A. Minter.

Rates Are Mixed At Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.952 percent, down from 9.0393 percent last week and down for the second consecutive week.

LEAD: Coffee futures prices rose sharply yesterday despite weekend showers in the major coffee-growing region of Brazil, the world's largest producer.


Blacks Keep Reins in Georgia Town
LEAD: Black candidates won all six city offices Monday in this racially divided town, proving to many black residents that a victory by blacks last year in Keysville's first election since 1933 was not a fluke.

LEAD: A group of 129 members of the House of Representatives reintroduced the proposed equal rights amendment to the Federal Constitution today and urged President-elect George Bush to support it.


V.M.I. Names Shuck
LEAD: Jim Shuck was named as Virginia Military Institute's head coach yesterday, saying the job with the Keydets would pose challenges similar to those he faced as Army's offensive coordinator.
Shuck, 34, plans to use the wishbone offense, which has worked well for Army, as he takes over the job with a five-year, $52,000-a-year contract.


Budd Speaks Out
LEAD: Seeking to counter renewed criticism of her political views, Zola Budd said yesterday she did not support any ''political system that entrenches the superiority of one race over another'' or violates basic human rights.
The former world cross-country champion issued one of her most explicit political statements in response to a controversy provoked by interviews she recently granted to British television networks.

LEAD: Albert Boyars mailed out a news release just last September that said the ''New York Experience'' was ''timeless,'' like New York City itself.
Here it is January and there is no longer an ''Experience'' to experience.
The 55-minute sound and light blitzkreig closed Monday night, proof that timelessness and permanence are two different things in New York.


Pepsico's Bottling Accord Off
LEAD: Pepsico Inc.'s agreement to buy the General CinemaCorporation's soft-drink bottling business for $1.5 billion has been canceled because questions from the Federal Trade Commission prevented the deal's completion before the end of 1988, the two companies said yesterday.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the 1988 performance of stocks on the American Stock Exchange misidentified the eighth-biggest loser for the year.
It is Energy Development Partners Ltd., a Denver-based partnership, not the Energy Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Public Service Enterprise Group.

LEAD: HOW do you plug a $70 billion hole with a handful of small change?
If you are the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, you use a little creative accounting and a lot of i.o.u.'s.
Last week the board dealt away 34 bankrupt savings and loan associations, ending a year in which it committed the Government to $38 billion in bailouts.

LEAD: You might think that Jimmy Carter's going home to Plains, Ga., or Harry Truman's going back to Independence, Mo., would be a much bigger deal than Ronald Reagan's coming home to Hollywood.

None, till they spawned Presidents.

LEAD:  SKIING  Swiss Wins 3d Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland posted her third World Cup slalom victory of the season, winning at Maribor, Yugoslavia, yesterday.
She finished ahead of Monika Maierhofer of Austria and Tamara McKinney of the United States.
It was Schneider's sixth World Cup victory over all this season.

Correction
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the outlook for mergers and leveraged buyouts misidentified the company that recently put the credit ratings of Salomon Brothers and Shearson Lehman Hutton under review.
It was Moody's Investors Service.

LEAD: The New Jersey Waterfront Marathon will have a revamped course this April that will start on the George Washington Bridge and end at Giants Stadium.


Edwards Injured
LEAD: Eddie (The Eagle) Edwards of Britain, the ski jumper who last February soared and dipped to international renown during the Winter Olympics at Calgary for his dogged competitive spirit despite extremely limited talent, yesterday broke a collarbone during a practice session in Innsbruck, Austria.
Training for a World Cup event, Edwards lost control of his right ski in mid-air and tumbled several times after landing, suffering a head injury and skin abrasions as well as the broken collarbone.

LEAD: The credit markets began the new year on a sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply in light trading.

Oliver L. Austin, 85, Ornithologist, Is Dead
LEAD: Oliver L. Austin Jr., an ornithologist who wrote a definitive study, ''Birds of the World,'' in 1961 and who was curator emeritus of ornithology at the Florida Museum of Natural History, died Saturday at his retirement home in Gainesville, Fla.
He was 85 years old and had lived for many years in Tuckahoe, N.Y., and in Wellfleet.

Soviet Travel Curb on Goods May Aim at East Bloc Allies
LEAD: A Soviet regulation that will bar foreigners from taking caviar, television sets and refrigerators out of the country after Feb. 1 appears to be the latest shot in a growing trade war between the Soviet Union and some of its Eastern European economic allies over scarce consumer goods.


EATING WELL
LEAD: Roast squab with port wine sauce; grilled chicken breast with white bean, fennel and escarole salad; braised salmon on a bed of barley and white rice: hardly Spartan dishes, yet they are part of a program for people who want to eat healthful but elegant food when they dine out.


Topics of The Times; And Read All Over
LEAD: A careful editor, amused by the vagaries of the English language, has for years found the word ''misled'' a momentary puzzle because in her head she read ''MY-zuld.'' Then it dawned on her that the word ''read'' itself poses a problem: its tense can be understood only from context.
That is, although the spelling of misled might mislead her into a mispronunciation, she is not likely to be misled into the wrong tense.


Connecticut To Address Budget Gap
LEAD: The Connecticut General Assembly will begin its 1989 session today, confronting not the opportunities of recent years but rather the limitations presented by a huge expected gap in the state budget.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about plans to address Israel's economic problems rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from Finance Minister Shimon Peres.
The quotation should have read, ''This is a directed and serious attempt to turn the economy toward growth, export, industry and economic independence''; he did not say ''dependence.


In Modern Times, Shrinking Standards
LEAD: REMEMBER when an acceptable substitute for a biscuit or cookie cutter was one end of an empty can of frozen orange juice?
When the ingredient list made reference to a No. 2 can?
When there was one size coffee can and it held a pound of coffee?
It also held a loaf of bread, which is why so many recipes years ago called for a coffee can for bread baking.

LEAD: Because of Lyme disease, Claire Palermo walks with a cane now.
At the age of 39, she says she sometimes feels like she is 82.
In the last two years, she has seen 42 doctors, spent $30,000 on medical treatment, missed four and a half months of work and experienced a multitude of symptoms, from arthritis and heart palpitations to profound fatigue and depression.

The Chicken Dinner, Both Humble and Noble
LEAD: CHANGING a meal's status requires more than a change of name, but not much more.
Roast chicken is still roast chicken whether you label it haute cuisine, bourgeois cuisine or country cooking; even calling it ''poulet roti'' will not transmogrify this simple bird.
Move, however, from the kitchen to the dining room and from everyday dishes to fine china, then add an appetizer and dessert, and a family meal becomes a festive dinner for guests.

LEAD: A new tremor rocked the earthquake-devastated Armenian city of Leninakan on Saturday, but it caused only minor damage to buildings, city relief authorities said today.

Israeli Diamond Exports
LEAD: Israel exported polished diamonds worth an all-time high of $2.46 billion in 1988, the Israel Diamond Exchange's president, Moshe Schnitzer, said today.
Mr.
Schnitzer said the figure, which compares with $2.06 billion last year, represented about a third of all Israeli industrial exports.
He said the added value after the cost of rough stone imports was $600 million.

Iceland Devaluation
LEAD: Iceland devalued its currency, the crown, today for the fourth time in less than 12 months to ease the island's crippling financial problems, and the nation warned of more economic measures to come.
The central bank said it was devaluing the currency by 4 percent against the dollar, bringing the rate to 48.08 crowns from 46.16.

How to Recognize Danger Signs of Depression
LEAD: To the Editor:


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: DRIED salted cod has been associated with Spanish, Portuguese and French cooking for centuries.
It was especially valuable before refrigeration because of its long shelf life.
The cod, some of which measure up to six feet long, were usually salted aboard fishing vessels in large wooden barrels.
Before cooking, the fillets were soaked in water to remove the salt and reconstitute the flesh.

New 12% British Bond
LEAD: The British Government today introduced a high-interest bond guaranteed to earn 12 percent a year over five years.
National Savings, a Government savings plan, said the interest on its new ''capital bond'' is accumulated and paid out at redemption, so the value including interest of a $:100 bond held for five years would be $:176.24, or about $320 at today's currency exchange rates.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Yields Rise For Week
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, with the yield increases in C.D.'s concentrated in the six-month and one-year maturities.


East Dominates West in Race for Eclipse Awards
LEAD: New York horses and horsemen were rewarded with a virtual sweep of thoroughbred racing's championship prizes.


Nightmare a Reality As Body of Mother Is Found in Freezer
LEAD: A woman who had had nightmares about her mother's 1985 disappearance pried open a locked basement freezer and found the woman's battered body on Monday, the police said.
The discovery led her father, a high school dean of students, to confess the slaying.


Campaign-Financing Law Is Amended
LEAD: The New York City Council, after a committee meeting marked by shouts of anger and frustration, overwhelmingly approved a series of amendments to the city's new public campaign-financing law.


The State of 3 States
LEAD: Money was on the minds of the gov-ernors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday.
They warned their constituencies separately of budget constraints necessitated by spending that is outpacing revenues.


Ball for Cleaner Air
LEAD: On Inauguration Eve, two environmental groups will sponsor a ball to raise public awareness of air pollution and its effects, specifically how the atmosphere traps pollutants under the sun's heat, like a greenhouse, in a way that is some think will raise the Earth's temperature.
The ball will be held in a greenhouse.


Florence Ryder, 88, Newspaper Publisher
LEAD: Florence Ryder, chairman of the Times Journal Company, which publishes several weekly newspapers serving members of the armed forces worldwide and a number of suburban newspapers in the vicinity of Washington and San Diego, died in her sleep yesterday at her home in Washington.
She was 88 years old.


Jersey Faces Shortfalls in Revenue, Kean Warns
LEAD: Echoing concerns in neighboring states, Gov.
Thomas H. Kean today disclosed growing shortfalls in the state's tax revenues and warned that New Jersey's next budget would be ''very tight.''


From Regan to Bush
LEAD: President-elect George Bush is receiving a lot of advice these days, some of it unsolicited.
Still, he might welcome the thoughts of Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's ousted chief of staff, in the form of a chapter added to the paperback edition of his 1987 memoir ''For the Record.''


Baker's First Blunder
LEAD: The Bush administration, three weeks before it takes office, has sent a signal of irresolution and hypocrisy in dealing with the Soviet Union.


Europe's Grand Plan for Web of Fast Trains
LEAD: European nations are undertaking the world's most ambitious high-speed rail project, which will tie Europe closer together by allowing travelers to move across the Continent at speeds up to 186 miles an hour.

LEAD: *
Progress Software Corp., Bedford, Mass., to Giardini/Russell Group, Watertown, Mass., with a $500,000 budget.


Cyanide Yogurt Case Still Puzzles Officials
LEAD: Investigators believe the cyanide poisoning of a teen-ager who ate tainted yogurt is an isolated incident, but they said yesterday that they were looking into a possibility that it might be linked to an unsolved product-tampering case two years ago.


Thompson's Choice
LEAD: Daley Thompson of Britain, the 1983 world decathlon champion and the 1980 and 1984 Olympic gold medalist in the event, says that Ben Johnson should be banned from international competition for life.
Johnson was banned for two years after testing positive for steroid use following his victory in the 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics.


14-Year-Old Bystander Is Killed In a Police Shootout in Brooklyn
LEAD: A 14-year-old boy returning home from church services in Brooklyn was shot in the head and killed Tuesday night after he and his family were caught in crossfire between a policeman and a robbery suspect.


Westerners Can Avoid Soviet Customs Curb
LEAD: New regulations barring foreigners from taking scarce consumer goods out of the Soviet Union after Feb. 1 will not apply to Westerners who buy caviar, vodka and other items and pay for them with dollars and other convertible currencies in special stores, a customs official said today.


Trial Begins On Newhouse Tax Issue
LEAD: Testimony began today in an attempt by the Government to win more than $600 million in taxes from the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse, who built one of the country's largest newspaper chains before his death in 1979.


Some Travelers Switching Airlines
LEAD: Concerned about the possibility of bombings, some travelers have begun to switch from United States airlines to foreign carriers for their flights to Europe.


Anti-Cholesterol Move by Keebler
LEAD: The Keebler Company, which sells more than $1 billion worth of cookies, crackers and other snack foods each year, said it would stop using tropical oils and animal fats in all its products.
The company, a unit of United Biscuits (Holdings) P.L.C. of Britain, is the latest food manufacturer to respond to consumer concerns about the cholesterol problems associated with coconut oil, palm oil, palm kernel oil, lard and beef fat, all of which are high in saturated fat.

LEAD: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in lackluster, apathetic trading yesterday.

World Bank Raises Rates
LEAD: The World Bank is raising interest rates for relatively prosperous developing countries to 7.65 percent annually, the first such increase since the bank began lending at variable rates in 1982, officials said today.

Good Riddance to the Welfare Hotels; At Least Help the Homeless Off the Street
LEAD: ''I don't pray!
Pray for what?
I been prayin' all my life and I'm still here.
When I came to this hotel, I still believed in God.
I said: 'Maybe God can help us to survive.' I lost my faith.
My hopes.
And everything.
Ain't nobody - no God, no Jesus - gonna help us in no way.''


AFRICANS IN BEIJING BOYCOTT CLASSES
LEAD: African students at a Beijing language institute began boycotting classes today to protest what they feel is racism in China, and interracial clashes were reported in another city after two weeks of racial unrest.


CNN in Latin America
LEAD: The Turner Broadcasting System said today that it would transmit the Cable News Network 24 hours a day to Latin America on the Pan American Satellite Corporation's international satellite.
The agreement followed tests that began in November, TBS said.
Turner's decision to use Pan American Satellite is a victory for the private company, based in Greenwich, Conn., and a defeat for Intelsat, the international consortium that operates most communications satellites.


Jazz Waives Kofoed
LEAD: The Utah Jazz yesterday waived the second-year guard Bart Kofoed, following an incident in which a teammate, Bobby Hansen, sustained a broken cheekbone during a scuffle at a New Year's Eve party. ''There are many versions of the story,'' said the Jazz general manager, Dave Checketts. ''The fact is, a punch was thrown, and I don't see that the situation could ever be patched up again.

Mr.
Lewenthal died of a heart attack on Nov. 21 at the age of 62.

LEAD: Ken Miller said he did not leave Merrill Lynch almost one year ago to create a one-man boutique.
That is why he called his fledgling deal shop the Lodestar Group, to suggest his role as guiding light. ''If you name a firm after yourself, it doesn't help in getting additional personnel,'' Mr.
Miller said.

LEAD: The defense lawyer in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that his client ''probably would be found guilty'' in the death of Lisa Steinberg and that he would probably be sent to prison.


Hoare Govett Sets Cutback
LEAD: The brokerage Security Pacific Hoare Govett announced today that it was getting out of the British and international bond markets and laying off 140 people.


Fire Shuts Down a Reactor
LEAD: A fire in a turbine building at the Oconee Nuclear Station on Tuesday caused operators to shut down one of its three reactors, a utility spokeswoman said today.
Workers were starting the plant's Unit 1 reactor, which had shut down automatically Monday, when an electrical breaker apparently caught fire, the station manager, Mike Tuckman, said.

LEAD: Moving to counter criticism that the Civilian Complaint Review Board has not done all it could to expose police wrongdoing in Tompkins Square Park last August, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has authorized the panel's investigators to selectively reinterrogate officers, this time under grants of immunity from departmental charges.

LEAD: Contributions to the 77th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are running ahead of the last appeal, and donors seem to be particularly alarmed by the desperate plight of the homeless.

LEAD: The Brooklyn block where Norris Graham died is a bleak stretch of sidewalk that looks as if it is more for dying than living.

Up to $2 Million Is Missing From a Chicago Storage Site
LEAD: As much as $2 million in coins owned by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago is missing from a suburban armored car company and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered the case, the authorities said today.

LEAD: ''PIPE smokers are funny people,'' said Vince Nastri, president of the Barclay-Rex Pipe Shop, started by his grandfather in 1910, in the Wall Street area. ''They break their pipes, and it's like they've broken their legs.
They have to have them fixed right away.''


Review/Television; Dinosaurs: Faster, Smarter, Warmer
LEAD: The image of the dinosaur is being refurbished.
Long considered just dumb, oversized lizards, the creatures that dominated earth for 140 million years are getting a better press.
Revisionist paleontologists now hold that dinosaurs were warmblooded, quite energetic, not necessarily unintelligent and, in at least one species, caring of their young.

LEAD: The much-honored ''Portraits'' campaign created by Ogilvy &amp; Mather for the American Express Company is adding another leaf to its laurel wreath: Ms. magazine's first annual ''Making A Difference'' advertising award.

LEAD: Officials grappling with New York's huge drug problem welcomed proposals today by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo in his State of the State Message to combat drug abuse.
But some officials criticized the Governor's program as thin on specifics and new initiatives.

LEAD: Ruth Moore Garbe, a writer of books about science, died of cancer Monday at her brother's home in San Francisco.
She was 80 years old lived in San Francisco.

LEAD: The Energy Department estimated today that it could cost $53 billion to $92 billion to clean up radioactive and chemical pollution at plants used to manufacture nuclear bombs and at other military and civilian installations under the department's control.

As director of co-operative advertising at D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles for the last two and a half years, he has routinely lured dozens of companies to join in one ad, a procedure that has gained the agency about $10 million in revenues.

16 Die in Philippines
LEAD: A motor launch carrying more than 140 people sank in the central Philippines and at least 16 people were killed, the coast guard said today.
Twelve people were reported missing.
The vessel, the Jem II, sank Tuesday off Romblon Island, about 150 miles southeast of Manila, a coast guard officer said.

LEAD: Tradition means a great deal on Capitol Hill.
So does family.
Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has honored both on the first day of every new Congress since he first came to Washington in 1955.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Sukova Advances: Top-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia advanced to the third round of the $150,000 Danone Australian hard-court championship in Brisbane yesterday with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over unseeded Alexia Dechaume of France.
Fifth-seeded Hana Mandlikova, a native of Czechoslovakia who is an Australian citizen, continued her recent poor form when she served 18 double faults during her 6-4, 6-4 loss to unseeded Catherine Tanvier of France.

New Flaws Are Discovered at Nuclear Arms Plant
LEAD: Engineers working to repair reactors at the nation's most important nuclear weapons plant encountered more potentially serious structural weaknesses today that could cause further delay in producing tritium, a vital ingredient of atomic weapons.

Punitive Damages Strike at Intent to Harm
LEAD: To the Editor:


9 Are Convicted of Extortion On Restaurant Inspections
LEAD: Six New York City health inspectors and three restaurant consultants were convicted yesterday of extorting thousands of dollars from restaurant owners by threatening to cite them for violations or close them.


AFRICANS IN CHINA ARE FINALLY FREED
LEAD: About 45 African students who had been held against their will by the authorities in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing for the last 10 days were released today.
Most plan to leave China as soon as possible.

Rail Police Resent Extra Burden of Homeless
LEAD: Freezing weather and gusty winds have prompted many homeless people to seek shelter in New York City's transportation terminals, prompting complaints from the police at Pennsylvania Station that they are being forced to work overtime to keep the homeless moving.


Treasury Issues Continue to Dip
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped again in moderate trading yesterday as market participants awaited this morning's release of December employment data.


White Supremacist Guilty
LEAD: A Federal jury today found a white supremacist guilty of conspiring to violate a family's civil rights.
The defendant, Gary Skillman, 24 years old, was convicted of of using force and the threat of force to intimidate the family and of burning a cross outside the family's home in Orange County.
The crimes carry a maximum sentence of 21 years.

LEAD:  The Economy


Russian at U.N. Says Moscow Had Urged Restraint by the U.S.
LEAD: The Soviet representative to the United Nations said today the Soviet Union had urged the United States to ''show restraint in the area'' before the aerial encounter in which two Libyan warplanes were shot down over the Mediterranean.


Arbitration for Thon
LEAD: Dickie Thon, the San Diego shortstop who had demanded a trade, exercised another right yesterday by filing for salary arbitration.
He was the only one of the 176 eligible players to file on the first day of the 12-day filing period.
Under the trade demand, the Padres must trade Thon by March 15 or lose him as a free agent.

Tickets: children and the elderly, $2.50; others, $5.

Rev. Charles T. Fritsch, A Biblical Scholar, 76
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Charles T. Fritsch, a biblical scholar and former professor of Old Testament literature at Princeton Theological Seminary, died Monday at his home in Jamesburg, N.J., after a long illness.
He was 76 years old.


U.S.-CUBA ENMITY MAY BE RELAXING
LEAD: After three decades of mutual hostility, the United States and Cuba appear to be edging toward a wider range of contacts that some diplomats say may lead to somewhat improved relations.


Pacers Pick Versace In Third Change
LEAD: In their third change of bench leadership while losing 23 of 29 games this season, the Indiana Pacers yesterday named Dick Versace, an assistant with the Detroit Pistons for three seasons, as their coach.
The Pacers lost their first seven games under Jack Ramsay, dropped two more under the assistant coaches Mel Daniels and Dave Twardzik after Ramsay resigned, then won 6 of 20 games under George Irvine, vice president of basketball operations.


Review/Art; Man Ray's Beginnings
LEAD: As it was for many young American artists at the time, the Armory Show of 1913 was for Man Ray an event of singular significance.
It put his mind ''in a turmoil,'' he recalled years later, ''the turmoil of a seed that has been planted in fertile ground, ready to break through.'' What Man Ray produced during the next eight years - beginning with the Cezanne-derived canvases he painted of scenes around his home in Ridgefield, N.J., and then in the photographs, collages and other Dada-inspired objects he created after moving to New


Auto Sales in '88 Set 2d-Highest Mark Ever
LEAD: The automobile industry enjoyed its second-best year ever in the United States in 1988, with sales of more than 15 million cars and trucks for an unprecedented fourth straight year.


CARLUCCI APPROVES BASE-CLOSING PLAN
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci approved a plan today to close dozens of military bases around the country, calling it a ''unique opportunity'' to save money that had been endorsed by military leaders.


Dexter Masters, 80, British Editor; Warned of Perils of Atomic Age
LEAD: Dexter Masters, a writer and an editor, died of bronchial pneumonia at St.
John's Hospice in Springfield, Ill., yesterday.
He was 80 years old and lived in Totnes, England.

Jersey Acts to Lift a Hauler's License
LEAD: In the first major crackdown on violators of the state's costly year-old garbage-disposal rules, the Board of Public Utilities has voted to ban a hauler from operating in the state.


'Xanadu/The Millions'
LEAD: Storytelling, music and dance will be combined in ''Xanadu/The Millions,'' presented by Mark Taylor and Friends tonight through Sunday at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street.
Suggested by the story of Marco Polo, the multi-media piece was choreographed by Mr.
Taylor to a score for percussion and amplified cello, composed and played at each performance by Elise Tobin.


Review/Art; The Possibilities of Line at the Nolan Gallery
LEAD: Given that line is the primary vehicle of drawing, a trip to the David Nolan Gallery, by whatever means available, is in order.
On view is an exhibition that traces the evolution of an eccentric linear drawing style in the work of Rudi Troger, born in 1929 and a teacher at the Academy of Fine Arts in Munich, and two of his students, Erwin Pfrang and Franz Gunzel.

Correction
LEAD: A brief article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday about the unemployment rate in West Germany described the change incorrectly.
The rate fell to 8.7 percent in 1988, from 8.9 percent in 1987, but the total number of unemployed did rise.


Paul Brown Gives Bengals A Regimen
LEAD: After the Cincinnati Bengals' switchboard operator plugged in the phone call, the voice that answered announced: ''Coach Brown's office.''


Iran-Contra Events Span the Reagan Era
LEAD:  Aug. 4, 1981 Maj.
Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps is assigned to duty at the White House with the National Security Council.
December 1981 President Reagan signs a ''finding'' authorizing a covert Central Intelligence Agency operation to support the Nicaraguan rebels, or contras.
December 1982 The first Boland amendment becomes law barring use of Federal money to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua.


Irvin Shapiro, 82, Distributor of Films By Foreign Directors
LEAD: Irvin Shapiro, a film importer and distributor who introduced many notable foreign movies to the United States, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Sunday at his home in New York.
He was 82 years old.

John E. Lawe, 69, the President Of the Transport Union, Is Dead
LEAD: John E. Lawe, president of the Transport Workers Union of America since 1985 and before that president of Local 100, which represents New York City's subway and bus employees, died of complications from cancer of the esophagus yesterday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
He was 69 years old.


Bonus to U.S. From Clash: Intelligence
LEAD: In shooting down two Libyan fighter planes, the Navy added to its knowledge of Libyan air defenses, information that would be useful if the Reagan Administration decided to attack what it says is a chemical weapons plant.


Samuel T. Carter 3d, Author, Is Dead at 84
LEAD: Samuel T. Carter 3d, a radio and television writer who retired to write on American history, died of cancer Dec. 28 at the Ponperaug Woods Health Center in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn.
He was 84 years old and lived in Heritage Village.


Ex-Insider Who Elects To Remain on Outside
LEAD: At a moment of political transition, when legions of potential officeholders are cajoling, conspiring or cudgeling their way toward the inner circles of power, former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. shows every sign of digging in firmly on the outside.


Half a Billion for One Plane
LEAD: The Pentagon's sophisticated new weapons are often criticized as gold-plated.
Not the B-2, the Air Force's latest bomber.
Forget plate: the aircraft costs nearly its weight in solid gold.
Last month, on his final day as Secretary of the Air Force, Edward Aldridge said that each B-2 Stealth bomber will cost $516 million.


Israel Approves $550 Million in Budget Cuts
LEAD: A proposal by Finance Minister Shimon Peres to reduce the Israeli Government budget by $550 million was approved tonight by the Israeli Cabinet.


Review/Art; Four New Sculptors
LEAD: Curtis Mitchell is one of many artists living in a raw warehouse area in Brooklyn, not far from the Brooklyn Bridge.
One of his three untitled works in the ''Emerging Sculptors'' show at the Sculpture Center was inspired by a visit to Manhattan's glitzy Trump Tower.
With its rectangular trunk shape, its marble facing and a carpet placed over it as carefully as a shroud, the sculpture suggests a fancy portable altar.


Global Trade System Gains
LEAD: As expected, the governors of the New York Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday night to join Globex, an electronic futures trading system developed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Ltd.
The system is designed to afford traders around the globe access to both markets after their normal trading hours.


This Is the Team That Embry Built
LEAD: No joke.
The Cleveland Cavaliers, once the comic relief of the National Basketball Association, now have the best record in the league.


Dow Climbs To Highest Since Crash
LEAD: Stocks rose broadly in heavier trading yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to the highest close since the October 1987 crash.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment a measure that would require increased regulation of private automated trading systems.

West Germans Try to Curb Dollar's Rally
LEAD: The West German central bank intervened against a surging dollar yesterday, indicating its increasing displeasure with the dollar's growing strength.


Man Executed in Missouri for Killing Waitress
LEAD: A convicted killer was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a tavern waitress, becoming the first Missouri inmate executed since 1965.


Soviets Curbing Private Businesses
LEAD: The Soviet Government has sent a wave of alarm through the growing private business sector with sweeping new limits on a range of private businesses, including medical care, publishing, film making, video salons, schools, concert booking and the manufacture of religious artifacts.


Reagan Supports 50% Raise for U.S. Officials
LEAD: President Reagan decided today to recommend that members of Congress, Federal judges and top members of the executive branch get a 50 percent pay increase, the White House and Congressional officials said this evening.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Braniff's purchase of aircraft from Airbus Industrie described a transaction involving Pan American World Airways incorrectly.
Airbus and International Aero Engines paid $115 million, plus the return of Pan Am's deposit, for the right to assign the order and options to Braniff.


Snow Falls in Iran's Desert
LEAD: Snow has fallen on the desert regions of Khur and Biyabanak in eastern Iran for the first time in 50 years, the official Iranian press agency reported today.
Officials said four inches of snow had fallen in the last 24 hours, forcing schools to close.


Koch Ends Support for River Projects
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch, anticipating election-year criticism of his development policies, has withdrawn his support for two large waterfront projects and says he will run ''on a campaign of balanced development.''


Raimondi Cancels
LEAD: Ruggero Raimondi, the bass who was to sing in the ''Pavarotti Plus ...
Plus!'' concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday at 8 P.M., has dropped out because of illness.
Paul Plishka will take his place in the ensemble pieces requiring a bass.
The performance is to be broadcast by the public television on ''Live from Lincoln Center'' and simulcast locally on WNCN radio (104.3 FM).

Armenians Raise a Glass to All Those Who Cared
LEAD: Normally on this day, Christmas Eve on the Armenian Church calendar, the Arutunyan family would have invited friends and relatives for a joyous feast and exchange of gifts.
And the next day they would have gone to the cemetery to remember the dead.

LEAD: The ESPN cable network yesterday won the television rights to 175 major league baseball games a year for four years, beginning in the 1990 season, in a $400 million deal.

F.D.A. Panel Finds No Need for Change In Taking of the Pill
LEAD: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said today that no changes in the use of birth control pills or in warning labels on the pills are warranted despite new evidence suggesting that use of the pill may increase the risk of breast cancer.

Mr.
Okada, a Japanese composer living in New York, has described the piece as an audiovisual madrigal.
It is also to be performed tomorrow evening at 8:30.

Exemptions by the C.F.T.C.
LEAD: In a policy retreat, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today exempted from its regulatory jurisdiction certain financial instruments linked to the price of oil, gold and other commodities.


Tyson in Accident
LEAD: Mike Tyson was in another car accident yesterday, when his 1988 Lincoln was hit by another car trying to get around a stalled vehicle in Las Vegas, Nev.
No one was injured in the accident, which police described as a minor fender-bender that slightly damaged the door of Tyson's car.
Tyson, a passenger, was on way to his doctor to be fitted for a mouthpiece.

LEAD: Following is a list of 145 military installations affected by the recommendations of the Commission on Base Realignment and Closure.
The numbers after each installation indicate a loss or gain of jobs and the amount of annual savings where any is expected.
ALABAMA  Alabama Ammunition Plant, closed, minus 1, $30,000.


Review/Art; Esthetics of Comfort
LEAD: He was ''Coddy'' to her.
She was ''Pussy'' to him.
They were friends, colleagues, collaborators.
Between them, they had an immense influence on the way certain people wanted to live.
In New York, in Boston, in Newport, R.I., in the Berkshires and on Long Island, their ideas were law, more or less, for those who did not blanch at the tab.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Virginia is expected to announce on Friday the first indictment in a broad investigation of accusations of bribery and fraud involving Pentagon officials, the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: When Emma McDougald entered the New York Infirmary 10 years ago to deliver her second child, she was a healthy 31-year-old who worked as a subway token clerk, managed her household and was planning to return to college.

LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida financier who took over the Singer Company last year, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 12 counts of violating securities and tax laws, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government.

LEAD: Senior State Department officials said today that West Germany was not moving quickly enough to respond to American assertions that a German chemical company had helped Libya build a vast chemical plant.

George Deukmejian announced today that he would not seek a third term in 1990, saying that he wants to return to private life for ''new challenges.''


Iranian Concern To Make Peugeots
LEAD: Iran's biggest auto company, Iran Khodrow, has signed a contract with Peugeot S.A. of France to produce 500,000 cars in the next 10 years, the Iranian press agency reported today.


'88 Decline in U.S. Executions Defies Predictions
LEAD: Fewer criminals were executed in the United States in 1988 than in any of the previous five years despite a 1987 Supreme Court decision that prompted predictions that the tide of executions would rise.

LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Says Tape Shows Missiles On a Libyan Jet
LEAD: The United States said today that it had visual evidence indicating that two Libyan fighter planes were armed when they were shot down Wednesday by Navy fighters over the Mediterranean.
It accused Libya of lying in asserting that the planes were unarmed reconnaissance aircraft.


Oliver North: Still Accountable
LEAD: Oliver North, the man at the heart of the Iran-contra affair, has cut the heart out of the criminal case against him.
The special Federal prosecutor, after struggling to reconcile the needs of national security with the demands of a public trial, has decided that he must drop the major conspiracy and theft charges against the former National Security Council staff officer.


Newhouse Head Testifies
LEAD: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. today lifted a small bit of the curtain that has kept from public view the inside workings of his family's vast newspaper, magazine and broadcast holdings.


For Christmas of '88, It's Adios and Ta-Ta
LEAD: Three events will ring out the Christmas season this weekend: a parade and a concert drawing on Hispanic traditions, and a Boar's Head and Yule Log Festival recalling old England.


Duke Remains Unbeaten
LEAD: Despite a lackluster offensive performance in the first half, top-ranked Duke led Davidson by 15 points, so Coach Mike Krzyzewski knew the Blue Devils' defense was effective.


Bengals' Wilson Arrested
LEAD: Stanley Wilson, the Bengals' often-troubled running back who was suspended for the entire 1987 season for substance abuse, was arrested early this morning and charged with disorderly conduct.


Keep Family Planning Free of Ideology
LEAD: To the Editor:


In Tripoli, Business Is Almost as Usual
LEAD: Shops were open, workers went to their jobs and commerce and business seemed normal here today.
But a day after an aerial confrontation in which two Libyan fighter planes were shot down, there was anxiety over what the Americans might do next.


Officer Removed Badge At Melee, Police Assert
LEAD: A 32-year-old New York City police officer was suspended yesterday and ordered to face trial on a departmental charge that he removed his badge during a melee last summer at Tompkins Square Park.


A Correction
LEAD: An article on Wednesday incompletely identified a West German company allegedly involved in illegal shipments of nuclear materials to third world countries.
The company is Alfred Hempel KG GmbH &amp; Company of Dusseldorf, not the F. W. Hempel Company Inc., also of Dusseldorf.

LEAD:  Friday  DAY FOR QUARTETS


Spielberg and Warner's Plan Cartoons
LEAD: The director Steven Spielberg, a longtime lover of animated cartoons, is joining forces with Warner Brothers for a new television version of Warner's famous ''Merrie Melodies'' cartoons, to be called ''Tiny Tunes.''


A New Arafat Veto by Violence?
LEAD: Yasir Arafat should not be surprised that every word he utters, every statement made in his name is meticulously scrutinized.
The world has so long associated the Palestine Liberation Organization he heads with terrorism that the credibility of his recent renunciation of this practice remains fragile at best.


The Singer Madonna Again Files for Divorce
LEAD: The actor Sean Penn and Madonna, the singer, have separated and are planning to end their three-year marriage, a spokesman for Mr.
Penn said today.


Magee Shows He Belongs In Champions' Tourney
LEAD: Andrew Magee admits that he was intimidated by the big-name players while spending the last four years earning his spurs on the PGA Tour.
He remembers the first time he played with Jack Nicklaus when he was a rookie.


South African Insurgents Agree To Shut Their Bases, Angola Says
LEAD: The African National Congress has agreed to close its military training bases here, Angola's President said today.


The lonely view from the bench for the new judge who must undergo a rite of passage
LEAD: The new judge, clad in a T-shirt and shorts, walked past a couple of lawyers at a local health club.
Only a few years ago, he knew, both of his one-time bar brethren would have ignored him. ''Good evening, your Honor,'' said one, thinking he was leaving.
In fact, the judge was only going to the Nautilus machine, and when he emerged a few minutes later he passed them again.


Robert Coles, Ophthalmologist, Dies at 68
LEAD: Dr.
Robert S. Coles, an internationally known ophthalmologist and educator, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness.
He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Enron Gas Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, signed a 15-year $150 million agreement to supply natural gas to a co-generation plant to be constructed in Uniondale, L.I., as part of the Nassau District Energy System, which supplies power on Long Island.

LEAD: Wyse Technology, once a fast-growing maker of personal computers and computer terminals, said today that it would reduce its work force by 15 percent in response to steep drops in revenue.
The company also announced that its president and chief operating officer, Phillip E. White, had left to join another company.
