Islanders Overcome Bruins With 5 Goals in Second Period
LEAD: Brent Sutter, who normally suffers through his post-game analyses of Islander games this season, basked in this one and even allowed some nostalgia for shinier seasons to temper his recollections of tonight's 5-3 victory over the Bruins.


Mullen Becomes Rangers' Odd Man In
LEAD: It wasn't much of a shot.
In fact, it barely qualified as a pass.
But for the Rangers, the puck that was launched without much speed or intent turned out to possess an unerring sense of direction.


Panel Lines Up Some Glitter For Eve of the Inauguration
LEAD: The co-chairmen of the committee mapping the activities surrounding President-elect George Bush's inauguration announced a number of plans today, including agreement by Bob Hope and Chuck Yeager to serve as grand marshals in the inaugural parade.


Shenyang Journal; A City That Undoes Mao Under His Steady Gaze
LEAD: This drab, Dickensian city, where a statue of Mao presides over the snow-covered central square, is best known for its soot and industry.


Less Is Still Enough For Depleted Bears
LEAD: In 1985, the Chicago Bears steamrollered the opposition almost every week en route to an impressive victory in Super Bowl XX.
Now a Bears team with less firepower, less talent and many more injuries is struggling and usually winning.


India Hangs Two Sikhs Convicted In Assassination of Indira Gandhi
LEAD: Two men convicted in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in October 1984 were hanged this morning, the Government announced.


FOR STALIN PURGES, YET MORE CRITICISM
LEAD: The Communist Party called today for the mass rehabilitation of Soviet citizens convicted by the summary courts that carried out Stalin's purges.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $700 million in real estate mortgage investment conduit securities.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creative Star Is Joining Hill, Holliday
LEAD: JOHN FERRELL, the creative prodigy whose demotion and subsequent departure from Young &amp; Rubicam last fall stunned the advertising industry, is joining the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos as executive vice president and chief creative officer.


Farm Credit Bank Cancels Offering
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation said yesterday that it would not conduct its regularly scheduled offering on Jan. 23 because it and its borrowers have only a limited need now to raise cash in the debt market for medium- and long-term financing.


Pop/Jazz; Recalling A Pop Artist And a Friend
LEAD: ''Andy, it's me/Haven't seen you for a while/I wish I had talked to you more when you were alive,'' begins the elegiac lyric for ''Hello It's Me,'' one of 14 new songs written by John Cale and Lou Reed for their new musical suite, ''Songs for 'Drella.''


Bush Is Urged to Fight Threat of Global Warming
LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences urged President-elect George Bush today to place the threat of a significant increase in global temperatures high on his agenda because ''the future welfare of human society'' is at risk.

Paris Broker Stake To Bankers Trust
LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has agreed to take a 49 percent stake in Didier Philippe S.A., a French stockbroker.
Didier Philippe said in a statement that the bank would not take any role in running the brokerage and that its current directors would retain control.


Cocaine Blamed in Bus Deaths
LEAD: A bus accident last May that killed three people and injured 19 others was caused by the bus driver, Louis Taylor, 45 years old, who was high on cocaine, according to Dutchess County prosecutors.
Mr.
Taylor is charged with manslaughter in the deaths of the victims, who were mentally handicapped adults.

'He's Got a Missile Off,' Followed by 'Good Kill'
LEAD: A Navy cockpit tape of the confrontation between American and Libyan jet fighters offers only flashes of video images, but provides in sound the drama of American aviators unexpectedly caught up in combat.


'Misbehavin' ' to Close
LEAD: ''Ain't Misbehavin','' a revival of the 1978 musical celebrating the music of Fats Waller, will close after the Sunday matinee on Jan. 15, at the Ambassador Theater.
The show, which was directed by Richard Maltby Jr., will have had 8 previews and 176 regular performances.


The Mahres Return, This Time as Pros
LEAD: Professional ski racing lumbered along for about 20 years with only a few recognizable stars and little spectator interest.
This season, that changed after Phil and Steve Mahre, the American Olympic medalists, joined the pro circuit.


Strong December Sales Reported by Retailers
LEAD: The nation's largest retailers yesterday reported strong December sales, registering an average gain of 10 percent above the previous Christmas season.

She was 82 years old.

LEAD: An obituary yesterday about a professor of economics and former academic vice president at Suffolk County Community College in New York misidentified him.
The professor, who died on Wednesday, was John J. Saal, not Faal.

LEAD:  Debt


Our Towns; Don't Build Here: The Fine Points Of Foot-Dragging
LEAD: New Jersey's Mount Laurel housing plan is probably the most painless way to build low- and moderate-income housing in suburban America.
Developed after 12 years of court battles, the state plan sets a quota of subsidized units for each suburb.
But it doesn't cost the suburb a cent.
The builder pays for it.


Sammie Smith Exits
LEAD: Sammie Smith, the Florida State junior tailback whose 115 yards rushing made him the most valuable player in the 13-7 victory over Auburn in the Sugar Bowl, said yesterday that he would apply for the National Football League draft.
Smith, whose freshman class will graduate this spring, was the Seminoles' leading rusher the last two seasons.

LEAD: Several Federal agencies have joined in a broad investigation of stock manipulation, using evidence that came to light as a result of the market crash of October 1987, officials reported yesterday.

LEAD: Larry Bird's recovery from surgery on his heels last Nov. 19 is ahead of schedule and he will probably return to the lineup before March 1, the Boston Celtics' team physician, Dr.
Arnold Scheller, said yesterday. ''There's no buildup of scar tissue, but right now we've got to work on getting the strength back in his calf muscles,'' Scheller said.

At the Movies
LEAD: When you've got something old, something new, something borrowed and something blue, usually the topic is weddings.

SON OF 2 RECLUSES IS DISCOVERED DEAD
LEAD: A 14-year-old boy has died of starvation and his parents and sister are under treatment for malnutrition in a case some people here link to the family's belief that God would take care of all their needs.


ReviewFilm; Love, and Discord, Between Sisters in Liverpool
LEAD: Liverpool, 1944.
The world is upside down, what with noisy, brawling, well-fed Yanks everywhere, throwing cigarettes and nylons around and acting as if they owned the place.
The very proper Nellie (Joan Plowright) doesn't like it.
Her thin lips permanently pursed, Nellie watches as giggly girls parade the streets, being pawed by American servicemen.


Money Fund Assets Dip
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds decreased by $449.50 million, to $278.03 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 136 institutional funds increased by $588.4 million, to $72.41 billion.
The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were up by $249.1 million, to $89.94 billion.


Review/Piano; Kalichstein in Recital
LEAD: Twenty years have passed since Joseph Kalichstein's New York debut, at which the Israeli-born pianist made a strong impression as a technician of heroic aspirations and a musician of serious intent.
His subsequent capturing of the Leventritt Award further fueled that reputation and targeted him as one of his generation's most promising artists.


Conlan Planning To Rejoin Bills
LEAD: Shane Conlan, a Pro Bowl linebacker sidelined for the last six weeks with a foot injury, practiced with the Buffalo Bills today and said he would start in the American Football Conference title game against the Cincinnati Bengals on Sunday.

Europe Fires A New Shot In Trade War
LEAD: The European Community said today that American walnuts and dried prunes, peaches, apricots and papayas would be subject to punitive tariffs if its trade dispute with the United States was not settled soon.


Mr. Stein's Strange Arithmetic
LEAD: Andrew Stein, the New York City Council president, misleads the public about the true costs of his refusal to participate in the city's new public campaign financing system.
He claims it will hold down the cost of an unpopular reform.
In fact, it will trigger higher spending, while restoring the influence of wealthy donors.


Israeli Civilian Killed in the West Bank
LEAD: An Israeli man was found killed in the West Bank on Thursday night, and Jewish settlers tried to raid nearby Arab villages in revenge, Israel radio said.
But troops ejected the settlers and blocked roads into Arab areas.

LEAD: To the Editor:


TV Weekend; Harold Prince's 'Butterfly'
LEAD: Harold Prince has collected a record 16 Tony Awards for his stage productions over the years, most recently for ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' Somewhat less well known is his work in opera.
He staged, for instance, Carlisle Floyd's ''Willie Stark'' for the Houston Grand Opera.
And on tap are ''Don Giovanni'' for the New York City Opera and ''Faust'' for the Metropolitan Opera.


'1992' Architect To Advise Firm
LEAD: Lord Cockfield, who stepped down today as vice president of the European Community, will become a consultant and special adviser on European affairs to Peat Marwick McLintock &amp; Company, Britain's largest firm of accountants and management consultants.


Man Charged in Death Of a 14-Year-Old Boy
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was charged with homicide yesterday in the death of a 14-year-old student, Jeffrey Vilain, who was caught in the middle of a gun battle between a police officer and a suspected robber in the East Flatbush section.

LEAD: ''Society, relatives and those close to the victims await the full rehabilitation of all innocently repressed and the perpetuation of their memory.''  - Soviet party declaration on victims of Stalin's purges.  [ A6:2. ]


Oklahoma Assails N.C.A.A. Immunity for Dykes
LEAD: Hart Lee Dykes, the Oklahoma State wide receiver who could reportedly figure in probations handed to four college football programs by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, ''is making a mockery of the N.C.A.A. system'' by receiving immunity for his testimony, a University of Oklahoma official said today.


President to Be Chief At Pratt &amp; Lambert
LEAD: Pratt &amp; Lambert Inc., an old-line Buffalo-based coatings and adhesives company, said yesterday that its president, Joseph Castiglia, was taking on the added title of chief executive.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about Ira D. London, the lawyer for Joel B. Steinberg, misidentified a New York University law professor who commented on legal ethics.
He is Stephen Gillers, not Villers.


Steinberg May Face One Less Charge
LEAD: Prosecutors said yesterday that they were seriously considering dropping the first-degree manslaughter charge against Joel B. Steinberg on the ground that their case was primarily based on his ''depraved indifference'' to Lisa Steinberg's life and not on any intent to kill her.


Vito Titone, Lawyer, 91
LEAD: Vito Titone, a retired lawyer, died of heart failure Wednesday at his winter home in Hallandale, Fla.
He was 91 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I., for the last year.

Mr.
Tobin was counsel for the Newspaper Guild of New York.

Knicks' Run Against Nets Is Still Barely Believable
LEAD: It lasted 7 minutes 4 seconds.
It's hard to imagine unless you saw it.
And it was a microcosm of the reason the Knicks (20-10) are a first-place team and why the Nets (13-18) remain far from the top.


The Right Goal
LEAD: A Canute-like law commands the Federal budget deficit to stop at $100 billion in fiscal 1990.
So a new President and a new Congress are about to take office hell-bent on reducing the deficit for that year by $27 billion to $41 billion, depending on whose economic estimates are accepted.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush's attempt to complete his Cabinet remained stalled today with no clear choice for Energy Secretary, senior Bush aides said.

LEAD: In memory of the victims of the explosion of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland, Fred Halden of Teaneck, N.J., sent $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: The rusting, rotting remains of a portion of the West Side Highway are about to get the burial they have so long deserved.
Starting in March, a 14-block stretch of the viaduct, moribund for years, will be torn down and hauled away.

Grafton Journal; Library's Name Brings Talk of Anti-Semitism
LEAD: Wintertime in this quiet town frequently finds children gliding uneventfully on ice skates across the frozen Milwaukee River while their parents keep warm over coffee cups in local diners, often hashing over the latest high school basketball game.
Residents acknowledge that news that makes headlines here might seem mundane to those in the big cities - news of a new library, perhaps.

LEAD: The Washington establishment is preparing a last hurrah for George P. Shultz at the State Department Monday night.
Among those expected to join in honoring the Secretary of State at cocktails and dinner are Henry A. Kissinger, William P. Rogers and Edmund S. Muskie, all of whom held the top Cabinet office, along with members of Congress, the diplomatic corps and such familiar foreign policy establishment figures as David Rockefeller, Sol M.

Reviews/Dance; Exploring the Boundaries Of Frivolity and Ferocity
LEAD: The New York City Ballet presented a program that probed extremes of light and darkness on Wednesday at the New York State Theater.


New Director at Photography Museum
LEAD: The International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House in Rochester announced yesterday that James Enyeart will become its director on April 15.
He succeeds Robert A. Mayer, whose resignation was made public Wednesday.


Grumman Offering Notes With Buyout Protections
LEAD: The Grumman Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 3/8 percent notes due in 1999 at a price of par, or about 1.11 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read &amp; Company.


Clash Off Libya Arouses Concern in Europe
LEAD: The downing of two Libyan jet fighters has sharpened concerns among America's Western European allies that the Reagan Administration could be preparing for a military strike against a Libyan chemical plant.


Newest Arrivals for the New Year
LEAD: IF cities had official mottos, ''What's new?'' might well be the most fitting phrase for the five boroughs of New York.
Change is so permanent a feature of city life that one almost expects yesterday's parking lot to be tomorrow's skyscraper and the nondescript coffee shop one visited last month to become the fashionable restaurant or trendy discotheque that opens next week.


His Number Is Up
LEAD: Joseph Frank of Lafayette, Ind., made his mark in history today, which is his 26th birthday.
According to the Selective Service System, he was the first 18-year-old to register for the draft eight years ago after Congress passed a law requiring young men to sign up within a month of their 18th birthday.


Gansz Dismissed
LEAD: Frank Gansz, whose teams won only eight games in his two seasons as coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, was dismissed yesterday by Carl Peterson, general manager and chief operating officer.
Under Gansz, 50 years old, who had two years left on his contract, the Chiefs were 8-22-1. (AP)


Airlines Ordered to Install Devices to Avert Collisions
LEAD: All planes that carry more than 30 passengers must have collision-warning devices by the end of 1991, under a rule the Government issued yesterday.


Debt Crisis For Banks Said to End
LEAD: Three leading bank regulators told Congress today that third world debts no longer posed a threat to this country's banking system.


TV Weekend; U.S.-Soviet Relations
LEAD: ''The Eagle and the Bear,'' a 26-part weekly series on the cold war that begins at 8 tonight on the Arts &amp; Entertainment cable network, is chronologically jumpy.
The first episode starts, reasonably, with the end of World War II and of the United States-Soviet wartime alliance.
In the second episode, we are in Korea a couple of years later.

Lockheed Contract
LEAD: The Navy awarded the Lockheed Corporation a $52 million contract to build two prototypes of a new submarine-hunting patrol plane, indicating that the project cleared an internal Pentagon review.
In October, after a spirited competition, the Navy selected Lockheed to develop a modernized version of its P-3C Orion antisubmarine airplane.

LEAD: The Dallas Mavericks forward Roy Tarpley, who went to drug counselors for help Wednesday, was suspended indefinitely without pay yesterday in line with the National Basketball Association's anti-drug agreement.
The 24-year-old Tarpley returned to the active roster Dec. 13 after missing 14 games with torn cartilage in his left knee.

LEAD: Sometime in the next three months most taxpayers will be sorting through their 1988 financial records to get the information they or their tax preparers need to file returns.
A key to really getting finances under control is to do the job as soon as possible and as thoroughly as possible, by preparing an entire cash-flow statement that shows all expenditures as well as income and deductions.

A Leader Who Took Japan to War, to Surrender, and Finally to Peace
LEAD: Emperor Hirohito reigned over not one Japan, but three: a Japan consumed with militarism almost from the time he took over the Chrysanthemum Throne, a Japan that lay in ruins at the end of World War II and seemed destined for years of occupation and dependency, and finally a Japan that, from the shambles of defeat, achieved in peacetime global economic power.

LEAD: Several leading experts in breast cancer said yesterday that they believed new data linking oral contraceptives and breast cancer were so troubling that some women should be discouraged from taking birth control pills.


Ottoman Archive: Painful Look Into Turkish-Armenian Past
LEAD: After 74 years and countless recriminations, Turkey plans to reopen the archival records on one of the more grisly episodes of this century: the mass deaths of Armenians at the hands of the Ottoman Turks during World War I. For decades, Armenians have maintained that as many as 1.5 million of their countrymen were murdered or were allowed to die of starvation and exposure in a deliberate Turkish attempt at genocide begun in the spring of 1915.

Patents; 3 New Drugs Backed for AIDS Study
LEAD: Three new drugs that promoters say could help in the fight against AIDS were granted patents this week.

Harvest Drops in China
LEAD: China reported today that its 1988 grain harvest fell for the fourth straight year, calling into question the ability of the nation to feed its billion people.
The official China Daily attributed the shortfall to one of the worst droughts in China's history and to ''lack of motivation'' by peasants to plant more grain.

LEAD: The beginning of the new year is a perfect time to establish or review personal investment portfolios.

Suit to Block Housing Is Dismissed by Judge
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice today dismissed a lawsuit by opponents of a proposed housing project for the homeless in the town of Greenburgh.


Starving Family Refused to Buy Food, Police Say
LEAD: A starving family had more than $3,600 in cash and in bank accounts but refused to spend it for food because they believed the money ''belonged to God,'' according to a police affidavit made public today.


Hearing for Scurry
LEAD: Rod Scurry faces a preliminary hearing April 4 on charges of possession and use of cocaine.
The court date was set for the free-agent pitcher during a brief appearance Thursday in Reno Justice Court.
He remains free on $6,000 bail.
The 32-year-old left-hander was arrested Dec. 22 and charged with buying $40 worth of crack from a police informant.


Time for Reckoning Arrives for Hembrick
LEAD: The Olympic T-shirt he wears is a souvenir, but it is also a sad reminder of what should have been the highlight of Anthony Hembrick's amateur boxing career.


It's Bad Enough Without Bashing Calcutta
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bengals Accused of Pulling a Fast One  No-Huddle, Hurry-Up Offense Angers Opponents
LEAD: It is fiendish, the better mousetrap. It might be unethical if not illegal.


Tokyo Takes News Solemnly, but in Stride
LEAD: With customary attention to decorum and detail, and with flashes of spontaneity, Tokyo awoke this morning to witness the first ascension of an Emperor since 1926, and to mourn the only monarch most Japanese have ever known.


Liability Cap in Crash May Not Apply to All
LEAD: To the Editor:


Andersen's Chief Will Step Down
LEAD: In an unexpected move, Arthur Andersen &amp; Company said today that Duane R. Kullberg would relinquish the title of term was scheduled to expire.

LEAD: The Knicks' rookie guard, Rod Strickland, who can dazzle, flung up a cuckoo shot in traffic that flew over the hoop.
This was on Tuesday night against the Celtics at Madison Square Garden.


Bonn Seems To Reverse Dollar View
LEAD: The dollar surged again yesterday, powered by an apparent change of stance by the West German central bank that left some currency traders wondering what was going on.

George M. L. La Branche, Stock Trader, 89
LEAD: George M. L. La Branche, founder of La Branche &amp; Company, a Manhattan stock trading concern, died of pneumonia Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.


'88 Jobless Rates in New York And Jersey Drop to '69 Level
LEAD: Unemployment rates rose slightly in New York State and New Jersey last month, but the annual rates for the two states dropped to levels not matched in 19 years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.


A Bigger Sea Around Us
LEAD: With a Christmas week stroke of a pen, President Reagan bestowed on the United States a breathtaking gift: 185,000 square miles of new territory.
That's the biggest acquisition since the purchase in 1867 of Alaska's 586,000 square miles.
The President extended the country's territorial waters from 3 to 12 miles, pursuant to a United Nations convention that has been denounced by his own Administration as a leftist plot.


Injury to Maggie Smith Leads to 'Lettice' Delay
LEAD: Maggie Smith broke a shoulder while riding a bicycle on vacation in November and the accident has forced the postponement until next season of ''Lettice and Lovage,'' the Peter Shaffer play in which she was scheduled to star on Broadway this spring.


Japan's Emperor: A Mortal Man
LEAD: When the American military high command in Tokyo in 1945 suggested that Emperor Hirohito renounce his divinity, the Emperor was bemused. ''I have never considered myself a god,'' he said, ''nor have I attempted to arrogate to myself the powers of a divine being.''

LEAD: Piero Bonaguri, a guitarist from Italy who made his New York debut on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, is a talented interpreter, if not the most adventurous programmer.
Most of the music he offered was from the tried-and-true core of his instrument's literature, including guitar works by Sor, Torroba and Villa-Lobos, and transcriptions of pieces by Frescobaldi and

Zielinski.

Hirohito, 124th Emperor of Japan, Is Dead at 87
LEAD: Emperor Hirohito, the last of the World War II leaders and Japan's longest-reigning monarch, died today at the Imperial Palace.
He was 87 years old.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about budget problems facing New York, New Jersey and Connecticut characterized Connecticut's response incorrectly.


Less Mystery in Car Rentals
LEAD: Drivers should find it easier to shop for the lowest rental-car rates this year, and many customers will be able to disregard the industry's puzzling and expensive insurance options, thanks to some new laws, guidelines and credit-card services.


Four Dead, Five Injured in Connecticut Fire


Inscrutable Occidental Mentality
LEAD: For days warlike sounds have issued from Washington about the need for a ''surgical strike'' to ''take out'' that troublesome chemical plant in Libya.
This fast-food and medical jargon harks back to Vietnam days when it was used to describe what our air forces were up to, which was bombing with a ferocity somewhat less destructive than nuclear assault.


Bruce Failing Sr., 70, Advertising Executive
LEAD: Bruce F. Failing Sr., an advertising executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at the Albany Medical Center.
He was 70 years old and lived in Westhampton Beach, L.I.


New York School Board Faulted For the Disarray of Local Districts
LEAD: The New York City Board of Education has failed to prevent the local decentralized school districts from mismanaging their budgets, ignoring ethical standards and often placing politics ahead of educational concerns, education officials, union leaders and representatives of community watchdog groups say.


Marcos Out of Hospital
LEAD: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has been released from a hospital and is resting at home after spending a week in the hospital for treatment of congestive heart failure, an aide said.


For Harper &amp; Row, the Deal Insures Closer Cooperation
LEAD: Now that Rupert Murdoch has won control of William Collins, Harper &amp; Row will be able to integrate more closely its publishing and distribution in Britain and Canada, where the two companies have often gone their separate ways.


FIRST INDICTMENT RETURNED BY JURY IN PENTAGON FRAUD
LEAD: A Federal grand jury returned its first indictment today against a military contractor, a Pentagon official and five other people in the two-year investigation of fraud and bribery in military weapons procurement.
Another contractor and two of its former executives pleaded guilty in a Federal court to similar charges growing out of the investigation.


Soviets Dispute U.S. Assertion On Libya Plant
LEAD: The Soviet Union implied today that the United States had no proof for its assertion that Libya had built a chemical weapons plant.


Ex-Chiefs of Haas Penalized In Stock-Manipulation Case
LEAD: More details of the Government's investigation of stock market manipulation were disclosed yesterday, as charges of regulatory violations were brought by the National Association of Securities Dealers.


U.S. SPURNS SAUDIS ON LIBYA MEDIATION
LEAD: Less than two weeks before two Navy fighter planes shot down two Libyan jets over the Mediterranean, the Reagan Administration rejected an offer by Saudi Arabia to mediate between the United States and Libya, State Department officials and Arab diplomats said today.


Life Magazine Photos
LEAD: ''Life: Through the 60's,'' an exhibition of 200 photographs from the archives of Life magazine is to be on view at the International Center for Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, from March 17 to May 14.
The photographs run from the late 1950's to the early 70's, and the subjects include the civil-rights movement, the Vietnam War, the Peace Corps and the Kennedy Administration.


Donald P. Wright, Lawyer, 48
LEAD: Donald P. Wright, a vice president and general counsel at the Harris Corporation, the electronics and communciations company, died of a heart attack Thursday at Holmes Regional Hospital in Melbourne, Fla.
He was 48 years old and lived in Indialantic, Fla.


Toyota Will Build Trucks In California if G.M. Agrees
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is close to concluding an agreement that would allow the Toyota Motor Corporation to build 100,000 trucks a year in Fremont, Calif., G.M.'s chief executive, Roger B. Smith, said today.


Capital's Mayor Balks at Drug Inquiries
LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., under Federal investigation for a December visit to a man suspected of being a drug dealer, declined today to make public the results of 10 drug tests that he has said he took over the past five years.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Despite the concerted efforts of medical treatment, finally today His Majesty passed away from a tumor in the duodenum.'' - Shoichi Fujimori, grand steward of the Imperial Household Agency.  [ 1:1. ]

Polaroid Stock Plan Upheld; Setback for Shamrock Seen
LEAD: The Delaware Chancery Court today determined that the Polaroid Corporation's employee stock ownership plan was valid, a ruling that appears to be a setback to Roy E. Disney's takeover bid for the film and camera company.

Bridge
LEAD: If the players competing in the Winter Regional Swiss Team Championship in Manhattan three weeks ago had been asked by Santa Claus what they wanted for Christmas, a likely answer would have been a doubled part-score, making game, with the help of some mis-defense.


A Witness Says Nussbaum Hit And Flung Lisa
LEAD: A defense witness in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg testified yesterday that she saw Hedda Nussbaum fling Lisa Steinberg aside in a fit of rage and then slap her on the side of her neck in 1983 when the child was less than 2 years old.

LEAD: ''Romance Romance,'' a four-character musical by Keith Herrmann, with book and lyrics by Barry Harman, will close after tomorrow's performance at the Helen Hayes Theater.
The musical will have played 289 regular performances and 10 previews.

Manning Injures Knee Ligament
LEAD: Danny Manning of the Los Angeles Clippers, the No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft last summer, has knee ligament damage and will not be with the Clippers when they play the Knicks tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.
The severity of the injury will be determined next week.


McMahon Named Starter
LEAD: Jim McMahon, who publicly lobbied to start the National Conference championship game, was given the job today by Coach Mike Ditka.

Contractor Disciplines 17
LEAD: The Sundstrand Corporation, the military contractor that agreed to pay a record $115 million fine last October for defrauding the Government, has taken disciplinary action against 17 employees as a result of the case.


President Enters a Hospital For Surgery on Hand Today
LEAD: President Reagan was admitted this evening to the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, where he will undergo minor surgery on his left hand Saturday for a condition that has caused a curvature of his ring finger.


Missouri Puts Killer to Death In Tavern Waitress's Slaying
LEAD: A convicted killer was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a tavern waitress, becoming the first Missouri inmate to be executed since 1965.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Alfred Julien, Lawyer, Dies at 78
LEAD: Alfred S. Julien, a New York trial lawyer who was founder and senior partner in the law firm of Julien &amp; Schlesinger, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y.
He was 78 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and in Westhampton Beach, L.I.


New Boston Arena
LEAD: An agreement for the owners of the 60-year-old Boston Garden to build a new arena, which could be ready by the fall of 1992, was announced yesterday by Mayor Raymond Flynn.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Beverly Enterprises Inc., Pasadena, Calif., agreed to sell 20 nursing homes in Massachusetts to GHM Inc., East Hartford, Conn., for $47.25 million.


Thomas Holmes, Psychiatrist, 70
LEAD: Dr.
Thomas Holmes, a psychiatrist who helped create a stress scale of such events as marriage and work troubles, died Dec. 24 of a stroke.
He was 70 years old.


Mark Producing Sells Its Assets
LEAD: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it and a Japanese partner had agreed to acquire the exploration and production assets of Mark Producing Inc. for about $245 million in cash.
Mark Producing, a Houston-based company, has extensive natural gas and oil properties in the Gulf of Mexico.
The deal includes proven and probable reserves of 190 billion cubic feet of natural gas and five million barrels of oil.


Difficult Issues Emerge On Canada-U.S. Trade
LEAD: When Gary Timmerman returned from a shopping trip to Chicago he became an example of the misconceptions and disappointments that have sprung up since the free trade agreement between the United Sates and Canada took effect last weekend.


U.N. HEARS DEFENSE IN DOWNING OF JETS
LEAD: The United States presented photographs of what it said were armed Libyan fighter planes to the Security Council today in support of its contention that American pilots acted in self defense in shooting down the Libyan planes.


An Opera Based on O'Neill
LEAD: An opera based on the Eugene O'Neill play ''Desire Under the Elms'' is to have its premiere on Wednesday at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, to benefit the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.
The work, composed by Edward Thomas with a libretto by Joe Masteroff, will be performed by the New York Opera Repertory Theater, with Judy Kaye starring.


Cracks Mar the Facade of Bhutto's Pakistan
LEAD: To the Editor:


Murdoch Wins Control of Collins
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch's News International P.L.C. won control today of William Collins P.L.C., ending a two-month struggle by the major British book publisher to resist a takeover by Mr.
Murdoch.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 7, 1989
LEAD:  Economy


Bonn Asks U.S. for Evidence of Libya Connection
LEAD: The West German Government renewed its demands today that the United States supply evidence to support assertions that a German chemical company was involved in the contruction of a chemical plant in Libya.
Bonn complained that it was being victimized by a ''media campaign'' in the United States.


Honeywell Bull to Cut Work Force by 15%
LEAD: Honeywell Bull Inc. said today that it would reduce its American work force by 15 percent, or 1,600 employees, in the next two months to make itself more competitive.


Bush Calls Walsh's Motion 'the Proper Suggestion'
LEAD: President-elect George Bush said today that he thought the independent Iran-contra prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, ''did the right thing'' Thursday in moving to dismiss the two main charges against Oliver L. North.
But the Senate Democratic leader called for more information on the move.


30% MORE FOR AIDS IN REAGAN BUDGET
LEAD: The Reagan Administration will send to Congress on Monday a $424.4 billion budget for health and human services that will include a 30 percent increase in spending on AIDS but restrain the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Attendants Forced Cancellation of Flight
LEAD: Flight attendants at Newark International Airport forced United Air Lines to cancel a Los Angeles-bound flight on Tuesday night when they learned of a sabotage threat shortly before the 198 passengers boarded.


Winfield Group Suing Steinbrenner Again
LEAD: The stormy relationship between Dave Winfield and George Steinbrenner yesterday produced a new round of thunder and lightning over an old matter: the owner's failure to make payments to the David M. Winfield Foundation.


But Does Ice Cream Go With Romance?
LEAD: How does an ice cream manufacturer draw attention to new flavors in the dead of winter?
Well, Haagen-Dazs's strategy this week was to release results of a poll that explored attitudes toward romance at the same time it announced its new flavors: deep chocolate, deep chocolate fudge and deep chocolate peanut butter.


Review/Dance; City Ballet's Answer to 'Unanswered Question'
LEAD: ''The Unanswered Question,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Thursday at the New York State Theater, has been a prickly addition to the company's repertory.
The piece, created by Eliot Feld for City Ballet's American Music Festival last spring, demands dramatic presence rather than virtuoso dancing from its performers.


Home Banking By Computer Hasn't Made Paper Obsolete
LEAD: Despite the continuing optimism of some bankers, banking at home with a personal computer has not come anywhere near its potential.


Who Knew What Will Remain Unknown
LEAD: PERHAPS more than a whimper, but there certainly wasn't much of a bang when the main thrust of the Government's case against Oliver L. North collapsed last week.


Big Stanley Wins Tropical
LEAD: Big Stanley, the quickest 2-year-old sprinter in Florida last year, carried his speed a mile and an eighth today to win the $166,950 Tropical Park Derby by 1 3/4 lengths at Calder Race Course.


Musings On Moses
LEAD: To the Editor:


Employers Assay Ban on Polygraphs
LEAD: AS Westchester retailers tabulate the profits from a successful holiday season, they fear they are losing ground against a common enemy, the thieving employee.
On Dec. 27 polygraph testing, one of the means retailers in the state have used to determine the honesty of employees, was banned under the Employee Polygraph Protection


Where the Trout Reside, and Why Where the Trout Are Hiding, and Why
LEAD: If you begin to peruse Tom Rosenbauer's ''Reading Trout Streams'' (Nick Lyons Books, $17.95) this winter, you'll spend less time flailing dead water when the fifth month's soft breezes are upon us.


Art Brut
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''In Europe, Tracing the Art of the Outsider'' (Travel, Nov. 20): Those who would like to learn more should read ''Art Brut'' by Michel Thevoz, the curator of the Art Brut Museum in Lausanne.


Turtle Bay Tour
LEAD: Adventure on a Shoestring is to conduct a walking tour of the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan at 3 P.M. today.
The fee is $5; for meeting place, call 265-2663.


Klaus Column: Help in the Kitchen
LEAD: My usual reaction to one of Barbara Klaus's articles is, ''Thank the household gods!
I am not alone,'' and her piece on holiday cooking  [ ''What It All Boils Down To,'' Long Island Sound, Dec. 4 ]  evoked that consoling shock of recognition.
I wonder if she is familiar with a further complication.


POSTINGS: Just Off Central Park; Rocky Road for Townhouses
LEAD: If everything went right for Townhouses on the Park, one-half block from Central Park West, all 77 of its two- and three-bedroom apartments with balconies and gardens would have sold for only $63,000 and $73,000.
But just about everything went wrong for the community development corporation that started building the project eight years ago with Federal and city aid.


Garment Unions Sue To Ban Work in Home
LEAD: Unions and clothing industry groups have filed a suit to block new Government regulations that would allow work at home in five industries, ending a 40-year ban.


The Black Ascent In Union Politics
LEAD: IN the early 1960's, the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. provoked an angry outcry from some labor leaders when it urged them to open their ranks to black workers.
It was not until 1964, some 15 years after the armed forces began to integrate and a decade after the Supreme Court ordered desegregation of public schools, that the last labor federation affiliate removed the ''whites only'' clause in its constitution and bylaws.


Reviews/Music; Newcomers in Met Opera's 'Figaro'
LEAD: Casts seem to be shifting more rapidly in the later years of the James Levine regime at the Metropolitan Opera than they did earlier on, and the four newcomers to Wednesday's cast of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' served to underscore that instability.


Howard Beach Victim Convicted in a Shooting
LEAD: Timothy Grimes, one of the victims of the Howard Beach racial violence, has been convicted of malicious wounding for shooting his brother in the face.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  IT ONLY HURTS WHEN I LAUGH.
By Stan Freberg. (Times Books, $19.95.) America's self-styled ''gray-flanneled kamikaze pilot,'' Stan Freberg wields the stiletto of satire against the smug and self-satisfied in popular culture and advertising.
Mr.
Freberg was the mad prophet of the airwaves, performing on radio, television and records his hilarious sendups of everything from ''Dragnet'' to the overcommercialization of Christmas.


COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Warehouses; In a Tenant's Market, Bigger Is Considered Better
LEAD: ALTHOUGH warehouse space tends to be tediously stable as a real estate investment in the metropolitan New York area, good fortune in 1988 was skewed sharply in favor of developers specializing in huge suburban warehouse complexes.


Multiple Listing Coming to Manhattan
LEAD: AN upheaval, bitter and factional, is reshaping the way apartments are bought and sold in Manhattan, forcing brokers to abandon traditional strategies in a marketplace lurching toward the future.


Valarie King Is Engaged
LEAD: Valarie King and Douglas P. Thoren, a son of Carol McKenna of Hoboken, N.J., and Donald P. Thoren of Mount Kemble Lake, N.J., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Harold King of Ridgefield, N.J., have announced.
Ms.
King, a graduate of Douglass College at Rutgers University, is studying for a Ph.D.


A Town of Crystal And Old Artistry Near Florence
LEAD: EVERYONE has heard of Venetian glass, but not even most Florentines, a mere 30 miles away, are aware of the crystal from Colle di Val d'Elsa, although 90 percent of Italy's crystal is made in this little hilltop town.
More famous in Dante's time than it is today, the scene of a decisive battle between Ghibellines and Guelphs, the poetic-sounding Colle di Val d'Elsa (literally the Hill in the Valley of the River Elsa), off the busy superstrada on the way to Siena, is also the birthplace of Arnolfo di Cambio, the greatest architect of his time, who designed Florence's


STREETSCAPES: Woodycrest Children's Home; A New Life - and Mission - for a Bronx Residence
LEAD: IT IS a wreck, still elegant in parts, but definitely a wreck.
Now the vacant, vandalized Woodycrest, a home for neglected children built in the Bronx in 1902 by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, seems on the road to repair, if not restoration.


TRAVEL ADVISORY
LEAD:  New York Bans Waivers on Auto Rentals


Jody Ann Hocart Engaged To Marry Gregory James
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
William T. Hocart of Essex Fells, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jody Ann Hocart to Gregory Michael James, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
John James of Glen Rock, N.J., and Fairfield, Conn.
A spring wedding is planned.


RIVER BLINDNESS: CONQUERING AN ANCIENT SCOURGE
LEAD: ON THIS BRIGHT NOVEMBER morning the mood is anything but gloomy in Sikoroni, Mali, a mud-hut village of the vast West African savanna.
The summer rains were generous for the first time in years, and today 10-foot sorghum stalks are bowed by heavy heads of grain.
True to protocol, the chief of this village of 400 has called in the elders to exchange ceremonial words with arriving visitors.


Richard Goldwater, 70, Ex-Assemblyman
LEAD: Richard M. Goldwater, a Manhattan lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died of complications of pneumonia Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Hirohito's Death Puts Focus on New Identity
LEAD: The death of Emperor Hirohito may crystallize a national pride, self-confidence and search for Japanese values under way long before he took ill.


How Israel's Economic Revival Ran Out of Steam
LEAD: AT the turn of the century, the creed of the founders of modern Israel was Labor Zionism.
Steeped in European socialism and a belief in hard outdoor work, and determined to escape pogroms and shtetls, they sought not only a new country, but a new Jewish people.

Classroom to Dias: Teacher of the Year

School of Hospitality Management have little time to flambe anything with cherry sauce; they are too busy with classes in hospitality information systems, hospitality law and physical-plant management.

MORE DEMAND FOR THOSE WHO MAKE WATER FLOW
LEAD: In 1985 and 1986, record high water in the Great Lakes washed away and flooded streets.
In 1988, a dry, hot summer was followed by a quick return to substantially lower levels that left harbors too shallow for ships to navigate.
The extreme fluctuations in water levels have created a nearly continuous debate among engineers and planners over the success - or lack of it - of current methods to regulate the water's rise and fall.

How an Era Empowered Students
LEAD: WHERE ONCE decisions about college life were made by administrators and faculty, the 60's changed all that.
Today student representatives sit on panels and committees alongside faculty and officials.

Now their counsel is institutionalized, in an effort to avoid potential conflicts.

The Trade War Keeps Simmering
LEAD: The new-year trade war between the United States and Europe got off to a halting start.
The European Community, led by Jacques Delors of France, did impose its Jan. 1 ban on meat from animals treated with growth hormones.
Washington, which says the ban is trade protectionism and not a health measure, did apply its 100 percent retaliatory tariff on $100 million worth of European food imports.

Part of the Family
LEAD: BUNDLE up and prune; lack of leaves reveals tree/shrub scaffolding, which makes it easier to do some judicious cutting; this is also a good time to prune overgrown conifers and hollies.
Cut off the Christmas tree branches and place them over perennials to protect early growth in spring.
Do not overfeed or overwater house plants now because most of them are in a resting or dormant period.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  FABLES FOR THE NUCLEAR AGE.
By Alan Neidle.
Illustrations by Jeff Leedy. (Paragon House, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) Behemoths, butterflies and other creatures populate ''Fables for the Nuclear Age,'' canny political parables that take up where Aesop and Orwell left off.
As animals scheme to shift the balance of power, they imitate Homo sapiens' diplomatic strategies more apt to escalate problems than to solve them.

POSTINGS: Confidence in Greenwich; Mansions on Spec
LEAD: In a soft market, smart money builds lavishly.
That seems to be the lesson to be learned in Connecticut.
While most of Fairfield County is enduring a residential sales slump, Greenwich is enjoying something of boomlet in mansion-building.
Signaling the confidence builders have in the high end of the housing market, four large homes rising near one another there are all being built on a speculative basis.

Reagan in 'Good Spirits' After Hand Surgery
LEAD: President Reagan was termed in ''good spirits'' after minor surgery today to correct a condition that had caused a curvature of the ring finger on his left hand.

Reagan remained awake throughout the operation and chatted about horses with his doctors.


CORRECTION
LEAD: The video column on Dec. 25 incorrectly described the kind of machine on which tapes recorded in Super-VHS can be played.
Such tapes cannot be played on standard VHS machines.
However, tapes recorded in standard VHS can be played on Super-VHS machines.


A Rebuttal To Cablevision
LEAD: Cablevision has been running recent TV commercials portraying ''the man on the street'' in an interview situation.
A woman claims she is not a sports fan, so why should she be expected to pay an increased rate if MSG (the Madison Square Garden network) was incorporated into the basic service?
Furthermore, why should someone who is not a Ranger or Knick fan have to pay for someone else's pleasure?


Director's Post Empty Again at Hudson River Museum
LEAD: AFTER serving a year and a half, Thomas S. Holman has resigned his post as director of the Hudson River Museum, museum officials and Mr.
Holman confirmed last week.
The 35-five-year old Mr.
Holman, the fifth director in this decade, signed a letter of resignation on Monday.


Argentina
LEAD: To the Editor: The Argentina Tourist Information Office listed in your article on Argentina (Travel, Oct. 2) is a travel agency, not a government office.
The official Argentina Tourist Office in the United States is the Argentina National Tourist Office, 12 West 56th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-603-0443.

Nothing to Laugh About
LEAD: To the Editor:


Naturalissimo
LEAD: ''I'VE ALWAYS BEEN INFLUENCED by landscape,'' says Kenneth Frazelle, a 33-year-old composer who lives in Winston-Salem, N.C.
And though such a sentiment borders on a romantic cliche, it would appear that for Frazelle, the hills are alive with the sound of music.
His impromptu, crayon-and-pencil representations of the musical ideas he derives from the outdoors initiate his compositions.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Three years ago, we put siding on our house and had it stained, rather than painted.
A couple of months ago, I noticed some gray spots on this siding, and they have now spread all over the outside.
It seems to be some kind of mold, and scrubbing with Clorox got rid of it.
This is harsh and seems difficult to do over the entire house.

LUCIAN FREUD: THE UNBLINKING EYE
LEAD: Marina Warner's article ''Lucian Freud: The Unblinking Eye'' (Dec. 4), full of compelling facts and rumors about Lucian Freud's personal life, is surely interesting, but what is important is to see and experience the intensity, depth and mastery of his work; there is no other painter like him.
Only a self-portrait by Rembrandt or Van Gogh comes close to the profundity and honesty of Freud's ''Reflection.


The Battle to Save the Banks
LEAD: The silent run was accelerating at the First RepublicBank Corporation's offices in Texas - silent because retail customers were not lining up on the streets.
This run was being fueled by large institutions, including other banks, racing to electronically withdraw uninsured deposits.
Alarm bells went off around Washington, as the nation's top bank regulators met in an emergency session.

State's Public Works Show: More than Just Buildings
LEAD: PEDESTRIANS strolling through the West Rock Tunnel of the Merritt Parkway in New Haven on the day of its dedication, the stones of Bulkeley Bridge in Hartford being set by hand, and even a worker loitering by a portable latrine as construction of the Hartford Armory went on all around him - such sights as these tracing the history of Connecticut's public buildings, highways and bridges are displayed in a new exhibit at the Connecticut Museum of History.

The Everlasting Autodidact
LEAD: MY HIGH SCHOOL classmates completed four years of college last June, a date at which I too had completed four years of study.
Their graduation was greeted by presents, parties and diplomas.
Mine never occurred.
What studies and studies and never graduates?
The answer can be found in one word: autodidact.


Bowing to Pressure
LEAD: After 20 years as head of the Italian track and field federation, Primo Nebiolo has decided to step down in the wake of a series of scandals.
The 64-year-old industrialist, who also serves as president of the international track and field federation, has been criticized because of the scandals, which included the fixing of the men's long jump results at the 1987 world championships in Rome.

IN PARIS - MINISkIRTS OF THE MIND
LEAD: Around the display tables of university bookstores, ''the latest fashion from Paris'' does not refer to the length of skirts.
It refers to a series of startling ideas and images out of the French mind.
In paraphrase: That truth is castrating and humanism oppressive.
That the ego is infinitely dissolvable.


At a Breast Exam, Perfection Is Where You Find It
LEAD: I HAVE reached middle age, my children are grown and gone, I am a grandmother and I have perfect breasts.
I'm not the one who thinks so.
Today someone who saw me topless described them that way, someone who sees women's breasts every day - the mammography technician.


Music Teacher's View of Holiday Music
LEAD: As a public-school music educator for the last 23 years, I have had to deal with the issue of holiday music in a variety of school settings.
The article ''Schools Strive for Seasonal Balance''  [ Dec. 18 ]  was interesting but failed to point out one obvious solution to the dilemma.
Simply make the issue a non-issue by remembering that the primary function of the music teacher is to teach music and to provide positive musical experiences to all students.

LEAD: Roy Marble's free throw with 11 seconds to play capped a 23-point performance, and Iowa beat North Carolina, 98-97, today.

LEAD: When auto racing finally discovered what other sports leagues already knew - that fans have an insatiable appetite for statistics - all sorts of performance barometers were created, from total laps led to fastest pit stops.
But one statistic from each race is usually known only to the promoter and the Internal Revenue Service: total attendance.

A TAKEOVER PLAY IN MUTUAL FUNDS
LEAD: TAKEOVER specialists searching for companies with undervalued assets are increasingly noticing a type of publicly owned companynot typically thought of as takeover play: closed-end stock funds.
Indeed, as corporate acquisitions remove more equity from the stock market, investment professionals believe that acquirers will become increasingly interested in closed-end funds, especially those whose shares sell at sharp discounts to their net asset value.

LEAD:  I can ride the wildest bronco in the wild and woolly West,
I can rake him, I can break him, let him do his level best.
I can handle any cattle ever wore a coat of hair,
And I've had a lively tussle with a tarnal grizzly bear.
I can rope and throw a longhorn of the wildest Texas brand,
And at Injun disagreements I can take a leading hand.

The Whitney Paradox: To Add Is To Subtract
LEAD: The temptation is to tell the story like a morality play.
Marcel Breuer's gray-granite Whitney Museum of Art, for two decades a Modernist fixture on Madison Avenue, is challenged by the upstarts of post-Modernism in the form of a design for a massive addition by Michael Graves.
The addition would not so much expand the Breuer building as overwhelm it by merging it into a post-Modern collage.

Those taxes may turn out to be particularly steep if, in addition to a principal residence, there is a vacation home or investment property, such as a condominium, which may have skyrocketed in value, too.

LEAD: A SATURDAY morning in San Angel begins, as do most days here, with the clanging of one of the bells in the tower of the Church of San Jacinto.
The church was constructed in the late 16th century by Franciscan monks and although much of it has been rebuilt, the bells have a heavy, tired sound - as though they have been ringing for too many years.

LEAD: The voice recorder from a South African airliner that crashed into the Indian Ocean 14 months ago was recovered Friday and appears to be in good condition, Cecil Margo, a senior South African investigator, said.
All 160 people aboard were killed when the South African Airways Boeing 747 crashed as it approached Mauritius on a flight from Taipei to Johannesburg in November 1987.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Dec. 25 about abortions performed solely because of the sex of the fetus attributed remarks by Dr.
Michael A. Roth to Dr.
Lawrence D. Platt.
Dr.
Platt does not perform abortions.
It was Dr.
Roth who said that doctors who decline to perform abortions for sex selection but perform abortions for other reasons ''are selectively picking out who they want to do them on and who not,'' and added, ''I haven't turned anybody down.

LEAD: A system to match fingerprints in a few hours is to be introduced this year, New Jersey officials said this week.
The $12.2 million Automated Fingerprint Identification System can compare prints from a crime scene with the 1.9 million in the state's file at the rate of 9,000 a minute, officials said.

By Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Being Sidney Sheldon means never having to say you're writing.

Sheldon appears to have produced a literary version of painting by numbers.
The story follows the fortunes of four nuns from an intensely austere Spanish convent as they wander through scenery that seems to have been imported from ''For Whom the Bell Tolls'' - in the company of some fugitive Basque nationalists.

The Financial-Aid Numbers Game
LEAD: SWEATY PALMS.
Rapid pulse.
Muscle spasms.
All symptoms of families anticipating those tuition and expense bills that will start arriving the moment their child starts his college career.

New York's Campaign Finance Law: Limits and Loopholes
LEAD: The first public financing of political campaigns in New York State went into effect in New York City last week.

Harking to The Muse Of Music

Feeding Bagels To Barracudas In Caneel Bay
LEAD: THERE'S something unnerving about having a four-foot stingray nuzzle against you while you're floating flat on your face, or offering a five-foot barracuda a bite of a bagel.
You learn later that a barracuda doesn't particularly like bagels, though it might be tempted by lox.
A stringray likes both, and will pester you for a handout.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  IMELDA: Steel Butterfly of the Philippines.
By Katherine Ellison. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Katherine Ellison is part of the Pulitzer Prize-winning San Jose Mercury News team that in 1985 traced the money of Ferdinand E. Marcos, then President of the Philippines, around the globe.
In ''Imelda,'' she is on the track of bigger game - the soul of the country as well as of her subject, Imelda Marcos, the President's wife, his political equal and - but for the explosion of long-simmering revulsion with their staggering corruption - his potential successor.

Fenner Turning Pro
LEAD: He's certainly had his share of problems since leading the Atlantic Coast Conference in rushing with 1,250 yards as a freshman in 1986, but now Derrick Fenner says he's going to turn pro.
After losing his scholarship to Gardner-Webb College because of academic deficiencies, Fenner, a transfer student who has not played in two years, said he had decided to waive his last years of collegiate eligibility and apply for the April draft.


When Buyers Shop for Reliability
LEAD: When a personal computer fails at a large company, the worker usually places a frantic call to the technical support office.
The technician comes to the desk and either fixes the problem or swaps the machine for a backup.
The failure is annoying but rarely catastrophic.
In most businesses, however, there is no in-house technical support, no backup machine or spare-parts inventory.


FLOURISHES
LEAD: Do not underestimate the power of a beauty statement.
When a number of women suddenly lop off their long hair, it may be more than just a collective whim.
Short hair tends to be popular when women are battling societal restrictions.
Right now, the feminine flourishes in fashion may be giving way to a more subdued, simplified look.

LEAD: President Reagan returned to the White House today, a day after undergoing surgery on his left hand.
Mr.
Reagan waved his bandaged hand upon leaving the Walter Reed Army Medical Center here, where the operation, to correct a curvature in the ring finger of his left hand, was performed.
He was not wearing a sling, although reports before the operation said he would have to wear one.

Prepare for a Wintry Day in the Woods
LEAD: SPORTS like skiing, hiking, snowshoeing, climbing and snowmobiling can turn cold and snow into a bounty of winter fun.
But you have to know when to be cautious.
Park trails and mountainsides are a lure for day trips and weekend excursions.
The risks are small if you go well prepared.
If you dress properly, take along the right food and recognize the signs of hypothermia and frostbite, you have little to fear and much to gain.

Topics of The Times; Beauty on a Bike
LEAD: The Palisades Interstate Park Commission governs one of the region's loveliest roads.
It runs along the base of the Palisades from just north of the George Washington Bridge to Alpine, N.J., offering intimate Hudson River views and access to marinas and picnic grounds.
The road, however, is barely two lanes wide and full of curves, and despite repeated requests from bicycling groups, the commission considers it unsafe for simultaneous use by autos and bikes.

She was 85 and lived in Englewood.

LEAD: Corning Glass Works announced yesterday that it would take a one-time after-tax charge of about $84 million to its 1988 earnings for its estimated liability on future medical benefits for its current retirees.

LEAD: Rabbi Herbert A. Seltzer, a retired administrator of a geriatrics center, died Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla.

Unisys Plans Job Cuts
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation said Friday that it would cut 450 jobs from its Computer Systems division in St.
Paul and Eagan, Minn., through layoffs and attrition.
The information services company, which is based in Blue Bell, Pa., said about half of the jobs affected are salaried.
Unisys employs 10,800 people in Minnesota.


Feasts on Cotton Plant May Be Over for Pest
LEAD: TO a caterpillar, a growing cotton plant is a natural invitation to dine and farmers pay the multimillion-dollar check.
But now, genetic engineers have developed a cotton plant that is naturally poisonous to the pests.


Guidry's Agent Tells Mets He's Interested
LEAD: Ron Guidry made a bid yesterday to remain in New York.
His agent, Reggie Ringuet, called the Mets to find out if they had any interest in him as a relief pitcher.
Guidry spoke with Pat Gillick, general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, who apparently do have some interest in him as a reliever. ''Basically, I couldn't give him an answer at this point,'' said Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' vice president for baseball operations.

Setback for Fed Jurisdiction
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board suffered a setback Friday in its attempt to extend its regulatory reach over banking subsidiaries and state-chartered banks seeking to expand into such areas as insurance and real estate investing.


Chess
LEAD: For the first time since the beginning of women's international team play in 1957, the Soviet squad had to yield the championship to Hungary in the 1988 Olympiad, which ended Nov. 27 in Thessaloniki, Greece.
The sensational Hungarian women racked up a score of 33-9 to capture the gold medal.


Ojeda's Recovery
LEAD: Bob Ojeda, who nearly severed the tip off a finger of his pitching hand with an electric hedge clipper in an accident on Sept. 21, says he is recovering nicely from the career-threatening injury.
The Mets' left-hander, who has begun pitching from the mound at a high school field in his hometown of Visalia, Calif., reported he was not hampered even though he has lost feeling in the tip of the middle finger on his left hand.


Steinberg Defense Disputes Account of Child's Death
LEAD: Disputing the prosecution's theory of how Lisa Steinberg was killed, a medical expert for the defense testified yesterday that the child was shaken, then thrown against a hard surface, causing the head injury that killed her.


Quake Felt in Las Vegas
LEAD: A mild earthquake was felt in the Las Vegas area Sunday night, but the authorities received no reports of serious damage or injury.
The tremor, centered 10 miles northeast of Las Vegas, came at 9:08 P.M. and measured 3.2 to 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion and energy released, according to the United States Geological Survey.


A Consortium Will Acquire Cooke's Cable TV Systems
LEAD: A consortium of cable operators said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the cable systems owned by Jack Kent Cooke, which have a total of 700,000 subscribers.
No price was disclosed.

Management Council, which represents the owners, and the N.F.L.

LEAD: British officials told Iran today that relations could not improve without progress on freeing British hostages believed to be held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon.

LEAD: THE Noxell Corporation, maker of Noxzema skin creams and Cover Girl cosmetics, has decided to screen new cosmetics and skin care products for safety by applying them to tissue cultures in laboratory dishes instead of injecting them into the eyes of rabbits.

LEAD: Americans took out $4.5 billion more in consumer debt in November than they paid off, as consumers increased purchases for the holiday season.

Polaroid Stock Off After Court Ruling
LEAD: Investors sold off shares in the Polaroid Corporation after a court ruling cast doubt on whether Roy Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc. could win its $2.4 billion bid to acquire the instant photography company.
The stock of the Cambridge, Mass., company dropped $1.875 a share yesterday, to $36.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Results Plus
LEAD:  TENNIS  Saceanu Upsets Chesnokov: Christian Saceanu of West Germany upset second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in the $350,000 New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia.
Olivier Delaitre, a French-born resident of Belgium, surprised Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4.


Scientists Find Lasting Damage From Oil Spill
LEAD: IN the first comprehensive ecological study of oil spills in tropical waters, scientists have found that, contrary to widely held assumptions, the damage to coral reefs is not only immediate and severe but also can leave the organisms vulnerable to devastating disease and blight for years to come.


Steinbrenner Files a Suit On Winfield Foundation
LEAD: George Steinbrenner, sued last week by Dave Winfield for his failure to make some $450,000 in payments to the Yankee outfielder's charitable foundation, filed his own lawsuit yesterday in an attempt to remove Winfield as head of the New Jersey-based organization.

LEAD: Afghan guerrilla leaders refused today to resume direct talks with Soviet representatives, accusing Moscow of playing political games to obtain a place in a postwar government for members of the Kabul Government.

LEAD: Despite strong opposition in Japan, the Japanese Government has told American trade officials that its restraints on automobile exports to the United States will be maintained for another year.


Scientists Link Some Breast Cancer to Loss of Protective Gene
LEAD: NEW evidence linking some breast cancers to loss of a protective ''anti-oncogene'' has strengthened the theory that loss of such genes is a major factor in the complex process by which many human cancers arise.

LEAD: In the largest sale under a Government program of tax breaks that is intended to increase ownership of broadcast properties by members of minority groups, The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its cable television system for $420 million in cash.

LEAD: No conclusive evidence exists on how abortions affect a woman's mental or physical health, C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, told President Reagan in a report today.


Supreme Court to Hear Argument On Law Limiting Abortion Access
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a Missouri law intended to limit access to abortions.
The case offers the Court a vehicle for reconsidering its abortion precedents, a step urged by both Missouri and the Reagan Administration, but the brief order issued today gave no indication whether the Court would take that opportunity.


U.S. Pilots Got Caution Warning
LEAD: The Navy pilots who downed two Libyan fighters last week received orders moments beforehand to act with caution and fire only in self-defense, the Pentagon said today.
The pilots had not received orders to fire at will.
A Pentagon spokesman, Daniel Howard, said the cautionary advice means that ''weapons are to be fired in self defense.

Soviets Open Pre-1917 Files
LEAD: The Central State Archive has opened 500,000 secret files on such subjects as the Russian Orthodox Church and the White Guards' opposition to the Bolshevik Revolution, the press agency Tass reported today.
Records on organizations liquidated during the 1920's and 30s, at the height of the Stalinist repression, are being declassified, it said.

Bridge
LEAD: A useful book for the experienced player is one that tests him with miscellaneous play and defense problems.
This genre, common in England, is rather rare on this side of the Atlantic.
Helping to fill the gap is ''Spingold Challenge,'' in which the reader, by a set of curious chances, finds himself in the final of a national knockout team championship and plays 64 difficult deals.

Barr, who as a producer brought to the stage the works of Edward Albee, Samuel Beckett and many other playwrights, was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Devil and Bruin Draw Suspensions
LEAD: Coach Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins was suspended by the National Hockey League for four games and Jim Korn, a Devils' forward, was banned for three games yesterday in connection with their fight Dec. 29 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
The league also fined each club $5,000, O'Relly $1,000 and Korn $500 for their fight in the runway under the stands at the end of Boston's 6-2 victory.


Stake in Unit Is Acquired By Memorex
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement with Memorex Telex N.V. to form a joint venture in which each company would own half of National Advanced Systems, formerly National's wholly owned subsidiary, which distributes mainframe computers and peripheral equipment manufactured by Hitachi Ltd.


Review/Television; Robert Moses' Vision: Boon and Bane
LEAD: To his admirers, he was the greatest builder of all time, who transformed New York from a 19th- to a 20th-century city and paved the way for urban developers throughout America.
To his critics, he was a prodigious destroyer of neighborhoods, who cared less for flesh and blood than for steel and concrete.


Male Duck's Timidity Around Flashy Rivals May Threaten Species
LEAD: THE American black duck, whose numbers have shrunk by 60 percent in the last 30 years, may be on the road to extinction because males of the species are too timid to win females away from the flashier and more assertive mallard drake, a study by Canadian scientists suggests.

OPEC Sets Strategy Talks With Other Oil Producers
LEAD: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other oil-producing nations will meet on Jan. 26 in London to discuss ways to cooperate in an attempt to stabilize the world oil market, the Secretary General of OPEC said today.


William Powers, 81, A Rhode Island Judge
LEAD: William E. Powers, the victim of an accident that left him blind, who become a Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court and the state's Attorney General, died Saturday at the Wayland Health Center in Providence.
He was 81 years old.

Sallie Mae Prices $450 Million Issue
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday priced a $450 million issue of floating-rate notes due on July 13, 1989, through a group of various securities dealers.
Sallie Mae is a federally chartered stockholder-owned corporation that has financed about 4 in 10 of all guaranteed student loans outstanding today, Offered at a price of par, the notes are yielding a variable rate equal to 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate.


Discovery of Rare Stars
LEAD: The world's most powerful radiotelescope has pierced dense clouds of cosmic dust and gas to reveal scores of very young stars in much greater profusion than ever found before, astronomers at the University of Wisconsin have reported.


After the N.F.L. Huddles, Bengals Won't Have To
LEAD: The Cincinnati Bengals can continue doing what they did to get to the Super Bowl.


G.E. of Britain Vows to Fight Possible Offer of $12 Billion
LEAD: Britain's largest manufacturing concern, the General Electric Company, vowed today to fight a takeover bid estimated at $12 billion that an international consortium is apparently trying to put together.


GTE Reorganizes Into Six Units
LEAD: The GTE Corporation, which operates the largest independent phone network in the United States, reorganized into six operating units and eliminated a layer of management in the process.
GTE has been restructuring since March, selling various businesses and announcing big job cuts.


Vagrant Held In Slaying Of Pathologist
LEAD: A vagrant who had been living secretly on the 22d floor of the Bellevue Hospital Center was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder, rape and robbery of a pregnant doctor who was attacked as she worked alone in her office Saturday afternoon.


Our Towns; Open Any Door: You Can't Tell An Owner Is Poor
LEAD: If you really, really try hard, you might be able to tell which are the subsidized low- and moderate-income condominiums at the new Society Hill complex here, and which are the $140,000 market-priced units. ''Sometimes I can tell which people - I think I can,'' said Petra Catogge, who lives in a subsidized unit.


Unihorn China Venture
LEAD: Chinese software developers will write programs for overseas customers in a joint venture with an American company.
Unihorn Inc., a San Francisco-based subsidiary of Unison Inc., has joined with the Chinese Aerospace Ministry and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, which sells satellite-launching services, in a venture that will develop and package software for international markets.


Pioneering Studies Find Surprisingly High Rate Of Mental Ills in Young
LEAD: AS many as one in five children suffer from psychiatric problems serious enough to impair their lives in some way, according to the surprising findings of several new surveys of the mental health of children.


Donors to the Neediest Cases List AIDS as a Major Concern
LEAD: ''How does one determine who the truly needy are?'' asks Arlene Solomon of Manhattan.
She notes that there are so many categories to choose from and mentions these: the homeless, battered women and children, people suffering from AIDS and animals abused in many ways.


Rig Count Falls Again
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs fell by 36, to 872, last week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
It was the second consecutive decline.
The count dropped by 32 the week before.
A year ago, the number of working rigs totaled 1,102.
The count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil.


How the Budget Would Allocate Funds for Big Domestic Programs
LEAD: President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1 advocates ending 82 Government programs, cutting spending on farm programs by nearly 19 percent and trimming the growth in Medicare and Medicaid by about $5 billion.

Investment Technologies.

Biotechnology Collaboration
LEAD: California Biotechnology Inc. and Genentech Inc. said today that they had agreed to collaborate on developing therapeutic uses of human lung surfactant.

Marcel Sanders, the president of the the Belgium Trading Company was arrested on Dec. 22 after trying to complete arrangements for an illegal shipment of American-made equipment to Bulgaria, the Government said.

New Swap Plan By Freddie Mac
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced the introduction of a weighted-average-coupon adjustable-rate mortgage guarantor program.
Under the program, Freddie Mac will swap its weighted-average-coupon adjustable-rate mortgage participation certificates for a like amount of adjustable-rate mortgages issued by lenders.

Thanks to him, balancing the books in future years will be harder than ever.

Cox to buy Texas Papers
LEAD: The Herald Publishing Company, corporate owner of The Daily Sentinel and The Sunday Sentinel, announced last week that it had agreed to sell the Nacogdoches newspapers to Cox Enterprises Inc.
No price was disclosed.
Cox publishes 17 daily newspapers, including 6 in Texas.
The transaction includes not only the Sentinels but also Ad Extra and The Garrison News.

Dukakis to Sit Out The Inaugural Ball
LEAD: Michael Dukakis will not be dancing at George Bush's Inaugural Ball.
Massachusetts's state office has sent the Democratic Governor's tickets back to the Presidential Inaugural Committee. ''He's got other things in the works up here,'' said James R. Dorsey, a Dukakis spokesman in Boston.


Review/Architecture; The Healing Murals of Richard Haas
LEAD: Richard Haas has, in all but name, become an architect.
He has not gone to school and got a degree, but no matter: Mr.
Haas's art, which has long taken architecture as its theme, has now expanded to the point where it plays as much of a role in the cityscape as many real buildings.


In Accessories, the Mood Is Softer
LEAD: When fashion follows a classic route, as it is doing for this spring, the extras make a difference.
Accessories can set a woman apart from the crowd and establish her personal style.
She can be as classic as a triple strand of pearls or as exotic as an armload of jangling charm bracelets.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Yellow Spots Gets Job For Southwestern Bell
LEAD: Yellow Spots Inc., the company that sees value in unused space in the nation's Yellow Pages directories, has become the exclusive marketer of filler space for Southwestern Bell Media's blond books.


Default Case Jury Let Go
LEAD: The 17-member jury for the huge securities fraud trial involving the Washington Public Power Supply System's $2.25 billion bond default was formally dismissed today.


Bill Terry, a .400 Hitter for the Giants, Dies at 90
LEAD: Bill Terry, the Hall of Famer who was the last player to bat .400 in the National League, died yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla.
He was 90 years old, and had been in failing health for several months.


Albany Urged to Keep Psychiatric Care Beds
LEAD: New York City Mental Health Commissioner Dr.
Sara Kellerman urged the state yesterday to relieve ''psychiatric gridlock'' by halting a state plan she said would reduce the number of beds for troubled patients.

LEAD: The entire White House staff was asked by President Reagan in November to submit resignations effective ''at the pleasure of the President.'' So some staff members have set out on their own rather than hold out hope for a post in the Bush administration.

Syracuse Upset Again as Villanova Tiumphs
LEAD: Kenny Wilson scored 20 points tonight to lead Villanova to a 75-73 victory over No. 4 Syracuse.
It was the Orangemen's second Big East Conference loss in a week.


Mourning Fails to Slow Japan's Economy
LEAD: No sooner did Emperor Hirohito fall gravely ill than Japan starting projecting the economic cost of an imperial mourning and succession period.
Economists calculated that the country's ever expanding gross national product would be noticeably hurt by days of lost work, as the world's second-largest economy officially closed down.

LEAD: A softening of a proposed resolution on the downing of two Libyan jets by United States planes over the Mediterranean last week was reported by diplomats today as the Security Council ended its third day of debate on the incident.

LEAD: New York City lost a key ally on the Senate Finance Committee today and Long Island legislators gained new leverage in the first major realignment of the State Senate leadership since 1973.
