Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Is it true that spare batteries last longer if they are kept in the refrigerator?
A.
It was probably true in the past, but consumers probably could not tell a difference now because of changes in the way batteries are made, battery manufacturers say.


Guilty Pleas Close Case Against 10 Klan Members
LEAD: Four members of the Ku Klux Klan pleaded guilty today just before their trial was scheduled to begin on Federal charges of conspiring to attack civil rights marchers in Decatur, Ala., in May 1979.

Thomas H. Kean released today a summary of his proposed initiatives for 1989, including programs designed to create low- and moderate-income housing, and a bond issue that would preserve open lands in this, the nation's most densely populated state.

LEAD: Israeli troops shot and wounded 23 Palestinians during clashes today, Arab reports said, as a general strike closed down the occupied territories.

Stephen Csoka, Painter, 92
LEAD: Stephen Csoka, a Hungarian-born realist painter who taught art in New York for four decades, died Thursday at his home in Kings Park, L.I.
He was 92 years old.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Monday about the Federal budget process misidentified the broadcast on which Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine appeared Sunday.
It was ''Meet the Press'' on NBC.


Koop's Stand on Abortion's Effect Surprises Friends and Foes Alike
LEAD: Once again Dr.
C.
Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, has confounded the White House and Congress, liberals and conservatives.
This time he told President Reagan in a letter Monday that, after extensive study, he could not conclude one way or another that abortions were harmful to women.


France Delays Visa Changes
LEAD: A French Government spokesman says that plans to cancel the visa requirement for American visitors are still under negotiation and that France is seeking a reciprocal move by the United States.


A New Way to Save Electricity
LEAD: Electrical transformers, which reduce high voltages on power lines to levels useful in homes and businesses, are inefficient devices.
Their metal cores must be magnetized and demagnetized dozens of times each second, which wastes electricity.
But amorphous metals, in which the atoms are arrayed radomly rather than in tight rows, are much more efficient as transformer cores because they are more easily magnetized and demagnetized.


Correction
LEAD: A brief report in the Transition Watch column yesterday about the Bible that will be used in George Bush's inauguration misstated the date the Bible was given to St.
John's Masonic Lodge in New York.
It was in 1770, not after George Washington's inauguration in 1789.

LEAD: Hardly a week passes without the United States devising yet another task for the no-longer-scorned United Nations.
The most recent proposal is to give the Secretary General power to probe charges of chemical weapons use.
That's a sensible idea, and the larger policy change is surely welcome.
What's baffling, even shaming, is that these ideas are unblushingly promoted by the U.N.

Judge Rules Mistrial in GAF Case
LEAD: In a serious embarrassment to Federal prosecutors in New York, a judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation case, the first prosecution based on information from the insider-trading scandals of 1986.


Texas Instruments Plans Plant in Italy
LEAD: Texas Instruments said it would build a $250 million semiconductor fabrication plant in Avezzano, Italy, about 65 miles east of Rome, to supply the European semiconductor market.

LEAD: The WPP Group has acquired for an undisclosed sum Donahue &amp; Associates Advertising, a firm that specializes in employment recruitment advertising.
Donahue, which has $20 million in billings, will be merged into Thompson Recruitment Advertising, a Los Angeles-based unit of J. Walter Thompson, whose billings exceed $130 million.

G.M. Layoffs at Buick
LEAD: About 100 workers of the General Motors Corporation's Buick division will be laid off as the auto maker cuts production of its Reatta luxury two-seat car, a company spokesman said Monday.
Larry Gustin said production levels at the Reatta Craft Center in Lansing, Mich., would be cut Feb. 13, from 56 to 42 cars a day.

LEAD: Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday after four days of gains, but the decline was modest.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended 6.25 points lower, at 2,193.21, after once again piercing 2,200 in early trading.

Wine Talk
LEAD: HOW much does anyone really know about wine?
There are sports fans who know every statistic, every player and every rule but who cannot throw a ball.
There are wine fans who know all the labels and all the vintages but who cannot tell hearty Burgundy from rare old Bordeaux.


M.H. Stone, Acclaimed Mathematician, Dies at 85
LEAD: Marshall Harvey Stone, a prodigious and influential American mathematician, died Monday in Madras, India, apparently of a stroke.
Dr.
Stone, who was 85 years old, had gone to India to attend a music festival.

Until recently the company's efforts to build in New York City have been thwarted by the high cost of land in acceptable locations.

LEAD: In the first formal inquiry into the savings industry's problems by the new Congress, members of the House Banking Committee assailed regulators today for their flurry of December transactions that rid the industry of 75 insolvent savings and loan institutions at a cost of $16.7 billion.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Monday about criticism of Finance Minister Shimon Peres over reports of a special account for the Finance Minister in the Israeli budget misstated the size of the account.
It is said to be equivalent to one-tenth of 1 percent of the overall budget reductions recommended by Mr.
Peres, not 10 percent.

LEAD: In the six days between the death and the Jan. 2 funeral of Daw Khin Kyi, the widow of the founder of Burmese independence, more than 20,000 people flocked to her house and garden off University Avenue, near Inya Lake.
They came to show reverence and respect, but also resistance, for Daw Khin Kyi's daughter, Aung San Suu Kyi, has become the foremost symbol of Burma's hopes for democracy.

Topics of The Times; Mr. Giuliani Departs
LEAD: Some prosecutors are quietly efficient.
Rudolph Giuliani, who now announces that he's quitting this month, is loudly so.
In five years as United States Attorney in Manhattan, he raised the visibility of an office long known for effectiveness and professionalism.
He recognized an important part of his job: tell the public what you're doing.

Review/Film; 'Kupalo,' Ukrainian Folk Tale
LEAD: For a couple of minutes at the start of ''The Eve of Ivan Kupalo,'' you can tell what is happening.
An old man in a boat is admiring a young woman -''my black-eyed daughter'' - on shore.
But when a young man appears and embraces her, the father jumps into the water and gets into a clownish splashing match with him.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that a conviction must be set aside whenever a trial judge has interfered with a criminal defendant's constitutional right to the assistance of counsel.

Thus a whole universe opens for Kremlinologists.

LEAD: Randall Cunningham, who directed the Philadelphia Eagles to their first playoff berth since 1981, yesterday was named winner of the Bert Bell Trophy as the National Football League player of the year.
Cunningham won by a 3-1 margin on first-place votes in balloting by Maxwell Football Club members, Pro Football Writers Association members, the Philadelphia news media and all 28 N.F.L.

LEAD: Interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

LEAD:  Security Council


S.E.C. Seeks Wider Fines
LEAD: The head of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Federal agency would ask Congress to pass legislation allowing the S.E.C. to seek monetary penalties for all civil violations of the Federal securities laws.
At present, the S.E.C. can seek monetary penalties only for civil charges of insider trading.


Plane Engine Shut Down Before Crash, British Say
LEAD: Investigators said today that an engine on a British airliner was inexplicably shut down before the plane crash landed in central England on Sunday night, killing 44 people.


No-Huddle Rule Wasn't An Easy Snap for Esiason
LEAD: Confused about the no-huddle, quick-snap penalty ruling for the American Conference championship game last Sunday?


Mexico Inflation Down
LEAD: A wage and price freeze reduced inflation last year to 51.7 percent, down two-thirds from the 1987 rate, Mexico's central bank said on Monday.
The Bank of Mexico noted that consumer prices rose by 159.2 percent in 1987.
Last Feb. 29, the Government froze the peso's exchange rate against the dollar.


Allegheny Plan Spurs Opposition
LEAD: A compromise plan that two rival suitors for Allegheny International Inc. have reached to avert a bidding war has provoked a backlash among the company's advisers and shareholders.

Nevada Scholarships Stem Student Exodus
LEAD: On a campus where basketball players are recruited with a religious zeal, Nevada's brightest students are getting a second look, thanks to a university president who resolved to stop this state's ''brain drain.''


California's 6-Year Boom May Be Over
LEAD: California's six-year economic boom, which strengthened the state's image as a land of boundless opportunity, may be coming to an end.

Father Flees Court in Case On Medicaid
LEAD: On the day of his sentencing for participating in a $16 million Medicaid fraud, Sheldon Weinberg failed to show up in a Brooklyn court yesterday and was declared a fugitive from justice.


Chefs Search for the Perfect Version
LEAD: RISOTTO is causing quite a stir in restaurants these days.
As diners become more knowledgeable about this versatile northern Italian staple, chefs are responding with an ever-increasing variety of preparations.
The accompanying recipes are a testament to the dish's versatility.


A Franc on the Cabernet Front
LEAD: ALTHOUGH cabernet sauvignon is the dominant red grape in California, trend-spotters predict that it will be challenged by varietal wine made from another family member - cabernet franc.


Kean Urges Ending 'No Fault' Car Insurance
LEAD: Reflecting the growing rage of car owners over soaring insurance premiums, Gov.
Thomas H. Kean today proposed scrapping New Jersey's 16-year-old system of ''no fault'' automobile insurance, an experiment originally intended to save drivers money.


William J. McDonald, A Catholic Bishop, 83
LEAD: The Most Rev.
William J. McDonald, a nationally known cleric who served as Auxiliary Bishop of the San Francisco Archdiocese for 12 years before his retirement, died of a heart attack Saturday.
He was 83 years old, Bishop McDonald, a native of Ireland, was president of the International Federation of Catholic Universities from 1960 to 1963 and editor of the Catholic Encyclopedia.


Atlanta Official Fined on Gun
LEAD: Atlanta City Councilman Hosea Williams, who was arrested in March for trying to carry a .38-caliber pistol past security at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport, was fined $1,000 Monday after pleading no contest to carrying a concealed weapon and carrying a pistol without a permit, misdemeanor charges.


Suns Beginning to See the Light
LEAD: Two occurrences best highlight the five-year fall and resurgence of the Phoenix Suns.
The decline began in June 1983 with the trade of Dennis Johnson to the Celtics for Rick Robey.
The trade considerably strengthened Boston and proved disastrous for the Suns.
Phoenix has finished at or below the .500 mark ever since and has missed the playoffs the last four seasons.


2 Groups Discuss Offers for G.E.C.
LEAD: Two international groups are talking about bidding for Britain's huge General Electric Company, industry sources said.
One is headed by General Electric of the United States, which is not linked in any way with G.E.C., and the other by G.E.C.'s chief British rival, Plessey P.L.C.


With a Microwave Oven, Relief From Constant Stirring
LEAD: THE very notion of cooking risotto in a microwave oven may seem as close to culinary blasphemy as one can get.
In reality, however, it is one of the most alluring recipes in the microwave cooking repertory.
Risotto cooked this way is not cooked more quickly than the traditional stove-top version, but the quality is excellent and the cook is liberated from the endless standing and stirring.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: AFTER a brunch of beef sausages, fried chicken, macaroni salad and Tater Tots, the 114 members of the Corsi Senior Center on East 116th Street in East Harlem donned party hats, decided who should have which noisemakers and strolled - some with canes, some with walkers - from the center's dining room into the lounge.


Moody's Reduces Rating On Outstanding Sears Debt
LEAD: Moody's Investors Service has reduced the debt rating for more than $5 billion in outstanding debt issued by Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company and of Sears Roebuck Acceptance and Sears Overseas Finance.


John F. Hennessy, 60, Construction Engineer
LEAD: John Francis Hennessy, a consulting engineer who supervised the design of major buildings in New York City and Washington, died of a heart attack Monday.
He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Pentagon Moves Against Figures Cited in Inquiry
LEAD: The Navy has initiated actions against more than a dozen individuals and companies involved in the Federal inquiry into military procurement fraud, including the suspension without pay of a Navy employee who was indicted in the case last week, the Pentagon announced today.

Donald Voorhees, 85, Conductor Who Led 'Bell Telephone Hour'
LEAD: Donald Voorhees, for 28 years the conductor and musical director of the ''Bell Telephone Hour,'' one of the most popular musical programs in broadcasting history, died of pneumonia yesterday at Tomlin Memorial Hospital in Cape May Court House, N.J.
He was 85 years old and lived in Stone Harbor, N.J.


U.S. Report Raises Estimate of Smoking Toll
LEAD: Twenty-five years after the Surgeon General of the United States jolted the nation with the first official warning of the health perils of cigarettes, a Federal report has concluded that smoking has caused more death and disease than previously believed.


Counter-Inaugurations
LEAD: The counter-culture lives, also in the context of the Presidential inauguration festivities that are to take place next week.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Surgeon General's Surprise


Why Not a Methadone Clone for Cocaine?
LEAD: Nothing would help the medical and public health communities fight substance abuse more than a chemical treatment that works against cocaine addiction much as methadone works against heroin.


Urban School District For Indians Is Urged
LEAD: The Minnesota Legislature should start the nation's first urban school district run by American Indians to focus on the special educational needs of native American children, a group of educators has recommended.


Giants Sued for Bias in Coach Hiring
LEAD: Lance Hamilton, the former Penn State linebacker, has filed a suit charging the Giants and the National Football League with racial discrimination.
He contended in a suit filed yesterday in State Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., that the Giants had reneged on a promised offer of a coaching job because he is black.


Arum Makes Big Plans
LEAD: Predicting that 1989 would be ''the year of the middleweights,'' Bob Arum announced yesterday that he planned to promote a series of middleweights bouts that would unify the title.
And if everything works the way the president of Top Rank Inc. believes it will, the series will lead to a fight that might gross more than $30 million.


Holly Farms to Set New Bid Deadline
LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation, the Memphis chicken producer, said its two suitors, Tyson Foods Inc. of Springdale, Ark., and Conagra Inc. of Omaha, would not be required to have their best proposals to acquire the company ready for Wednesday's board meeting.


Jackson Talks Resume
LEAD: After a hiatus of almost two months, the Knicks resumed negotiations yesterday on a new contract for Mark Jackson, their star second-year guard.
Al Bianchi, the club's general manager, and Don Cronson, Jackson's agent, met for about an hour in Bianchi's office at Madison Square Garden.
Bianchi said he had given Cronson an opportunity to make a counterproposal to the Knick offer that Bianchi had called ''final'' at the previous session on Nov.


End of Jersey's No-Fault System Would Surprise Few Auto Insurers
LEAD: The proposal by Gov.
Thomas H. Kean that New Jersey abandon its no-fault system for automobile insurance is unlikely to be viewed as a decisive blow to the no-fault concept in insurance circles.
The New Jersey version of no-fault has long been regarded as so weak as to be no-fault in name only.


Redmen's Fortune Turns for The Better
LEAD: Contrary to the assortment of twists and turns that have lurked along the path to victory for teams in the Big East Conference this season, something straight and narrow transpired last night before a sellout 6,008 fans at Alumni Hall: St.
John's defeated Connecticut, 71-63.


Market Place; Warning Signs For Stock Prices
LEAD: THE Dow Jones industrial average is trading at its highest levels since the 1987 crash, to a chorus of disbelief.
Contrarians can take comfort in just how much doubt there is, but in the meantime there are signs that the stock market is not nearly so healthy as the Dow would seem to indicate.


British List Bill On Steroid Use
LEAD: A bill that would impose a criminal penalty on anyone caught taking or supplying anabolic steroids without a prescription was introduced in the House of Commons today.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were generally higher in erratic trading yesterday.


Cocoa Prices Fall Sharply Amid Selling by Arbitragers
LEAD: Cocoa futures prices dropped sharply yesterday amid heavy arbitrage selling and rumors of large export shipments from the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer.

Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL  YANKEES (AL) - Traded Rick Rhoden, pitcher, to Houston for John Fishel, outfielder, and Pedro DeLeon and Mike Hook, pitchers.
Assigned Hook and DeLeon to Albany of the Eastern League.
MONTREAL (NL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Fitzgerald, catcher, on a one-year contract.
OAKLAND (AL) - Agreed to terms with Matt Young, pitcher, on a one-year contract.


Newspaper Ads Up
LEAD: Spending on newspaper advertising for the first three quarters of last year totaled $22.68 billion, an increase of 5.9 percent over the comparable period in 1987, according to preliminary estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.
National spending rose by 2.5 percent, to $2.66 billion, while retail advertising climbed by 3.5 percent, to $11.08 billion, and classified increased by 6.8 percent, to $3.01 billion.


Boom Ends As Minorities In the Region Lag Behind
LEAD: The metropolitan region's six-year economic boom has ended but without any progress in drawing a large part of the population into the mainstream workforce.


Eating Well
LEAD: IT seems as if everyone is talking or writing about nutrition these days.
Even if you seldom follow the subject, you might be surprised at the amount of information you have absorbed subliminally.


Interim U.S. Attorney: 'Street Smart' and Fair
LEAD: Benito Romano brings to the job of interim United States Attorney ''street smarts,'' a fervent intolerance for corruption and a sense of fairness that comes from growing up poor in the South Bronx, his friends and colleagues say.


India's Claims on China
LEAD: To the Editor:


Review/Television; Smoking: From Flirtation to Peril
LEAD: ''Smoking: Everything You and Your Family Need to Know,'' on Home Box Office tonight at 10:30, marks the 25th anniversary of the Surgeon General's report linking cigarette smoking and lung cancer.
Nothing good has been discovered about smoking in the interim.


Rostropovich to Conduct Premiere Of Unpublished Shostakovich Work
LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet expatriate cellist and conductor of the National Symphony, will present the world premiere of an unpublished and unperformed satirical cantata by Dmitri Shostakovich tomorrow night in Washington.
The National Symphony is to play the same all-Shostakovich program Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.


Carnegie Plans Centennial
LEAD: Carnegie Hall officials announced preliminary plans yesterday for the hall's centennial season in 1990-91, highlighted by a commissioning program to link 10 composers with 10 performers and ensembles.


Time for Mr. Mosbacher to Come Clean
LEAD: Robert Mosbacher, who served as George Bush's chief campaign fund-raiser, now reaps his reward; he is the President-elect's choice to be Secretary of Commerce.
But before he is confirmed he needs to take care of some unfinished business: clearing the air about the millions he raised in so-called ''soft-money'' campaign contributions.


Record at Burson
LEAD: Burson-Marsteller, the public relations unit of Young &amp; Rubicam, said yesterday that its 1988 revenues totaled a record $148.7 million.
The revenues increased 17.6 percent over those of 1987.


Children's Book Awards For Writers and Illustrators
LEAD: Paul Fleischman has won the 1989 John Newbery Medal for his book ''Joyful Noise: Poems for Two Voices'' (Charlotte Zolotow/Harper &amp; Row).
The award is given annually for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children.
The books honored have been published the previous year.

Arbitration for Joyner
LEAD: Wally Joyner, the California Angels first baseman, filed for salary arbitration yesterday.
Three players who were eligible to file yesterday agreed to one-year contracts: Mike Fitzgerald with the Montreal Expos, Ken Howell with the Philadelphia Phillies and Pat Clements with the Padres.
Players can file through Monday.


8 Desktop Computers Introduced by Digital
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced eight desktop computers today and outlined a new software strategy that company executives said would give the company an advantage by allowing its different models to be coupled more closely.


Cyril A. Zebot, Professor, 74
LEAD: Cyril A. Zebot, a retired professor of economics at Georgetown University and a Slovenian nationalist who vigorously opposed the postwar Communist regime in Yugoslavia, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Washington.
He was 74 years old.
Professor Zebot, a graduate of the University of Ljubljana, came to the United States in 1947 and taught at Duquesne University before joining the Georgetown faculty in 1958.


Nuclear Plant Decision Is Limited
LEAD: Experts on utility regulation said the Supreme Court's decision that utilities do not have a constitutional right to bill customers for the costs of unfinished plants had limited applicability to the scores of nuclear plants abandoned around the country.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Pacers 127, Celtics 108: Indiana beat Boston at Boston Garden last night for the first time in 18 regular-season games since April 2, 1978.
Chuck Person scored 29 points and Rik Smits had 21 as the Pacers gained their first victory in 16 road games this season.
It was the fourth consecutive victory for the Pacers, including three straight under Dick Versace, their new coach.

Mr.
Lifchitz, who holds academic posts in Albany and New York City, writes a busy, rhythmically active, upbeat-sounding kind of music in a dissonant idiom.

LEAD: The landmark Sheraton Palace Hotel, a home away from home for several Presidents and armies of celebrities since 1875, has closed for the first time since the great earthquake of 1906 for a $60 million, 18-month renovation.

Karl Geiringer, 89, Musicologist And Composers' Biographer, Dies
LEAD: Karl Geiringer, a leading figure in musicology since the 1930's, died Tuesday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif., from complications arising from a fall.
He was 89 years old and lived in Santa Barbara.

Bush's staff said tonight.

LEAD: Gov.
Thomas Kean's final New Jersey State of the State Message this week was notable mainly for its modesty, both for the few initiatives proposed and for the demands they would place on the budget.
The modesty is a tribute to the Governor's sense of political realism and the prospect of growing revenue shortfalls.

Ralston Purina
LEAD: The Ralston Purina Company accepted about 5,525,000 shares of its common stock for payment at $84 a share in accordance with its previously announced tender offer.
Based on an early count, the human and pet food products group said about 5,538,000 shares had been tendered at or below $84 a share.
Ralston Purina's offer expired Tuesday night.

LEAD: Britain's Civil Aviation Authority today ordered British airlines to increase inspections on engines similar to those on the Boeing 737-400 aircraft that crashed Sunday and said the inspections would continue until the precise cause of the accident was determined.

LEAD: TOSS a marketing dollar in the air these days and the breeze is likely to waft it away from large advertising agencies and toward small sales-promotion companies or Yellow Pages specialists.

LEAD: Striking oil workers disrupted production throughout Mexico today, protesting the dramatic arrest of their longtime union leader.
But their strike did not spread and there were signs that the bold step by the Government might pass without embroiling it in a national labor crisis.

A real airline should be so soothing and accommodating.

Ogrin Lets Tournament Score Speak for Itself
LEAD: The First Amendment to the Constitution does not really come into play for the golfers on the PGA Tour.
Many pros, including such players as Mac O'Grady, J. C. Snead and David Graham, have paid the price for speaking their minds or writing what they believe.
The going rate has been $1,000 or more in fines.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: ALEXANDRA LOGUE was the sort of finicky eater who drives parents to distraction.
At 1 year of age she wouldn't touch anything except bread and milk.
Fifteen years later she couldn't stand such teen-age staples as spaghetti or Coke.
She still refuses to eat fish.


More Punished in Marine's Death
LEAD: The Marine Corps punished more officers today for abandoning a 19-year old lance corporal in the California desert, where he died last summer.


Scientists Find How Allergic Reaction Works
LEAD: Scientists have discovered the structure of a substance that is a key to allergic reactions, and they expect to use the knowledge soon in searching for new treatments for these widespread and varied forms of illness.


Holmgren Is a Coach After His Players' Hearts
LEAD: The night he found out he wasn't a Flyer anymore, a devastating tidbit of news that came to him from his car radio, Paul Holmgren drove the car into a ditch.
His body, already battered from eight years as a Flyer henchman, wasn't hurt, but his pride was, and at that moment the ditch seemed like the place to be.


Special Agency for Air Traffic Urged by Transportation Chief
LEAD: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley today proposed restructuring his department in a way that could lead to the establishment of a semiprivate organization to control the nation's air traffic.

LEAD: C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, criticized the tobacco industry today for advertisements in many newspapers that maintain that smokers are a put-upon group and that ''enough is enough!''

LEAD: The West German economy defied the gloomy forecasts of a year ago to post its strongest growth since 1979, according to provisional figures on 1988 performance released today by the Federal Statistics Office.

LEAD: The Devils and the Canadiens played hockey tonight the way it should be, fast end-to-end action with no fights, crisp and accurate passing and inspired goaltending from both teams.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater plans to celebrate its 50th anniversary with extended United States and international tours, a retrospective of the company's repertory, a ''Dance in America'' program for public television, and a touring exhibition of Ballet Theater memorabilia.


U.S. ORDERS CHECKS ON 300 JETLINERS
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration instructed United States airlines tonight to inspect 300 Boeing aircraft within 72 hours to make sure that their engine warning systems and monitoring circuits are not flawed.


1% OF EMPLOYEES TESTED FOR DRUGS
LEAD: Despite intense publicity about the magnitude of the nation's drug problem, less than 1 percent of the nation's workers were subjected to drug tests by their employers from the summer of 1987 to the summer of 1988, the Labor Department said today.


90 Feared Dead in Pakistan On Boat Carrying Mourners
LEAD: A river boat crowded with funeral mourners and goats broke apart and capsized after hitting an obstruction, and 90 people were missing and feared dead, newspapers said today.

LEAD: Mary Field Twombly, a former member of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee, which monitored patient care for the United Hospital Fund, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at the Duncaster retirement community in Bloomfield, Conn., where she lived.
She was 79 years old.

LEAD: A 10-month-old boy died after the temperature in the Bronx apartment where he was sleeping reached 110 degrees, the police said yesterday.
His mother, who had turned on a gas heater and then left the child unattended for about 12 hours, was charged with manslaughter.


Soviets Say Foreigners Will Need AIDS Certificates
LEAD: The Soviet Government said today that it would require foreigners planning to stay here for longer than three months to present a certificate showing they do not carry the AIDS virus, starting Feb. 1.

Chrysler officials were not immediately available for comment on the report.

Diamond Trade Spurts
LEAD: Belgium's diamond trade, the world's largest, reported a 27 percent gain in business last year, to 461.5 billion francs ($12.5 billion), the industry said on Tuesday.
The country's diamond sales rose 25 percent, to 229.6 billion francs ($6.2 billion), while imports climbed 30 percent, to 231.9 billion francs ($6.3 billion).

LEAD: Lloyd's of London, which prides itself on having never failed to settle an insurance claim, said today that it would maintain its policy of unlimited liability.

LEAD: National Football League owners yesterday approved unanimously a free-agency plan the league will put into effect Feb. 1 unless an agreement is negotiated with the players' union.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.The floors in our bathrooms are covered with small hexagonal tiles that I feel look old-fashioned.
I would like to re-cover these floors with a vinyl or with some other type of tile.
Can I apply the new floor covering directly on top of the old tiles, or must they all be removed first?
A.As long as the old tiles are still bonding firmly you can apply a new floor covering directly over them.

Our Towns; Creating Castles At a Discount For Playgrounds
LEAD: No one at Fairmount Elementary School had ever met a celebrity architect before.
And what a celebrity.
Robert Leathers has built 450 playgrounds all over America. (How do you get a job like that, they wanted to know. Might as well be eating ice cream for a living.) At each school he mobilizes hundreds of children and parent volunteers, showing them how to construct a playground in practically no time for a fraction of the normal cost.

SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Schneider Sings Weill Helen Schneider, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005).

In her new show, devoted to the songs of Kurt Weill, Ms.
Schneider dives fearlessly into the tempestuous emotional world of the songs, rather than taking the ironic distance that an older generation of Weill interpreters used to adopt.

John Island after surgery, a festival spokesman said.

Touring the Brooklyn Museum: An Art Explorer's Selection
LEAD: Doubtless it is from professional deformation that this critic has, every so often, an irresistible dream.
He is in a city unknown to him.
On the top of a hill, there is an enormous house.
He walks up to it.
The door opens to his touch.
He gets inside.
Before him is an encyclopedia for the eye.
The art of all times and all places is documented there, together with human nature in all complexities.

Brazil High-Speed Train
LEAD: Brazil has announced plans to introduce Latin America's first high-speed train.
The train, which will exceed 132 miles an hour, will reduce the travel time between the country's two main cities, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, to two hours, the authorities said.
The cities are 280 miles apart.

LEAD: Murray Industries, the parent of the Murray Chris-Craft Boat Companies, said it had tentatively approved an offer from Genmar Industries to buy a substantial part of the boat maker's assets.
Terms were not disclosed.
The offer is subject to court and regulatory approval and any higher or better offer, said Mary Glass, a Chris-Craft spokeswoman.

Review/Concert; 83 Minutes of Bruckner
LEAD: Klaus Tennstedt and the Philadelphia Orchestra devoted their entire program Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall to Bruckner's Symphony No. 8 in C minor.
That meant the concert, without intermission, began at 8:05 and ended two minutes before 9:30.
But it would seem unlikely that anyone in the nearly full auditorium felt cheated of their customary two-hour concert span.


Thomas Brennan, 81, Trade Group Official
LEAD: Thomas M. Brennan, an official of the National Association of Manufacturers for 28 years before his retirement in 1965, died of cancer on Tuesday at his winter home in Lake Wales, Fla.
He was 81 years old and also had a home in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

Review/Art; Straitened Landscapes Of a Post-Modern Era
LEAD: Suddenly there is a spate of landscape shows in New York.
Several have a post-modern feeling to them, which is surprising since post-modern landscape painting has almost seemed like a contradiction in terms: post-modernism has a lot more to do with sitting around theorizing about ''nature'' than setting hand and foot to earth and stone.


Washington Talk: Briefing; They Also Serve
LEAD: There was an unusual ceremony Wednesday honoring a Foreign Service wife, Emily Vest.
She was given a ''tribute of appreciation'' and a plaque by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said of her four decades of service to the country, ''You have represented America with distinction.''

Space Shuttle Will Not Carry Civilians on Its Future Flights
LEAD: The space agency, scarred by the explosion of the Challenger in which a teacher was killed, announced today that it will no longer carry civilians on the space shuttle.


William Chaison, 44, Dancer and Teacher
LEAD: William Chaison, a dancer and choreographer and associate professor of physical education at Kean College in Union, N.J., died last Friday at Doctor's Hospital in New York City.
He was 44 years old.

Assessing the Johnson Debacle
LEAD: The specter of the sprinter Ben Johnson and his Olympic fiasco hung over a hearing room this week as Canada's judicial inquiry into drug use by athletes began taking testimony in an attempt to get to the bottom of the country's worst sporting embarrassment.


Experimental Ulcer Drug Held Superior to Current Mainstay
LEAD: Researchers have found that a new ulcer drug is superior to one of the mainstays of ulcer treatment because it promotes healing and relieves symptoms more quickly.

Sudan Train on Rebuilt Track Takes Food to Starving Town
LEAD: Railway workers, rebuilding track as they went, crossed 175 miles of Sudan's civil war zone to reach the starving town of Awiel with 30 carloads of cornmeal, the Government reported today.

Review/Film; 'Sucka,' a Sendup
LEAD: A decade and a half after their heyday, the grand old men of the blaxploitation genre can be heard complaining about their bunions in ''I'm Gonna Git You Sucka,'' a cheerful and gag-filled (though not terribly sharp-toothed) sendup that actually owes less to blaxploitation than to the anything-goes humor of the ''Airplane!


Spinal Osteoporosis Reported Halted by New Drug Therapy
LEAD: Texas researchers reported evidence today that a new treatment halts the progress of spinal osteoporosis and reverses bone loss.
The disease, which can cause a curved spine and stooped posture, afflicts millions of people, primarily elderly women.


Knight-Ridder to Sell 2 Daily Papers
LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced plans today to sell two of its daily newspapers - The Star-News in Pasadena, Calif., and The Post-Tribune in Gary, Ind.


Housing Street People Better, Cheaper
LEAD: Shelter number 1 offers hundreds of beds on the noisy, open floor of an armory.
Privacy is impossible and there are too few security guards to assure personal safety.
The most fragile homeless street people, the mentally ill, shrink from such a place.


Miami Upsets Kansas on Foul Shot With 2 Seconds to Play
LEAD: Joel Warren made a foul shot with two seconds remaining for his only point of the game tonight and Miami upset No. 16 Kansas, 87-86, ending the Jayhawks' 11-game winning streak.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased by $4.36 billion, to $282.4 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 137 institutional funds rose by $519.2 million, to $72.94 billion.
The assets of the 225 general-purpose funds were up by $239.5 million, to $90.17 billion.


New Arrivals: Hustlers Vying With the Skycaps at Kennedy
LEAD: In the year since self-service baggage carts were introduced at Kennedy International Airport, hundreds of free-wheeling hustlers who retrieve the wagons for their 25-cent return fee have taken to cruising the terminals, stealing baggage from the carts and fleecing passengers with a host of confidence schemes.


Drug Nominee Vows He'll Kick the Habit
LEAD: In accepting his new assignment to coordinate the Federal attack on drug abuse, William J. Bennett promised today to give up a drug habit of his own: cigarette smoking.


Airlines Begin Checking Jets' Engine Circuits
LEAD: Airlines began an urgent safety inspection of Boeing 737's around the country today, but as the work progressed no flaws were reported in the wiring of engine monitoring and fire alarm systems.


2 Finalists at Columbia
LEAD: Walt Hameline, caoch at Wagner, and Ray Tellier, coach at Rochester, are the finalists to succeed Larry McElreavy as head football coach at Columbia, several sources told The Associated Press yesterday.
Hameline, who led Wagner to the Division III title in 1987, and Tellier each declined comment except to say he wanted the job.


THE LAW: At the Bar; Conclave in herringbone ponders lofty and mundane in legal education's muddled mission.
LEAD: Speaking to a packed house of his peers, James Boyd White of the University of Michigan talked of Shakespearean sonnets, Burmese art and the evolution of the Gothic arch.
And Dante, Gertrude Stein and Jaroslav Pelikan.
And Picasso's ''Guernica,'' Mont St.
Michel and the cathedral of Chartres.


How Opium Became Burma's Cash Crop
LEAD: To the Editor:


Thomas Will Return
LEAD: The Penn State tailback Blair Thomas, a third-team all-America selection in 1987 who was sidelined by a knee injury last season, announced yesterday that he would return for his final season.
Thomas ran for 1,414 yards on 268 carries in 1987. (AP)


NERVE GAS SCHEME STOPPED IN JERSEY
LEAD: A Short Hills businessman was arrested today by Customs Service agents and charged with participating in a conspiracy to buy and export 125 tons of an illegal nerve gas for $5 million.


PRETORIA MINERS FEUD WITH OWNERS
LEAD: Fifteen months after South Africa's longest and costliest mine strike ended, residual bitterness over mine violence and working conditions has erupted in a war of words between the Anglo American Corporation and the black miners' union.


Reported AIDS Cases Increase in Connecticut
LEAD: Reported cases of AIDS in the state's three biggest cities were up last year, with the largest increase in Bridgeport, the state's Department of Health Services reported.


Holly Farms Sets Deadline for Bids
LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation said it had given its two potential buyers, Tyson Foods Inc. and Conagra Inc., until next Wednesday to submit their best and final offers for the company.
The Memphis-based chicken producer said its board would meet then to consider the proposals and to determine which is the most attractive for Holly


Oil Prices End Unchanged After Day of Wild Swings
LEAD: Domestic crude oil prices closed unchanged yesterday after a day of wild price swings caused by heavy selling at the opening of the New York Mercantile Exchange and fresh buying late in the session.


On Stage
LEAD: 'American' on Broadway Wouldn't it be nice if the year continued with news like this?
And the news is that a show called ''An American in Paris'' (yes, it is the ''American in Paris'' you're thinking of) will, if everything goes as planned, be on Broadway sometime next year.


Delta Government Options Given Approval by S.E.C.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved the Delta Government Options Corporation yesterday as the first registered clearing organization for over-the-counter options on Treasury securities.


Israeli Jets Raid Base Of Palestinian Group
LEAD: Israeli Air Force jets attacked a base in southern Lebanon today that belongs to the hard-line Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal.
It was the second day of air raids.


Restaurants
LEAD:  La Boite en Bois Just a few years ago, when someone seeking restaurant advice asked me what to look for around Lincoln Center, my response was ''a cab.'' I was only half joking, for pickings in the neighborhood were lean.
Cafe Luxembourg was always a solid choice, but it is difficult to reserve on short notice.


Recycling Plant for Rockland
LEAD: The Rockland County Executive, John T. Grant, is proposing a $3 million bond issue to plan and design a countywide recycling plant.
He said he would submit the proposal to the County Legislature at the end of the month, along with legislation on the management of recycling in the county.
The proposals are part of his plan to develop a countywide recycling program by 1990.

LEAD:  Aunt Sonia Aunt Sonia is not a matronly relative who loves to cook.
It's a down-home, no-frills restaurant in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn - named for the nearby Ansonia Clock Building - that turns out some engaging fare at budget prices.
The chef and co-owner, Michael Schrieber, is a self-taught cook who took over a bric-a-brac shop in a landmark building two and a half years ago and with his partner, Wayne

Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

Retirement at McCann
LEAD: John J. McNamara announced his retirement yesterday as president and chief operating officer of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, but not his retirement from the larger world.
His first book, ''Advertising Agency Management,'' will be published this summer.
What is more, Mr.
McNamara, 54, is running for mayor of Pelham Manor, N.Y.


No Headline
LEAD: Alain Chevalier resigned today as chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the apparent loser in a bitter board-room power struggle with Bernard Arnault, the largest shareholder.

Marine Officer Charged in Death
LEAD: The Marine Corps said today that an officer had been formally charged in the case of a lance corporal who was abandoned and died in the California desert last summer and that technicalities had been cleared away so that courts-martial of two sergeants could proceed.


Swing for Dancing
LEAD: Spanky Davis, a trumpeter, and the Jimmy Ryan All-Stars will play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society on Sunday at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090).
Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.


Allegheny Plans to Sell Key Units to Rival
LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. disclosed yesterday that its 13 directors had unanimously approved a plan of reorganization that involves selling the company's prized Sunbeam and Oster appliance units to one of its largest competitors, the Black &amp; Decker Corporation, for about $260 million.


Mayoral Credibility and the Talent Bank
LEAD: Six years ago Mayor Koch did something naive or sloppy, or more likely disingenuous.
He established a job-referral service that he said was designed to ''attract women and members of minority groups to city service.''


U.N. Seeks Procedural Shifts For Poison Gas Investigations
LEAD: To improve compliance with a 1925 ban on chemical and germ warfare, the United Nations is preparing a code of conduct to govern investigations into reported violations, officials say.


2d Daughter for Nelson
LEAD: Karl Nelson, the Giants' offensive tackle, has become a father for the second time.
His wife, Heidi, gave birth yesterday to a daughter, Lindsay Rae, at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J.
The Nelsons also have a daughter named Brittany, who will be 3 years old in March.
Nelson began chemotherapy treatment Tuesday after a recurrence of Hodgkin's disease, a cancer of the lymph-node tissue.


Inauguration With a Mission
LEAD: The five-day inaugural gala has been packed with symbols carefully planned to convey the tone of the Bush administration.
Page D28.


Murder Suspect Flees Rikers Unnoticed
LEAD: A man awaiting a second trial on murder charges left Rikers Island last month after an accomplice falsified jail records to make him eligible for bail, a spokeswoman for the City Corrections Department said last night.


Economic Scene; The Budget Gap: Failed Forecasts
LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN has delivered his farewell address and his final budget.
His one great regret, he said, was ''the deficit.'' But the least surprising thing about his final budget is that it shows the deficit declining well within Gramm-Rudman-Hollings targets: to $98.6 billion in 1990, $66.8 billion in 1991, $32.2 billion in 1992, and then swinging above the balanced-budget line to surpluses of $2.4 billion in 1993 and $33.4 billion in 1994.


Whittle Chief Executive Announces Resignation
LEAD: Nicholas Glover, president and chief executive of Whittle Communications, announced his resignation yesterday after five years at the Knoxville, Tenn., publishing partnership he helped to build.
Time Inc. bought a 50 percent interest in the company last month for $185 million, with provisions to increase its stake over the next five years.

LEAD: The defense in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg tried to portray Hedda Nussbaum to the jury yesterday as having been a mentally competent, functional woman immediately after the death of Lisa Steinberg and not the helpless, incoherent victim who the prosecution said was incapable of saving the life of the 6-year-old child.

LEAD: ''VOLTAIRE once said that God is a comedian; it's just that His audience is afraid to laugh,'' said Steve Kaplan, the artistic director of Manhattan Punch Line Theater.

LEAD: Sikhs waging a separatist war in Punjab killed 36 people, hanging 4 in revenge for the executions of two Sikhs convicted in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, the police said today.

Peru Rebels Blamed in Death Of Jersey City Mayor's Wife
LEAD: A New Jersey mayor's wife who died in a rail crash Dec. 1 in Peru was probably the victim of sabotage by leftist guerrillas, the United States Embassy said today.


BEATING IN PANAMA PROTESTED BY U.S.
LEAD: The United States has strongly protested the severe beating and threatened killing of an American sailor by Panama's Defense Forces, Pentagon officials said today.
The Panamanian Government has acknowledged that the incident occurred, but made no apology.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  ALPINE SKIING  Figini Leads Swiss Sweep: Michaela Figini, the defending World Cup champion, led the Swiss to a sweep of three of the top four places in a World Cup downhill race yesterday at the new Tschuggen course on Mount Eiger in Grindelwald, Switzerland.
Figini was timed in 1 minute 55.82 seconds down the tough, bumpy course.

So are some of the major law firms in New York.

LEAD: Nomura Securities International, the American affiliate of the world's largest securities firm, is again trimming its United States staff, particularly in the equities securities area.

'At the Chelsea' Festival Looks at Hotel's History
LEAD: ''At the Chelsea,'' a festival of performance art, music and theater based on the Chelsea Hotel's history, is being presented through Feb. 5 in three rooms of the hotel at 222 West 23d Street.
Among the artists who have created and are to perform works during the festival in tribute to the hotel are David Van Tieghem with Tina Dudek, Penny Arcade, John Kelly, Frank Maya, Squat Theater and Ann Carlson.


Luciano Berio Speaks of Virtuosos and Strings
LEAD: For 30 years Luciano Berio has cultivated, alongside his ambitious and once-controversial works for the stage and concert hall, a special genre of solo music that he calls the ''sequenza'' (sequence).
Each one is a short but substantial unaccompanied virtuoso work, theatrical and full of contrast, usually exploiting unconventional playing techniques.


More Comedy USA
LEAD: Funny men tell no jokes in the new 64-page directory of comedians just published by Barry Weintraub.
Instead, their names lie on the page, waiting to be plucked by casting directors and promotions organizers.
Mr.
Weintraub is a 28-year-old entrepreneur whose previous ventures include Comedy USA, a semiannual magazine distributed at some 300 comedy clubs around the nation, and Comedy USA Newswire, a trade journal.

LEAD: Elizabeth Kellerman of Douglaston, Queens, has embarked on a personal mission to keep the Little Neck Bay shorefront free of litter, going out daily to pick up cast-off cans and bottles.
Then as a double good deed, she sent the refunds on the cans and bottles, amounting to $100, to The New York Time Neediest Cases

G.M.'s Saturn Unit
LEAD: The Saturn Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it would hire 1,000 people and spend $1 billion on capital equipment this year to prepare for the introduction of its cars by the fall of 1990, as planned.
The company now employs 500 people at its complex in Spring Hill, Tenn., where buildings are still being completed.

What's Cooking in Park Slope; Strolling Seventh Avenue With Food in Mind
LEAD: As the gentrification of Park Slope in Brooklyn continues, its major commercial artery, Seventh Avenue, is experiencing dramatic change.
Small ethnic groceries and storefront service businesses are fast giving way to specialty grocers, upscale carryouts, wine shops, bars and trendy restaurants - from bagels to brioche, so to speak.

For All the Talk of New Faces, the Cabinet Shapes Up as a Group of Government Pros
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis promised a campaign about competence, not ideology.
George Bush, who beat him, today completed the selection of a Cabinet that might be described with the same words.


G.M.'s Dispute Over Hughes
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has made only two major strategic acquisitions in recent history, and both have proved troublesome.
Its $2.5 billion purchase of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 1984 led to an embarrassing public dispute with the E.D.S. founder, H. Ross Perot.
Now G.M. is embroiled in a potentially costly wrangle over its 1986 purchase of the Hughes Aircraft Company.


In Brazil, an Isolated Leader Struggles to Be Heard
LEAD: In a somber mood some weeks ago, President Jose Sarney threw out the dark prediction that Brazil is ''marching toward totalitarianism'' as a result of leftist gains in recent municipal elections.


Review/Art; Image Manipulation
LEAD: Barbara Kruger's latest exhibition at the Mary Boone Gallery includes a lenticular photograph depicting five apparently healthy babies who, when seen from one angle, disappear behind block letters spelling out phrases like ''feed me,'' ''hug me,'' ''need me.'' Viewed from another angle, the faces reappear above the words ''psychotic,'' ''neurotic,'' ''schizophrenic,'' ''hysterical'' and ''paranoid.

LEAD: The Ogilvy Group announced yesterday that its board had adopted a shareholder rights plan intended to deter a hostile takeover.

LEAD: A 16-year-old student was arrested yesterday at his high school in Manhattan and charged with carrying a loaded .38-caliber revolver, and, in a separate incident, a 15-year-old student in the Bronx was charged with menacing a teacher with a fake gun, the police said.

LEAD: The smiling pictures of Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi, next to those of President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia, were still fresh on building walls weeks after the Libyan leader's third visit of 1988.


SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
LEAD:  Vietnamese Classics Nguyen Dinh Nghia, Uris Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art (206-1050).
Nguyen Dinh Nghia is a master of the sao, a Vietnamese bamboo flute.
Along with his family - two daughters and a son, who double as his band - he'll play transcriptions of classical European music on Vietnamese ethnic instruments.

LEAD: Accidents involving United States commercial air carriers and private airplanes killed 875 people in 1988, the lowest number this decade, Government figures indicate.

For Schultz, Bad News Is No News
LEAD: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has either had a vision or his standards are lower than the grade-point averages of some college athletes.
There is no logical explanation for Schultz's rose-colored state-of-the-N.C.A.A. address to the convention in San Francisco earlier this week, in light of the almost daily revelations of scandals in big-time college sports.


Art and Conscience Mix In King Observances
LEAD: There are some who argue that art and politics do not mix well, and some who insist that art unsupported by a political conscience is meaningless.
But there have always been statesmen whose principles have inspired not only those artists who see their work as part of a social force, but also those who prefer to think of art in more abstract ways.

Sorrow and Grace Mix As Pathologist Is Buried
LEAD: Dr.
Kathryn Hinnant and the son she was carrying were buried today beneath a stand of loblolly pines far from the Bellevue Hospital office in which she was killed five days ago.


Review/Violin; Webern Pieces By Rony Rogoff
LEAD: Certain aspects of Rony Rogoff's violin playing at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday evening were unusual and satisfying.
In a recital of Mozart, Beethoven, Webern and Franck, Mr.
Rogoff fought shy of the muscle-bound, cutting tone that is favored by many of his colleagues, shaped his lines with sensitivity, and thoughtfully matched his tone and vibrato to the expressive purpose of the phrase at hand.

Peru Rebels Kill 9 Policemen
LEAD: Left-wing rebels killed nine policemen Wednesday, raising the toll to 33 this month in a surge of violence as Peru's army retreats from the countryside.
Guerrillas of the Shining Path group shot dead five policemen and two civilians who had been traveling on a bus near the port city of Huacho in central Peru, and attacked a power station near the central city of Huaras and shot dead four policemen.

Accelerator Is Proposed for Making Bomb Material
LEAD: The Department of Energy could use a linear accelerator to produce tritium for nuclear weapons, a process that would be cheaper and safer and would produce less radioactive waste than a reactor, according to an unreleased Department of Energy study.

LEAD: THE United States economy is in the seventh year of expansion, and nothing lasts forever.


Review/Piano; Pogorelich, Dapper but Otherwise Recognizable
LEAD: Ivo Pogorelich has cleaned up his act a bit, sartorially speaking.
The Yugoslavian pianist, who made his annual recital appearance at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, used to look like a romantic punk.
This year, he was coifed and conventional in attire, although his slack posture and wan appearance still bespoke the matinee idol.

Facing a Big Job With Limited Tools
LEAD: President-elect Bush's choice for Secretary of Energy is being asked to lead one of the most complex and expensive environmental and rebuilding programs in history with only a fraction of the financial resources experts have said are needed to complete the work.


Chemical Net Rose 25.7% in 4th Quarter
LEAD: The Chemical Banking Corporation, one of the nation's largest banking companies, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 25.7 percent, bolstered by the receipt of past-due loan interest from Brazil.


Mayor Seeks Panel Records On Job Bank
LEAD: Reacting to a possible scandal in his own office, Mayor Edward I. Koch asked a state investigating commission yesterday to turn over to him its files on the how a City Hall agency handled job referrals from Democratic politicians.
The agency was supposed to place minorities and women in city jobs.


Angola Says Rebels Still Hold Border in Southeast
LEAD: Five months after South Africa and Angola agreed to jointly patrol Namibia's border, a 300-mile gap remains under the control of Angolan rebels supplied by South Africa, an Angolan Army officer asserted here today.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Museum is presenting these exhibitions, talks and concerts, all free with the suggested admission of $3 for adults, $1.50 for students and $1 for the elderly.
The museum, at 200 Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue, is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily except Tuesday.
Information: (718) 638-5000.

LEAD: There were 18 seconds remaining in tonight's game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
The Nets trailed the Boston Celtics by a point.
And Roy Hinson, New Jersey's forward, had the ball exactly where he wanted it: 12 feet from the basket in the lane.


GAF Loses Plea for Stay
LEAD: A two-judge panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday denied a request by the GAF Corporation and its vice chairman for a stay that would halt the selection of a new jury for a trial on stock-manipulation charges.
A judge this week declared a mistrial in their original trial.

This time she did not get what she wanted.

LEAD: The Republic Pictures Corporation and United Artists Communications Inc. have formed a joint venture to develop and produce television programs and have committed $60 million in the next five years to support it.

LEAD: Despite the involvement of minority officers in helping to prepare a new promotion examination for the New York City Police Department, 94.7 percent of the latest group of officers promoted to sergeant are non-Hispanic whites.

F.B.I. Is a Strange Hero for 'Mississippi Burning'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Small-Town Feeling on Brooklyn's Gold Coast
LEAD: Park Slope has a large collection of Victorian town houses, one of America's greatest urban parks and a grand arch unlike any this side of the Arc de Triomphe.
But perhaps the most notable hallmark of this central Brooklyn community is that, in many ways, it feels like a small, friendly college town.

LEAD: Universities glory in the study of feudalism, but where they truly excel is in the practice of it.

LEAD: Cathy Barrett's children hadn't been born when she wrote a letter to WGN-TV nine years ago, requesting tickets to ''The Bozo Show.'

LEAD: Inconsistencies of United States chemical weapons policy lie exposed by the unhappy conjunction of Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi's big new poison gas factory with Secretary of State George P. Shultz's cautious avoidance of specifics in his address to the Paris chemical weapons conference that ended Wednesday.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about a sedition trial in Springfield, Mass., cited the defendants' previous convictions incorrectly.
Two defendants, Raymond Luc Levasseur and Richard Williams, have been convicted on bombing charges; they have not been convicted of bank robbery.

LEAD: Sixteen American electronics companies, including several leading computer companies, are actively looking at banding together to get the United States into the emerging high definition television business.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today filed a sealed statement in Federal District Court buttressing the request by the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case to drop the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North, Government officials said.

LEAD: A Brooklyn elementary school principal who has been involved in a bitter community dispute was transferred yesterday to the District 16 office.


Bassett Foods To Fight Proposal
LEAD: The British maker of jellybabies, a popular gelatin candy, has vowed to fight a hostile takeover offer of $:63 million, about $112 million, from the Swedish company Procordia A.B.
Bev Stokes, the chief executive of Bassett Foods P.L.C., said the offer by Procordia, Sweden's 10th-largest business, badly undervalued the company.


McGirt's Hooks Halt DeLeon In Six
LEAD: Buddy McGirt, the former International Boxing Federation junior welterweight champion, stopped Manuel DeLeon last night at 29 seconds of the sixth round at the Felt Forum.


Bellevue Slaying: Gaps in Mental Care
LEAD: The arrest of a homeless man with a history of psychiatric illness in the murder of a pregnant doctor at Bellevue Hospital Center reflects a failure by New York City and State agencies to concentrate mental-health services on the most seriously ill, mental health care experts say.

LEAD: Michael V. Forrestal, an international lawyer and former Government official who frequently served as an intermediary seeking to improve relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, died of a ruptured aneurysm Wednesday.
He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The American fighter crews that shot down two Libyan warplanes last week used tactics developed through mock combat exercises that include missions against Soviet-built warplanes that have been obtained by Western intelligence agencies, a Pentagon official said today.

LEAD: A car bomb exploded in the western Afghan city of Herat, killing or wounding 20 people, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

Green Helps Out
LEAD: The uniforms of the Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team were stolen a few weeks ago.
When Sidney Green, the Knick forward who was a basketball star at the Brooklyn school 10 years ago, learned of the problem, he ordered a new set of 15 uniforms, costing about $2,500.
He will present the new outfits to the team today before the school's home game against Wingate High School.

LEAD: They may not displace baseball cards, but among political junkies ''Iran-Contra Scandal Trading Cards'' are gaining popularity.

Review/Film; In a Wet And Scary Place
LEAD: Even the fish lack personality in ''Deepstar Six,'' a film that makes the exotic undersea world not much more interesting than the average bedroom closet. ''Deepstar Six'' is supposed to take place six miles beneath the ocean's surface, but in fact it unfolds on a drab, colorless command-module movie set where the blinking lights on the control panels don't even blink very well.


On Nicaraguan Range, Assault Rifles for Hire
LEAD: There are signs that civil conflict in Nicaragua may be ending after six years, but those who feel nostalgic for the crack of rifle fire can indulge themselves just 15 miles from the capital.
Here anyone with cash can legally rent a rifle or a submachine gun for target practice.

Cruising to Louisville
LEAD: For Shug McGaughey and Easy Goer, these are the sweetest and easiest days of winter.


Valentin Glushko, 80, Rocket Pioneer For Soviet Program
LEAD: Valentin P. Glushko, who in the 1930's pioneered the development of Soviet liquid-fueled rockets, then played a prominent but secret role in Russia's postwar space program, has died at the age of 80, the Soviet press agency Tass announced yesterday.


Racial Differences Found in Care Heart Patients Obtain at Hospitals
LEAD: A team of researchers has found one of the strongest indications so far of racial differences in the kind of medical care Americans receive.
The researchers at Harvard University found that a significantly higher proportion of white people admitted to Massachusetts hospitals with heart problems undergo coronary bypass operations and cardiac catheterizations than do blacks.


Marietta Names Head Of Its Space Venture
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday named Edward M. Browne to lead its commercial space venture.


Bush Inaugural Will Signal Open, Accessible President
LEAD: President-elect George Bush's five-day inaugural gala is being packaged down to the last waltz to suggest an administration that will be more open and more engaged than President Reagan's.


Bear Stearns Has Record Profits in Quarter
LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that the quarter just ended was the most profitable in its history and announced that it planned to buy back 4 million of its shares outstanding.


Dollar Steady On Threat of Intervention
LEAD: The threat of further, coordinated central bank intervention held the dollar relatively steady yesterday.


Knicks Turn Up Defense And Roll Past Hornets
LEAD: In the same way the Hornets have awakened fans in Charlotte, N.C., to becoming a part of the National Basketball Association, they put the crowd to sleep in the second half last night at Madison Square Garden in a 106-89 loss to the Knicks.


Nominee for 'Drug Czar' Has Tough-Talking Past
LEAD: William J. Bennett, President-elect George Bush's choice to coordinate the Federal Government's battle against illegal drugs, has always spoken bluntly when he felt strongly about something, and the drug problem in the United States is something he feels strongly about.

Bridge; Post-mortem arguments tend to dominate partnerships after every duplicate event.

Editors' Note
LEAD: An article on Dec. 23 about Representative Manuel Lujan Jr., who has been selected as Interior Secretary, discussed his background, his record in Congress and the response to his selection.
In describing Mr.
Lujan's family, the article noted that he is a Roman Catholic.

LEAD: The birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday.
Below are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Closed.
Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.

Rockland Jury Hears Evidence In Murder Trial
LEAD: A Rockland County jury began hearing evidence today in the murder trial of 18-year-old Alonzo Williams, who shot his mother five times after, he said, she had sexually abused him since he was 6 years old.


New Limits Imposed On 376 Substances Found in Workplace
LEAD: The Labor Department today broadened its regulation of toxic and hazardous substances in the workplace, putting new limits on such substances as grain dust and gasoline fumes while strengthening existing limits on others.


String Band Festival
LEAD: The 1989 String Band Festival, at 8:30 and 11:30 tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880), will include the Nashville Bluegrass Band, Major Conte and the Canebrake Rattlers, Pat Cannon's Foot and Fiddle Dance Company and the Wretched Refuse String Band.
Tickets are $13.


Rushdie Novel Brings Bomb Threats
LEAD: Several anonymous bomb threats by telephone have been directed against the New York publisher of Salman Rushdie's new novel, ''The Satanic Verses,'' and thousands of threatening letters have been sent to the publishing house.

BENEFICIEARIES OF THE TALENT BANK
LEAD:  Highest-paid city workers hired through the Mayor's Talent Bank, a job-referral program operated out of the basement of City Hall, according to a list taken home in a shopping bag by Nydia Padilla-Barham, the program's former director.
List covers period between 1981 and July, 1985.
Salary is as reported in that list.


Asia Upset Over U.S. Quota Cuts
LEAD: Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong and other countries where Vietnamese boat people seek asylum are upset with President Reagan's decision to increase the number of Soviet refugees allowed into the United States at the expense of Southeast Asians, Thai officials and Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: Juan Samuel, a second baseman turned outfielder, has agreed to a two-year, $2.8 million guaranteed contract, the Philadelphia Phillies announced yesterday.
Samuel, 28 years old, who is moving from second base to the outfield this year, batted .243 in 157 games with 12 homers, 67 runs batted in and a club-high 33 stolen bases.(


Chip Maker Posts Loss
LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices, a semiconductor manufacturer, said today that it lost $34.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1988.
Sales in the quarter were $248.1 million, down 5.5 percent from $262.5 in the fourth quarter of 1987.

LEAD: An international group of scientists is planning to use satellite photography and other sophisticated computer-imaging techniques to aid searchers still looking for the remains of 28 passengers in the widely scattered wreckage of a Pan Am Boeing 747 in Scotland.

LEAD: There were indications yesterday that Ray Tellier, the head coach at the University of Rochester, would be appointed the next football coach at Columbia University.

LEAD: After three decades of welcoming Hispanic immigrants with open arms, officials here said today that Miami could not cope with the latest wave of Nicaraguans and had no jobs or housing for them.

LEAD: Copper futures prices rose sharply yesterday in reaction to reports of a disastrous explosion at the smelting operations of the world's largest copper mine near Chuquicamata, Chile.

LEAD: Citing social and political tensions in impoverished Latin America, the United States and other major industrial nations are trying to induce their commercial banks to lend the countries much more and to absorb some losses on loans they have already made, American officials and officials of other leading governments said.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Saving Indoor Plants
LEAD: Pots of gardenias, geraniums, African violets and ficus sit serenely near the window.
But look again.
When the heat is on, insects multiply indoors.
These minute nuisances often live their lives undetected until leaves turn yellow or drop, or the plant fails to thrive.
An arsenal of chemical weapons is not necessary to get the insects under control.


Central Banks' Action Drops Rates
LEAD: Interest rates continued to plunge yesterday, largely because of coordinated actions by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to reduce the dollar's value.


Patents; Preventing a Car From Rolling Over
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation received a patent this week for a computer-controlled system that anticipates the likelihood of a car to roll over and tries to prevent it.


Gordon Wright, 85, Riding Team Founder
LEAD: Gordon Wright, a noted horseman and riding instructor who helped establish the United States Equestrian Team after World War II, died Jan. 5 at a nursing home in Tryon, N.C.
He was 85 years old and had lived at Wright Way Farm outside nearby Landrum, S.C.


Sooner Lineman Shot
LEAD: Prosecutors in Norman, Okla., have charged Jerry Parks, a starting cornerback for Oklahoma, with shooting with intent to injure after a teammate was wounded during an argument in an athletes' dormitory early yesterday morning.


KEY NORTH COUNTS DISMISSED BY COURT
LEAD: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell today dismissed the main criminal charges against Oliver L. North in the Iran-contra case, saying he was ''totally powerless'' to try the two charges without classified documents the Reagan Administration had ordered withheld.

James E. Hurtubise, Race-Car Driver, 56
LEAD: James E. Hurtubise, a race-car driver who once held the average qualifying speed record for the Indianapolis 500, died Jan. 6 after suffering a heart attack near his home in Port Arthur, Tex.
He was 56 years old.

Mets-Padres Trade
LEAD: In a trade of minor leaguers, the Mets have traded Rich Rodriguez, a pitcher, to the San Diego Padres for Brad Pounders, a first baseman.
Pounders, 25 years old, hit .279 in 110 games for Class AAA Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League last season.
He had 14 home runs and drove in 74 runs.
Rodriguez, 25, a left-hander, was 2-7 with six saves and a 2.87 earned run average in 47 games with the Class AA Jackson Mets of the Texas League.(


Fire Damages 11 Businesses
LEAD: Eleven businesses were heavily damaged yesterday when a wind-whipped fire burned through the roof of a one-story row on upper Broadway, the Fire Department said.
Thirteen firefighters suffered minor injuries, but no one else was injured in the fire that was reported at 6:58 A.M.
The cause of the fire is under investigation, but was believed to have started in the Dyckman House restaurant, which has entrances both on Broadway and Dyckman Street, said a Fire Department spokesman, Joseph Addonizio.


All-Star Jazz Reunion
LEAD: Art Farmer on fluegelhorn, Clifford Jordan on tenor saxophone, the singer Chris Connor and many other musicians will perform at J's All-Star Jazz Reunion at 6 and 9 P.M. tomorrow.
J's is on the second floor at 2581 Broadway, above 98th Street; admission is $15, with a two-drink minimum.
Information: 666-3600.

Bareheaded Motorcyclists Pressed Anew to Cove Up
LEAD: While Gary Busey, the actor, recovers from head injuries caused by a motorcycle accident last month, legislators in several states are drawing attention to his case as they revive attempts to require motorcyclists to wear safety helmets.
The well-publicized accident has also given lawmakers and safety experts an opportunity to promote the use of helmets in many other recreational sports, like bicycling, skiing, skateboarding and roller-skating.

LEAD: Michael Chang, the 1988 rookie of the year in men's tennis, will join Andre Agassi, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso on the United States Davis Cup team, which will meet Paraguay in Fort Myers, Fla., Feb. 3-5.

LEAD: New York City, while sharply disputing the state's assertion that large amounts of garbage fly off the barges that travel to the city landfill on Staten Island, will begin placing covers over the barges next Tuesday.

LEAD: The developer Harry Macklowe, who illegally tore down four buildings in Manhattan in 1985, has started building a hotel on the site two years before he was supposed to because the New York City Council - apparently unknowingly - removed a ban on the construction.

Beuys and Warhol Still Set the Tone - Even After Death
LEAD: The two ubiquitous artists of the late 1980's are Joseph Beuys and Andy Warhol.
Beuys was featured in last year's inaugural exhibition of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and given prime place in the 1987 Documenta, whose theme was social and political art.
Warhol had a museum and gallery show in New York City last fall.


ETHICAL QUESTIONS THAT ARISE WHEN IT'S EASY TO DOCTOR IMAGES
LEAD: Want a photograph of Alf, the lovable TV space alien, presiding at your company's board of directors meeting?
Or how about the Eiffel Tower in the middle of the Manhattan skyline?
Such doctored photographs have always been possible, of course, through tedious cut-and-paste operations.
But the advent of still video photography, in which images can be stored in digital form in computers and manipulated on the screen, enables users to arrange tricks - or, more typically, to improve existing photos - at the touch of a button.

Review/Music; Organ Recital By German
LEAD: The centerpiece of Hans Uwe Hielscher's organ recital last Sunday afternoon at St.
Bartholomew's Church was a big four-movement sonata by the French Romantic composer Alexandre Guilmant.
Guilmant's name and some of his work are known to organists - he was a notable teacher, of Nadia Boulanger among others -but his music rarely turns up in recitals.


A Debate Heats Up: Is It News or Entertainment?
LEAD: After years of dancing around the edge of sensationalism, television leaped enthusiastically into the pit last year with the kind of journalism many newspapers have practiced for a hundred years or more.
The half-dozen or so new shows and the old ones that remade themselves on a sex-and-mayhem model proved so successful that they have spawned a multibillion-dollar industry: reality-based television.


A DEATH IN LENINGRAD
LEAD:  STALIN AND THE KIROV MURDER  By Robert Conquest.  164 pp.
New York:  Oxford University Press. $16.95.


Meaning Is in the Ears of the Beholder
LEAD: Pop musicians and their advisers slave to make themselves clear.
They agonize over lyrics, try dozens of takes on solos, mix and remix arrangements, scrutinize album packages, fiddle with advertisements and re-edit videos according to private combinations of game plan and instinct.
At some point in the project, they'll try to think like a casual listener, a radio program director or a longtime fan, all in attempts to guarantee that their initial inspiration comes through just the way they planned it.


Judge Rejects Boat Searches
LEAD: A Superior Court justice in Maine has ruled that game warderns' searches of boaters along the Saco River last summer were unconstitutional.
Game wardens conducting the searches cited rowdy and potentially dangerous behavior by some boaters.
But Justice Donald Alexander said there was ''no significant connection'' between the behavior the wardens sought to stop and the charges that were subsequently filed.


Spain, Losing Backward Image, Booms as It Lures Foreign Money
LEAD: With Europe's fastest economic growth rate and foreign investment that has tripled in five years, Spain is turning into the continent's Sun Belt.

LEAD: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators in Vienna announced an agreement today that cleared the way for the start of new negotiations on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe and for a major East-West document on human rights and economic cooperation.

The Strategy and Tactics Of Mothering a Sportsman
LEAD: ANYONE who has ever raised a boy knows that gym class is a metaphor for life.
Here in the sports arena of junior athletics, the boys are separated from the men, wimps are weeded out from winners and coach is a deity second only to the Highest Power.
I should know.
I'm a sports mother, dedicated to the care and feeding of the next lean, mean money machines: two young athletes in the making.

Frozen Pipes
LEAD: FREEZING winter weather brings with it the threat of frozen plumbing.
To minimize the risk, most household water pipes are deliberately situated away from unheated areas.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture.
However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years.
The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone.
I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent.
