LEAD: IT'S a jawbreaker of a word: xenodochiophobia.


NEW YORKERS, Etc.
LEAD: IF there are two overworked words in the English language at the moment, they must be ''kinder'' and ''gentler.'' Since President-elect George Bush chose them to convey his vision of the country and the future, they have filled newspaper columns and airwaves, have been sprinkled in countless conversations, have jumped out of advertisements and commercials and have been used in almost every context, with a grand disregard for accuracy.

The pressure to win: too great.

LEAD: In this drab industrial city on the Gulf Coast, the main supermarkets are owned by the Mexican oil workers union.

Fresh Herbs at Hand No Matter What the Season
LEAD: AS more companies go into the business of growing herbs hydroponically, various fresh herbs are now available all year.
A few sprigs of fresh thyme, rosemary or tarragon can be found in many produce markets, sealed in plastic.
In winter they usually cost $1.25 to $2 a package.

LEAD: DESPITE attempts to introduce modern, refined bread, the Portuguese by and large prefer the old-fashioned country kind, loaves that are big and rough and the color of earth, with crisp crust and a moist interior.

Hoping Selfishness Goes Out of Style
LEAD: I RECENTLY watched Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life'' for the eighth time.
As always, I was emotionally uplifted by the story, which paints good and evil in broad strokes, letting the former prevail.
But I was also saddened, for the movie highlighted a major failing of too many of my contemporaries - their need to measure success in terms of material wealth.

LEAD: Researchers at the University of Chicago say a new social survey of low-income inner-city residents here offers evidence of a strong correlation between unemployment among men and the growing number of children who are being reared by single mothers.

LEAD: Angel Antonio Sanchez-Cabanas turns away from the glare of Madrid's midday sun and leans his frame against a wall, the better to show off his garb.
He wears a snug-fitting toreador-style jacket, a black ribbon tie - the sort of thing that Zorro might have fancied - and a Mexican belt with a hand-tooled silver buckle.

LEAD: President Reagan, saying ''Saturdays will never seem the same,'' delivered his final weekly radio talk to the nation today, thanking the American people for the chance to lead them in pursuit of ''the American saga.''


Oklahoma Shooting
LEAD: The shooting of one Oklahoma football player by another was an accident after a series of arguments ''about stupid stuff,'' according to a third Sooner player who said he witnessed the incident early Friday morning.
Rod Fisher, a halfback, told The Daily Oklahoman that he was present when Jerry Parks, a freshman, shot Zarek Peters, a third-year lineman, during a scuffle in Peters's dorm room.

Correction
LEAD: A front-page contents listing on Dec. 18 for an article about Rio de Janeiro characterized the city incorrectly.
The capital of Brazil is Brasilia.

The concert is in a few weeks.


THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
LEAD: Marie Colvin's article ''The Ambiguous Yasir Arafat'' (Dec. 18), is accompanied by a large picture of Mr.
Arafat addressing the Palestine National Council in Algiers.
It was at this conference that he renounced terrorism.
In the picture, Mr.
Arafat is wearing army fatigues and has a large gun in a holster at his right side.

LEAD: An article about a municipal building getting a face lift appeared in The New York Times on the same day that Melvin Konner's Body and Mind article ''Mortality'' did (Dec. 4).
I doubt whether anyone would object to the ravages of time, weather and pollution being effaced from the building; one would rejoice, rather, that the landmark was being restored to its former splendor.


Evacuation Fears Unfounded
LEAD: Re: ''To the Reagans: Happy Trails''  [ Letters, Jan. 8 ] .
Those who read the papers and watch TV know that evacuation around a nuclear power plant in the event of emergency is required only for those within a 10-mile limit of the plant.
Physicists are confident only two miles is necessary because of the improved safety of our U.S.

L.I. Radio: Two Markets
LEAD: The article regarding Long Island radio  [ ''Radio Redux: Frequencies Are in Demand,'' Dec. 25 ]  was interesting but made a common mistake, namely, that Long Island radio is one market.
It is not.
It is two.
Nassau and western Suffolk is one and Long Island's East End is the other.
While Arbitron does not measure them separately, Birch Research does.

POSTINGS: Near Spring Lake; Basic Colonial
LEAD: The 65 houses of Old Mill Estates in Wall Township, N.J., will look so much like those from the 1790's that, if not for their obvious newness, they would seem straight out of the 1970's.
Their architect, Tom Schauvette, said that while the Colonial style, marked by shutters, shingles and simplicity, remains as popular in the 80's as in the 70's, such houses today usually are dressed up.

Woman Is Killed by a Train
LEAD: A 33-year-old woman was struck and killed Friday night by a Long Island Rail Road train as she walked along the tracks, the police said today.
The woman, Teresa Bustos, of 26A Town Path in Glen Cove, was walking on the tracks between Glen Street station and Seacliff station at 7 P.M.
Friday when she was struck by a westbound express train, said a police spokesman, Officer Frank Messana.

A Lesson of Sorts in Italian Geography
LEAD: IN Italy, La Sila is a lovely mountain in Calabria.
On Long Island, it's an Italian restaurant on a quiet street in Inwood.
A taste of La Sila's food is an instant lesson in Italian geography.
Robust red sauces all point to a restaurant whose heart and soul are near that mountain in the south of Italy.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We have been caring for our teak furniture by rubbing it periodically with an oil sold specifically for this type of unvarnished furniture.
However, the wood seems to have darkened over the years.
The other day I repaired the top of one piece, and I first cleaned off the surface with acetone.
I was amazed to see how clean and light the finish looked after cleaning it with this solvent.


THE CZARS NEVER HAD IS SO GOOD
LEAD: In 1770, eight years after she became Empress of Russia, Catherine the Great established the workshops that would lavishly and permanently furnish the imperial palaces.
Catherine's move gave birth to the Russian furniture industry - and the Russian style.
Antoine Cheneviere, a Swiss-born London antiques dealer specializing in Russian furniture, has written RUSSIAN FURNITURE: The Golden Age 1780-1840 (Vendome Press, $65), the first major book outside of the Soviet Union on the style as it evolved over a 60-year period.

LEAD: With President Alan Garcia seemingly overwhelmed by the challenges posed by wild inflation and mounting terrorism, Peru has been shaken over the last two weeks by intense rumors of an imminent military coup.

Burma Becomes a Test Case in Human-Rights Politics
LEAD: BURMA'S new military leaders paid dearly for their brutal crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations in September.
Not only were they shunned diplomatically, but nearly all the country's foreign aid - including $300 million from the Japanese, $100 million from the West Germans and $12 million from the United States - was suspended.

COLLEGE BASKETBALL: ISSUES AND ANSWERS By BILLY PACKER; Billy Packer is the principal college basketball analyst for CBS Sports. As a player, he led Wake Forest to the Final Four in 1962, and was an assistant coach there from 1965 to 1970.
LEAD: Despite the serious issues considered at the just-concluded National Collegiate Athletic Association convention and the recent controversy involving Jim Valvano and North Carolina State, I think the status of collegiate basketball has never been better.
The quality of coaching, the new rules that have dramatically improved the style and flow of the game, the incredible individual talent and the dozens of teams that can realistically set their sights on the national championship all combine to enhance the already grand expectations for the 1990's.

SPIES &amp; THRILLERS

Instant Snapshots for Your TV Screen
LEAD: For the consumer who has everything, a new toy will soon be beckoning.
It is the electronic still video camera, a device that looks like a bulky 35-millimeter camera but captures images on electronic sensors instead of film.
The images are then stored on built-in magnetic disks that can be played back with a machine connected to a TV.

Man Convicted in Cow Deaths
LEAD: A Bethel man on Wednesday was convicted of cruelty to animals for letting his cows starve to death and will spend nine days in prison, a court spokeswoman said Thursday.
The man, David Townsend, 46 years old, who is now a truck driver, had farmed for 20 years before the discovery of dead and dying cows drove him out of business.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Katmandu
LEAD: Katmandu, capital of a kingdom closed to all but a few official foreigners until 1951, has done a lot of catching up, particularly in the last decade.
While much of the country remains medievally rural, steeped in social traditions, religious customs and even superstitions established by centuries of practice, the outside world has made inroads all over Nepal, especially in the capital.

High-Tick
LEAD: MOST CENTURIES, IN ORDER TO compensate for the accumulated irregularities of measured time, the calendar skips a leap year Feb. 29.
There are watches complex enough to adjust for this.
However, at the turn of every fourth century (the year 2000 is one), the one leap year day must be reinstated, compensating for a slightly out-of-whack compensation.

LEAD: I can empathize with the anguish and frustration experienced by William and Joan Squadron.
My husband waited eight anxiety-ridden months for a desperately needed heart transplant, which he was lucky enough to receive last August.
He, like Joan, was running out of time, and we will be eternally grateful to an anonymous family in Cleveland, who offered John the gift of life in the midst of their grief.

The Homey Carpets Of County Cork
LEAD: IRELAND has its rains and winds; it also has some of their most effective antidotes.
Irish civilization at its best puts sufficient warmth inside the home to counter the deepest chills or damp.
The heat of a good peat fire penetrates; steaming tea and fresh wholemeal scones brace one against the elements.

THE AMBIGUOUS YASIR ARAFAT
LEAD: In her article, Marie Colvin writes, ''After 1967, when the Arabs lost the last inch of Palestine. . . .'' Our modern definition of Palestine is derived from the British Mandate on Palestine, which defines an area including Jordan and Israel as ''Palestine.'' Although it may hardly satisfy the Arabs on the West Bank, who want an independent state, the fact remains that there is an Arab Palestine - it is called Jordan.

LEAD: Six canoes slipped through the dark bayou waters under a full moon.

That early autumn night all celestial rays were blocked by thick clouds just blown in from the Gulf of Mexico.

At Long Last, dBase IV Arrives
LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation has finally completed dBASE IV version 1.0, the latest revision of the most popular data base program for personal computers.

LEAD: William Squadron's story of his wife's agonizing wait for a suitable heart-lung organ transplant surely emphasizes the critical need for donors (''Two Lives on Hold,'' Dec. 18).
One can only hope that thousands will respond by making the decision to become donors.
In signing up with a human-parts bank, it is also helpful for the donor to inform his physician and lawyer, as well as next-of-kin.


The Lost Voice
LEAD: AT 6 O'CLOCK ON A FRIDAY night, Dr.
Robert F. Ward waits for his last patient of the day.
She rushes into his office at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, in Manhattan, and croaks a greeting.
The patient is a singer who goes on stage in two hours - and she has laryngitis.
Dr.
Ward asks her to stick out her tongue; he grasps it with a piece of cotton gauze.

Question Of the Week; Can College Sports Play By the Rules?
LEAD: The N.C.A.A., like OPEC, is a cartel, and any economist will confirm that cartel members gain a competitive advantage by cheating on their fellow members.
Since no big-time coach willingly yields or fails to pursue an edge, cheating naturally inheres in big-time college sport.
It is one more way our major universities teach their students the futility of fairness and the wisdom of greed.

LEAD: This year my Christmas spirit did not make it well into the New Year.
It exploded into thousands of angry fragments on Christmas morning, when I read the article, ''Taxes Will Rise by Average of 9 Percent for Homeowners.'' To tell someone, whose tax burden is already approaching five figures, that his liability will be upped another big notch so as to pay $150-per-night hotel bills for the ''underprivileged'' is enough to create total outrage.

Trip Insurance
LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to warn Times readers about the amounts paid to a traveler who buys trip cancellation insurance.
The round-trip fare to Milan, for example, varies from as little as $400 to a high of about $660.
T.W.A. advertises round trip to Rome, which is farther, at $546.
These are restricted fares and are nonrefundable, noncancelable.

Now Vail is twice the area it was a year ago.
That's not just a figure of speech.
Vail this season has opened the China Bowl Expansion, a shorthand reference to the opening of four bowls (large, deep expanses of terrain mostly free of trees) on the back of the mountain - China, Teacup, Siberia and Mongolia - all made accessible by two new lifts.


Outdoor Trips for the Active
LEAD: Adventure travel is not for watchers but for doers.
For some travelers, simply leaving the tour bus behind and striking out on an independent itinerary is adventure enough.
For others, the destination is the adventure - China before it had Western-style tourist facilities certainly qualified, but fewer travelers would categorize it that way today.

LEAD: Pro golfers can make as much money as corporate sponsors are willing to put up in prizes.
That has been the theme of the PGA Tour under Commissioner Deane Beman: money, money, money.

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. we may think of his willingness to challenge the system of segregation or his denunciation of our Government's involvement in the Vietnam War or his determination to continue his nonviolent protests despite persistent death threats, or all of these.


Review/Music; Two Composers' Odes to St. Cecilia
LEAD: Music becomes a little self-conscious when called upon to describe itself, whether in Mozart's ''Impresario'' and the whole tribe of parody operas about how funny opera supposedly is or in the family of rhapsodies and apostrophes to which the odes to St.
Cecilia by Purcell and Handel belong.
The two most substantial of those composers' Cecilian offerings - Purcell's ''Hail, Bright Cecilia'' of 1692, with words by Nicholas Brady, and Handel's 1739 ode to verses by Dryden - were sung by Musica Sacra under Richard Westenburg, with an orchestra of period instruments, at Alice Tully Hall

Ms.
Zavatto, a graduate of Adelphi University and Teachers College of Columbia Univesity, is a physical education teacher at the Hewitt School in New York.

LEAD: Doctors at the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh have stopped performing multiple-organ abdominal transplants until they can find a better way of keeping the body from rejecting the organs.

On a Vacation
LEAD: VACATIONS, I've found, serve two purposes.
They let us shed the woes and cares we've been carrying with us for months.
They give us a chance to point ourselves in a new direction.

LEAD: On Friday night, the San Francisco 49ers' special teams got together for a Gutbuster Dinner.

Lynn Stiles, the special-teams coach, picked up the check.

LEAD: South Korea plans to cut its trade surplus with the United States by $2 billion in 1989 to help ease pressure from Washington to revalue the won, economic planning officials said last week.

Michael's Church (Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street), the group investigated Baroque territory already familiar to most period-instrument players - including, no doubt, this foursome, since all are active with other early-music ensembles.

A Nation Kicks a Habit
LEAD: The 1989 Surgeon General's report calls it ''phenomenal,'' and it surely is.
Nearly half of all living adults who ever smoked have quit.
In doing so they have kicked a habit responsible for more than one out of every six American deaths.
Surgeon General C. Everett Koop warns, however, that progress has to continue and accelerate or the health impact of smoking will remain into the 21st century.

Martin Luther King Day
LEAD:  NEW YORK  Government offices: Closed.
Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: Regular collections.
No street cleanings.
Schools: Closed.

LEAD: Policemen used riot sticks, dogs and water cannon today to crush a rally commemorating the death 20 years ago of a student who set himself afire to protest the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.


Major Hispanic Museum Lies Low and Likes It
LEAD: In a city teeming with vibrant cultural institutions, the Hispanic Society of America has chosen to go its own anachronistic way.
A magnificent cache of Spanish art and literature far from the busy museum-gallery scene of mid-Manhattan, it draws only 10,000 visitors a year, and its administration likes it that way.


Trade Arbitration Plan
LEAD: The European Community has given a cool response to a proposal made by a group of United States Congressmen to set up a bilateral panel to arbitrate trade disputes between the United States and the community.
A spokesman for the European Community's External Relations Commissioner, Frans Andriessen, said Friday that the community was more interested in strengthening the procedures of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based international trade body.

LEAD: Solar energy is used to heat some houses, and now the same technology is being used to produce warmth in ski wear.

LEAD: A United States subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. will end operations as a primary dealer of United States Treasury securities, the bank announced Friday, a little more than three months after the unit had gained approval to be a dealer from the Federal Reserve Board.

LEAD: Once again prime-time television entertainment is approaching the subject of AIDS through the case of a hemophiliac youth infected through a transfusion of tainted blood.

Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market.
The regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, normally held on Mondays, will take place tomorrow.
The Treasury cash market is closed today for the observance of Martin Luther King Day.

LEAD: President Reagan is expected this week to lift some prohibitions on American oil companies doing business in Libya to prevent theirlosing their assets in the country, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: ''Guys like to fight - it's like petting but it's hard and very fast,'' observes John O'Keefe in ''Shimmer,'' a rivetingly kinetic solo performance piece in which he remembers his troubled adolescence in Iowa in the mid-1950's.

LEAD: The Polish Communist Party begins a two-day conference on Monday that may lead to renewed contacts between the Government and the banned Solidarity trade union.


Taking On the Slopes (Sideways)
LEAD: TWO years ago, a skier riding sideways on a single, wide snub-nosed ski was a rare sight.
Most conventional skiers dismissed it as a fad.
Today, between 200,000 and 250,000 people are climbing onto snowboards and swiveling downhill, according to the North American Snowboard Association, the sport's governing body.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has given the developer Donald J. Trump permission to buy more shares of Caesars World Inc. stock.

The Biggest Wheel
LEAD: In Milltown, N.J., in 1940, Edward W. Bradley was chosen by his eighth-grade teacher to deliver Special Delivery letters around town for the local postmaster.
The only requirements were to get a bicycle and to report to the Post Office every morning at 6:30 sharp.
Mr.
Bradley recalled delivering hundreds of letters, receiving about 8 cents for each of them.

LEAD: For most of the last eight years, said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, ''there has been no bipartisanship'' in any area of foreign policy from strategic planning to state dinners.
He said ''Democrats are almost never invited'' to the dinners, ''which was not the case in the past.

No terms were disclosed.
The acquisition raises E.P.B.'s total billings past $300 million annually.
Ensslin &amp; Hall's major clients include GTE Mobilnet and The St.

LEAD: Almost three-quarters of the victims of violent crimes who survived to tell about it say they made some effort to protect themselves, and most believe their resistance was worthwhile, a Federal survey shows.

LEAD: Six members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries now have 70.5 percent of the world's proven oil reserves, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.


Grain and Soybean Prices Tumble
LEAD: Grain and soybean prices plunged yesterday, despite Government crop reports detailing sharply lower harvests caused by the drought last summer and the Soviet Union's announcement that its grain harvest had come up short as well.


National Semiconductor To Cut Work Force 5%
LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would reduce its worldwide work force by approximately 2,000, or about 5 percent of the total of 39,000.
In connection with this action, National said it would record a one-time restructuring charge in the third quarter of its 1989 fiscal year.

LEAD: It's not clear to what extent television molds social behavior.

Both partners deserve credit for the effort.

LEAD: Jerry Rice, generally regarded as the top receiver in the National Football League, suffered an injury to his right ankle in today's 49ers' practice and was listed as only 50-50 to be able to play in Super Bowl XXIII on Sunday.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's grain harvest last year fell 40 million tons short of the target of 235 million tons, according to preliminary estimates, a Soviet offical said today.

LEAD: The Damon Corporation ended its seven-month struggle for independence today and agreed to be acquired by Nomad Partners L.P. in a deal valuing the chemical laboratory company at more than $250 million.

British Sales Decline
LEAD: Britain's retail sales fell by a tenth of a percent in December from November, the Government reported today.
Retail sales had fallen six-tenths of a percent in November.
But retail sales were up 5.2 percent on a year-to-year basis in December, the Department of Trade and Industry said.


Mitsubishi Metal
LEAD: The Mitsubishi Metal Corporation said it would build a $250 million copper smelter in Texas City.
The plant will employ about 250 people and generate an estimated $5 million annual payroll, the company said.
The plant is expected to be in full operation in 1991 and will produce about 150,000 metric tons of copper a year.

Merciless Texas Justice
LEAD: One reason Texas leads the nation in executions is the peculiar way Texas law makes it hard for juries to grant mercy.
The case of a convicted rape-murderer, Johnny Penry, argued before the Supreme Court last week, exposes the law's unfairness and forces the justices, who have upheld the law in principle, to confront its operation.

LEAD: Fred Goldsmith, the new Rice football coach, said yesterday that he is facing the most challenging job in college football.

He replaces Jerry Berndt, who resigned Dec. 28 to accept the head coaching job at Temple.
The Owls finished last season 0-11 and have the nation's longest losing streak of 18 losses.

Cable Company Drops CVN Bid
LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., one of the nation's largest cable-television concerns, said it had withdrawn its offer to buy the CVN Companies for $14 a share in cash and a $4 note.
The offer, made in November, had been valued at about $313 million.
Tele-Communications, based in Denver, said it had withdrawn the offer because CVN's stock price on Friday, $18.50 a share, exceeded its bid.

LEAD: THIS fall, in what has become a case study in the sociology of science, William A. Goddard 3d, a chemist at the California Institute of Technology predicted that the new copper oxide superconductors would never work at room temperature.

NEW WIRE FAULTS FOUND ON 2 JETS
LEAD: Two more Boeing 757 jetliners have been found with crossed wires leading to cargo hold fire extinguishers, bringing to five the number of planes found with wiring problems since compulsory checks began on Friday, The Times of London reported today.

Unisys to Display A New Computer
LEAD: The Unisys Corporation said it would introduce this week the first model in a new line of computers.
The new desktop model will have the power of minicomputers and mainframe computers, the Blue Bell, Pa., company said.
It said it was able to shrink the size of its A-series machines through the use of a new processor called the Scamp.

Alexander Hahn Postwar Investigator, 92
LEAD: Alexander Hahn, who headed a mission after World War II that sought to locate and return Hungarian property taken by the Nazis, died of arterial sclerosis on Dec. 29 at the Forest Hills Nursing Home in Queens.
He was 92 years old.

LEAD: Nearly half of a group of professional baseball players who used snuff or chewing tobacco regularly had lesions in their mouths, researchers said today.


Hoechst Celanese
LEAD: The Hoechst Celanese Corporation, the American subsidiary of Hoechst A.G. of West Germany, said it would offer to acquire all the shares of Celanese Canada Inc. that it does not own in a deal valued at $210 million (Canadian), or about $175 million (United States).
Hoechst Celanese owns about 56.2 percent of Celanese Canada and is offering to buy each of the remaining shares for $35 (Canadian), or about $29 (United States).

Scientists Race to Explain How the New Superconductors Work
LEAD: IN the quest to find superconductors that work at higher and higher temperatures, scientists have been frustrated by the fact that they really don't know what in the name of physics is going on.
There was little reason to expect that the new materials, which are not metals but ceramics, would conduct electricity at all, much less that they would do so without losing any energy to resistance.

McDonnell Order
LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said China Eastern Airlines had agreed to buy five MD-11 jetliners in an order valued at more than $500 million.

Its main competitor is the Airbus A340, produced by the European consortium Airbus Industrie.

Jackson said, not a Republican event but an event for the republic.

LEAD:  FIGURE SKATING  Zander Pulls Off Upset: Richard Zander, an American-born West German who almost quit last year because of a back injury, upset the Soviet favorite, Aleksandr Fadeev, to win the men's compulsories at the European championships yesterday in Birmingham, England.
Zander, who was born in Portland, Ore., and grew up in Los Angeles, gained top marks in both figures with a superb display of technical skating and swept into the lead on the first day of the tournament.

LEAD:  Hence  By Brad Leithauser  320 pages.
Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
In Brad Leithauser's ambitious new novel, the year is 1993 and Americans are suffering from ''millennial neuroses.'' Trends already in evidence in our own day have accelerated.
Changes in the weather heighten everyone's worst environmental fears, and the nation's desperate craving for some kind of order or faith is exploited by evangelists who preach apocalyptic doctrines of blood and sacrifice on television.

New National Coach
LEAD: The United States Soccer Federation yesterday announced the appointment of a full-time coach for the national team.
He is Bob Gansler, a staff coach with the federation since 1975 and the head coach soccer coach at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee since 1984.
Gansler replaces Lothar Osiander, who had coached the United States national team on a part-time basis since 1986, including in the 1988 Olympics.

Diners Stabbed, Waiter Held
LEAD: A waiter angered by the small tip left by two customers was arrested after he allegedly attacked them with a knife, the police said today.
Guang Da Shen,19 years old, of Brooklyn, was charged with two-counts of assault after the incident Saturday night outside the Dragon House Restaurant.
Louis Pabian, 59, of Trumbull, was stabbed in the abdomen, and his son, Neil, 24, of Bridgeport, was cut in the hand, They had left a $2 or $3 tip on a bill of less than $50, the police said.

Exchange Seat Record
LEAD: A membership seat on the New York Mercantile Exchange has been sold for a record $267,500, the exchange said yesterday.
A seat on the 116-year-old exchange sold for $265,000 Monday, and two seats garnered $260,000 apiece on Friday.
The exchange's chairman, Lou Guttman, attributed the rising prices to the Mercantile Exchange's agreement in principle this month to join the Globex system - the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's planned after-hours electronic trading network.

Business Inventories Rose 0.4% in November
LEAD: Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November and sales rose at the same pace, the Government said today in a report that analysts said bodes well for the nation's economy.


Hospital Neglected to Notify Family of a Man Who Died
LEAD: The body of an 81-year-old man who died in a Queens hospital nine days after he was in a car accident was sent to the morgue for burial in a common grave because his relatives were not called, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.


Sen. Gordon Allott, 83, Pushed for Water Projects
LEAD: Former United States Senator Gordon Allott, who during 18 years in the Senate helped push through water projects instrumental to the economic development of Colorado and Arizona, died of cancer today.
He was 82 years old and lived most of his life in Englewood.

Their offense collapsed in the fourth quarter.
They were struggling against the San Antonio Spurs (10-26), a team the Nets shouldn't lose to at home.

LEAD: Michael Jordan, held to 11 points for three quarters, erupted for 11 fourth-period points and dished off 13 assists tonight to help lead the Chicago Bulls to a 103-96 triumph over the Indiana Pacers.

LEAD: Alvin Davis agreed to a three-year, $4.45 million contract with the Seattle Mariners yesterday.
Shawon Dunston, Zane Smith, John Cerutti, Neil Allen and Al Nipper agreed to one-year contracts.
Davis, who made $922,500 in 1988, will get $1.25 million in 1989, $1.425 million in 1990 and $1.725 million in 1991.

Review/Theater; A Fictional Bert Lahr In Crisis
LEAD: A famous clown named Max Luck is in Florida rehearsing a role in an avant-garde tragicomedy (very much like ''Waiting for Godot''), and his insecurity in the play sends him into a swirl of memories about his early days in vaudeville.
For many years, he and his partner, Maxie (later his first wife), had been struggling troupers.

Cooking Classes Come to the Family
LEAD: PEOPLE who make a living in the food business certainly have an obligation to teach their children how to cook.
Right?
Well, I tried.
Heaven knows I tried.
After both of my children, who are five years apart in age, had gone through the licking-the-bowl-and-the-eggbeater stage and had shown an interest in how to make the stuff that was clinging to both bowl and beater, I was happy to instruct.


The Pop Life
LEAD:  Tallying the Hits ''My image is that I have no image except that of an everyday person,'' Debbie Gibson said the other day. ''When I first signed with Atlantic Records, the people I was working with said I had to have one.
They thought I should look older.
But I asked why.
I pointed out that guys in the business don't have to have an image, and that's one reason why they get taken more seriously.

Texas Eastern
LEAD: The shares of the Texas Eastern Corporation, which on Monday received a $2.6 billion takeover bid from the Coastal Corporation, rose yesterday as investors apparently believed that another bidder would emerge.
The oil and gas pipeline operator's stock rose $1.375, to $46.375, higher than the $42-a-share offer from Coastal.


How the Balloting Went
LEAD: The results of two ballots on Proposition 42, an amendment to the N.C.A.A. bylaw popularly known as Proposition 48.
Proposition 42 would tighten academic requirements for an athletic scholarship.
The first vote was Jan. 10, with the proposition being defeated by 159-151.
On a second vote, on Jan. 11, the proposition was passed, 163-154.


It's a Disgrace! Moscow's Warmest January in 100 Years
LEAD: Add winter to the list of current items in deficit in Moscow.
With chickens and soap disappearing from store shelves and service stations empty of gasoline, Muscovites are finding that even cold weather is hard to come by.

Review/Theater; Medieval Mystery Plays, As Performed to Music
LEAD: Handed down through centuries, the Medieval Mystery Plays are a native folk art in England, France and Germany.

Farley Expects Shift by Pepperell
LEAD: The chairman of Farley Industries said he believed that West Point-Pepperell Inc.'s executives would change their hostile stance toward Farley's $48-a-share offer before a special shareholders meeting on Feb. 25.


Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Upholds California Redistricting
LEAD: Ending a decade-long legal battle over Congressional redistricting in California, the Supreme Court ruled today that the district lines drawn after the 1980 Census did not amount to unconstitutionally partisan gerrymandering.


Nova Scotia Yield at 9.51%
LEAD: The Province of Nova Scotia priced $200 million worth of long-term bonds yesterday through a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: Carl M. Spero, retired president of the Spero-Whitelaw Company, Manhattan insurance brokers, died of pneumonia on Monday at New York Hospital.
He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

McTear Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Houston McTear, a former record-holder in the 100-yard dash when world records were recognized in that event, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of selling cocaine and will be sentenced in Santa Monica (Calif.) Superior Court Jan. 31.
McTear was arrested by the Santa Monica police last fall and charged with selling cocaine in a park.


Marriott in Venture With Soviet Airline
LEAD: The Soviet airline Aeroflot and the Marriott Corporation announced a venture to supply about 10,000 meals a day to Aeroflot passengers.
The catering operation would be the first in the Soviet Union to involve a Western concern, the companies said.


Columbia Fellows to Include Soviets
LEAD: Columbia University will establish a graduate fellowship program next fall in American and international studies with students from the United States, the Soviet Union and four other countries, school officials say.

LEAD: As President Reagan prepares to leave office this week, two-thirds of the American people approve his performance over the last eight years, the highest rating given any President at the end of his term since World War II.

He was 65 years old.


Petoskey Journal; One Victim Fights a Rare Disorder
LEAD: Nancy Whitmore Sando's muscles began slowly turning to bone when she was 5 years old.
Now at 29, she is almost completely paralyzed, the victim of an extremely rare genetic disorder, Fibrodisplasia ossificans progressiva.

Mr. Meese's Disgrace
LEAD: The difference between escaping indictment and vindication has long eluded Edwin Meese.
He claimed vindication when one special prosecutor failed to indict him, thus clearing the way for his confirmation as Attorney General.
He claimed vindication again last summer when another special prosecutor declined to file criminal charges.


U.S. Note and Bond Prices Slip
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped modestly in light trading yesterday, as market participants awaited this morning's release of the latest figures on the United States trade deficit.


Trade Parley Falls Through
LEAD: In a bid to defuse trade tensions, United States and European Community officials tried last week to set up a secret meeting in Bermuda, European diplomats and American officials said today.
But no meeting was held because of scheduling conflicts.


Correction
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Lotus Development Corporation misstated the circumstances under which Mitchell Kapor, its founder and chairman, left the company.
Mr.
Kapor said he left in July 1986 because he was unhappy with his work.
He did not start another company until late 1987.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about self-service baggage carts at Kennedy International Airport misstated the salaries of skycaps who also help carry passengers' luggage.
They earn $19,000 a year plus tips, not $14,000.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about foreign reaction to Emperor Hirohito's death misidentified a South Korean official who visited the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to sign a book of condolences.

LEAD: William F. Redfield, a retired grocery executive and former president of the Hills Brothers Company, died Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J., after a long illness.
He was 94 years old.

LEAD: Military use of biotechnology threatens to create a biological arms race that will disrupt recent efforts at international arms control, a panel of scientists said today.

LEAD: The nation's ability to produce steel will increase this year after declining for seven years, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Monday.

LEAD: A private commission today reported a ''dramatic decline'' in civil rights enforcement by the Federal Government under the Reagan Administration and urged that President-elect George Bush appoint a Cabinet-level group ''to deal with the causes and results of bigotry and prejudice.''

Five Children Killed As Gunman Attacks A California School
LEAD: A young drifter dressed in military fatigues opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle at children playing outside and others inside an elementary school today.
Five children between 6 and 9 years old, all of them refugees from Southeast Asia, were killed and more than 30 people were wounded, about half of them critically, before the gunman shot himself to death.

LEAD: Poland's Communist Party approved a complex plan early today that if accepted would lead to the legalization of the outlawed Solidarity labor union.

RESULTS PLUS

Klimova and Ponomarenko have never won a major event, having been runners-up in eight previous world, Olympic and European championship appearances.

Bridge
LEAD: If you watch a declarer win the first trick and then see him start to think, you can safely assume he is not an expert.

Crude Oil and Gasoline Rise; West Texas Contract Climbs
LEAD: Crude oil and gasoline futures prices posted strong rises again yesterday, building on recent bullish momentum.
Prices tailed off late in the day, however, amid profit taking.


Dancing At the Bottom
LEAD: I once went to an Inaugural Ball.


Accord in Death of Girl Who Made Peace Trip
LEAD: The mother of Samantha Smith, a Maine schoolgirl who visited the Soviet Union on a peace mission at the invitation of the Soviet head of state, has settled a $50 million lawsuit she filed after the girl and her father died in a plane crash, a lawyer said today.


Hugh D. McCandless, 81, Ex-Rector of Church
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Hugh Douglas McCandless, rector emeritus of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany at York Avenue and 74th Street in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Hamden, Conn.
He was 81 years old.


Koch Rebuffed in Bid for Inquiry Data
LEAD: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity yesterday refused to provide Mayor Edward I. Koch with confidential information gathered during its investigation of the Mayor's Talent Bank.


Putting Data at Your Fingertips
LEAD: Stephen A. Rondel stood amid a small crowd with a strange contraption in his hand, speaking slowly into a microphone. ''I would like . . . to go . . . to the . . . airport,'' he said in a monotone voice.
Then, he added, ''Translate.''

How to Obtain State Budget
LEAD: Copies of the 1990 New York State Budget, which run about 700 pages, are bing sold to the public for the first time.
The cost to the state is $20 per copy, but they will be sold for $10 each, and 3,000 copies are available.
Legislators, libraries and journalists will still receive free copies.
To obtain a copy, send $10 to Paul Fisk, Budget Services Unit, Room 117, State Capitol, Albany, N.Y., 12224.


Garrison Makes Comeback And Moves to Third Round
LEAD: Sixth-seeded Zina Garrison came back in the final set to beat Sandra Wasserman of Belgium, 7-6, 4-6, 6-4, today and advance to the third round of the Australian Open tennis championships.


Confusion Renewed Over Pill and Risks
LEAD: CONCERNED and confused, sometimes angry or, by now, numb to bad news about breast cancer: that is how gynecologists are describing patients' reactions to three recently released studies linking prolonged exposure to the estrogen in oral contraceptives with increased risk of breast cancer.


Australian Dollar Offering by Unisys
LEAD: The Unisys Financial Corporation priced a $75 million (Australian) note offering.


Mayors Hopeful on Homeless
LEAD: The nation's mayors expressed guarded optimism today that the problems of homelessness and hunger in the cities had finally stabilized.


Justice Dept. Assails Meese
LEAD: The Justice Department's ethics office said yesterday that if Edwin Meese 3d were still Attorney General he should be subjected to Presidential discipline.


Budget Plan Burdens New York City, Its Officials Say
LEAD: New York City officials, citing the new burdens they would shoulder for education and medical care, said today that Governor Mario M. Cuomo had underestimated how onerous his proposed budget would be to the city.
They vowed to lobby for major changes in the budget.


Lessons
LEAD: Most societies have some sort of rite of passage from childhood to adulthood.
The aborigine in Australia send adolescents into the wilderness on a ''walkabout.'' German noblemen prove their maturity by acquiring dueling scars.


Kissinger Relays Bush's Ideas On Relations to Gorbachev
LEAD: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met Mikhail S. Gorbachev today and relayed some ideas about Soviet-American relations from President-elect George Bush, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.


IRAQ SAID TO STUDY BIOLOGICAL ARMS
LEAD: Iraq is developing biological weapons, including arms that can spread typhoid, cholera and anthrax, Government officials said tonight.

The New Voodoo, Made Fairer
LEAD: Commendably, President-elect Bush wants to stretch the dismally short investment horizons of American business.
Not at all commendably, he thinks that cutting the tax on capital gains is a sensible way to do that.
He urged that new form of voodoo economics during the campaign, and it is now said to be high on a list of contemplated fixes.


Intel's Net Down in Quarter
LEAD: The Intel Corporation, a leading maker of computer chips, reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings had dropped 10.2 percent from a year ago.
The company cited a decline in demand for its 80386 microprocessor, reflecting inventory buildup by personal computer manufacturers.


EATING WELL
LEAD: AFTER a dinner at your favorite restaurant in which nearly every dish is served with a sauce enriched with cream, butter or both, you may find it difficult to believe that the chef has heard of the dangers of cholesterol.


Paul Sheatsley, 72; Pioneer and Leader In Opinion Research
LEAD: Paul Baker Sheatsley, a retired research director who was a well-known authority in public opinion polling, died of emphysema Sunday at Little Company of Mary Hospital in Chicago.
He was 72 years old and lived in Chicago.


Rules on Tranquilizer Prescriptions Don't Harm Confidentiality; Bottleneck in Refills
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Now, No Changes in Prescribing Methods
LEAD: DOCTORS at most family-planning groups and student health clinics surveyed said they did not plan to change guidelines for prescribing contraceptive pills in the wake of three new studies linking the pills with increased risks of breast cancer.

Review/Television; Diary of a Rain Forest and Its People
LEAD: Phil Agland lived with the Baka in their tiny villge deep in a rain forest in southeastern Cameroon while making ''Baka: People of the Forest,'' and it shows.
His close-in view of the day-to-day lives of the seminomadic Pygmy tribe awakens thoughts of our common humanity.
The appealing National Geographic documentary can be seen at 9 P.M.

Serious Ethics Breaches by Meese Are Found in Justice Dept. Study
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that Edwin Meese 3d violated government ethics codes so seriously when he was Attorney General that if he were still in office he should be subjected to Presidential discipline.


Awaiting the Corrugation of a New President


Review/Dance; Isadora Duncan's Legacy
LEAD: One of the most amazing theatrical illusions is spontaneity.
Isadora Duncan, the great pioneer of modern dance, must have known how to create it, for she so enthralled audiences that many assumed her choreography was improvised.
But the dances by Duncan preserved by her disciples after her death in 1927 are as precise in form as they are eloquent in content.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about bank earnings misstated the closing price of the stock of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
It closed at $30.875, up 62.5 cents.


Bush's Domestic Policy Team Is All Set, but Not the Agenda
LEAD: George Bush ascends to the Oval Office this Friday having made a broad set of domestic policy promises: to clean up the environment, fight drug abuse, improve education and make day care more affordable for the poor.

An Executive Director Is Chosen at Bellevue
LEAD: The executive director of the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst was named the executive director of the Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday.

L.F. Rothschild Withdraws As a Key Treasury Dealer
LEAD: L.F.
Rothschild &amp; Company said yesterday that it had withdrawn as a primary dealer in United States Treasury securities.
It cited difficult business conditions and questionable short-term prospects.

Check of Ski Lifts Is Ordered After Cracks Appear in Chairs
LEAD: State officials have ordered nine ski resorts to inspect ski lifts immediately after cracks were found in a chairlift.


Raise for Galarraga
LEAD: Andres Galarraga tripled his salary yesterday and Bobby Bonilla, Joe Hesketh, Wes Gardner and Kevin Mitchell doubled their paychecks.
Galarraga and the Montreal Expos agreed to a one-year contract for $865,000, an increase from the $240,000 he made in 1988.
Bonilla and the Pittsburgh Pirates agreed to a one-year contract for $730,000, a $485,000 raise.


Bush to Meet U.N. Chief
LEAD: President-elect George Bush has invited Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to a small dinner party at the White House next Tuesday evening, officials said today.

Talking Deals; How Zeckendorf Filled a Tower
LEAD: WHERE crowds once roared at the previous Madison Square Garden, between 49th and 50th Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, workers are putting the finishing touches on an office tower and residential complex that pushes the midtown cluster of high-rises and white-collar workers into a neighborhood best known for pornography and cheap bars.


Lotus to Offer PC Software
LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that it would introduce a new kind of utility software designed to help personal computer users organize and retrieve information stored in computer files, including spreadsheets, word processing documents and data base files.


Bengals' Krumrie Carries the Load
LEAD: Most football players train by lifting weights. Tim Krumrie lifts an anvil.


Bridge
LEAD: Every beginner is taught to select a four-four major suit fit rather than play in no-trump.
There are rare exceptions, and it is possible to have hands with a five-four fit on which no-trump is preferable.
But eschew a five-five major suit fit?
Never.

Gasoline Demand and Oil Price Rise
LEAD: The price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil climbed to $19.26 a barrel yesterday, its highest level since November 1987.
The 31-cent increase in the spot contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange was spurred in large part by sharply higher gasoline prices.


King Says He Signed 2 Contracts with Tyson
LEAD: While making a deposition in Mike Tyson's suit to void the contract of his manager, Bill Cayton, Don King was glum in the morning, loquacious in the afternoon and thunderingly irate at the close of the proceedings.


At Library, a Room for the Homeless
LEAD: WHEN the new public library in Haverhill, Mass., opens in 1992, it will include a room designed specifically for homeless people.
The 60,000-square-foot library is part of a civic center, shown above, being designed by Mark Mitchell Associates of Hanover, N.H.
Haverhill is in the northeastern part of the state.


Lebanon Foes to Aid Arab League Mediators
LEAD: Leaders of rival Christian and Muslim Cabinets have agreed to cooperate with the Arab League in an effort to prevent the formal partition of Lebanon, officials reported today.


Jaruzelski Said He'd Quit If Party Rejected His Gesture to Solidarity
LEAD: Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski and other Polish leaders threatened to resign to force the adoption of a resolution opening the way for legalization of the Solidarity trade union, a Government press agency report said late Wednesday.


RABIN AT CENTER OF ISRAELI STORM
LEAD: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin walked out of a stormy debate in Parliament today after opposition members heckled him about increased bloodshed in the occupied territories and demanded that he resign.


Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: EVERYONE in the Miller household admits that living the past eight months under one roof has taken some adjusting.

LEAD: Boris Becker, playing his first outdoor match in four months, breezed past Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 7-5, 6-1, 6-3, today to advance to the third round of the Australian Open.


Federal Judge Acting to Settle Lilco Suit Case
LEAD: The Federal judge presiding over the racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company has intensified pressure on the representatives of the utility, its customers and Suffolk County to fashion a settlement that could lead to the closing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


Gorbachev Promises Big Cut in Military Spending
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told a visiting Western delegation today that the Soviet Union will reduce its military budget by 14.2 percent and cut production of weapons and military hardware by 19.5 percent.

Apple Offers New Computer
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. introduced the Macintosh SE/30 today, a new computer that packs much of the power of the top-of-the-line Macintosh IIX into the smaller housing of the original Macintosh.


Woman Gets Top News Job At Knight-Ridder
LEAD: Jennie Buckner, a senior editor of The San Jose Mercury News, is to leap into the corporate hierarchy of Knight-Ridder Inc. on July 1 when she assumes responsibility for the news and editorial content of the Knight-Ridder chain's 12 largest newspapers and its Washington bureau.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the New York State budget misstated the total spending proposed by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo for the coming fiscal year.
It is $46.6 billion, not $46.4 billion.

Problems on Shuttle Resolved
LEAD: Engineers have resolved the tile and engine problems of the last space shuttle flight, and the launching of the next shuttle has been set for Feb. 23, the Kennedy Space Center director said today.
Forrest S. McCartney said damage to tiles on the shuttle Atlantis on its secret mission last month was caused by insulation that hit the shuttle in liftoff.


In London, a Showcase for Italian Design
LEAD: The richly colored metaphysical paintings of Giorgio de Chirico fill an entire gallery in the new exhibition ''Italian Art in the 20th Century,'' which opened Saturday at the Royal Academy of Art here.


Holiday Glow Won't Go Away
LEAD: Christmas decorations still glow each night in downtown Delano because the Chamber of Commerce does not have the money to store them and pay for insurance.
The lights have been plugged into city light poles since mid-November, so they turn on automatically every evening. ''It's very embarrassing to me,'' the chamber manager, Dorothy Knight, said Monday.

Reagan in Retrospect, on 'Frontline'
LEAD: ''Frontline'' bids farewell to the Reagan era tonight with a 90-minute exploration of ''The Real Life of Ronald Reagan.'' The title hints at a theme of Garry Wills's narration -that Mr.
Reagan's own view of his career and the world often owed more to memories of the movies he played in or watched than to reality.


Is That in Ohio?
LEAD: One of the many perils of testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is pronunciation.
More than one official has made himself look silly in years past by stumbling over the names of people and places in remote lands like Iran or Laos or Liechtenstein.


U.S. Again Reports Libyan Role in Terrorism
LEAD: The United States asserted today that Libya continues to support terrorism around the world and is using foreign surrogates to strike Western targets.


Syracuse Mourns Students Killed on Flight 103


When Chest Pains Have Nothing to Do With a Heart Attack
LEAD: Severe, crushing pain in the chest is often a warning of an imminent heart attack, but in tens of thousands of people this frightening symptom has nothing to do with heart disease, scientists have concluded on the basis of new studies.


Berlin Wall Aids Peace, East Bloc Powers Assert
LEAD: The Soviet Union and East Germany today rejected Western calls for the destruction of the Berlin wall, saying it must stay in place for the time being.

Review/Cabaret; Hildegarde, Still Kinetic
LEAD: ''The Incomparable Hildegarde,'' as this singer from Milwaukee has been billed for many years, is now, at the age of 83, not only beyond comparison but is seemingly unquenchable.
In the new cabaret room Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, she is singing, playing piano, bouncing around the tiny stage and expending enough energy to exhaust someone half her age.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Most of the time my toilet flushes fine, but occasionally the water swirls around and won't flush completely.
In fact, sometimes the water keeps rising until it almost reaches the rim of the bowl.
The ballcock inside the tank is adjusted properly and the flapper valve is working fine.
There is no leakage.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Rally
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged a rally in active trading yesterday, bolstered by the dollar, which rose despite a trade report that showed the merchandise trade deficit widening substantially in November.


32 Are Killed and 41 Injured In Chinese Bus-Train Crash
LEAD: At least 32 people were killed and 41 injured when a passenger train hit a crowded bus in northeastern China, the New China News Agency reported today.


ARCO Offering
LEAD: ARCO said it expected to receive up to $1.38 billion in proceeds from its 40-million-share initial public offering of the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, which was priced today at $30 a share.
As part of the offering proposal, Lyondell paid ARCO a $500 million dividend on Tuesday.
The stock will be offered for sale beginning Thursday through the offering's underwriters, Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company and Salomon Brothers Inc.

Julian L. Greifer, Sociologist,87

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about risks and benefits of the female sex hormone estrogen misidentified the group of women in which the incidence of breast cancer is increasing most rapidly.
It is those over age 50.

Many Species Are Still Threatened Despite Law, U.S. Agency Reports
LEAD: The Federal program that is supposed to protect threatened plants and animals is fraught with problems, the General Accounting Office reported today, and a third of the 500 species listed as in peril continue to fade toward extinction.


U.S. Says It Has Tape of Arafat Threat
LEAD: Despite denials that Yasir Arafat had made any threats, the State Department said today that it had a tape recording by the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman made on New Year's Day that amounted to a threat to moderate Arabs and strayed from Mr.
Arafat's commitment to renounce terrorism.

LEAD:  Nine Days of Antiques, Seventh Avenue Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-665-5250.

Trump Gets Initial Approval to Acquire Eastern's Shuttle
LEAD: The Department of Transportation, after reviewing the financial and managerial fitness of Donald J. Trump to run an airline, gave its initial approval today for the New York real estate developer to buy the air shuttle operations of Eastern Airlines.


Pacific Gas Has Big Loss
LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported today that it lost $487.1 million in the fourth quarter.


Roberts and 49ers Become Stronger
LEAD: It would not be fair to say that Larry Roberts was being pushed around a season ago.
He was in his second season as a defensive end with the San Francisco 49ers, primarily responsible for an outside rush in passing situations, when injuries suddenly necessitated a new role and created extenuating circumstances.


Nissan Establishes U.S. Finance Unit
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company of Japan said it had established a financial subsidiary in New York that would complement those in London and Tokyo.
The unit will give the auto maker 24-hour access to global financial markets.


Gretzky Places Third In Balloting by Fans
LEAD: It was no surprise that Wayne Gretzky made the Campbell Conference team for the National Hockey League All-Star Game when results of fan balloting were announced yesterday.
The surprise was that he finished third in the voting.
From the record 1,151,321 votes cast by the fans, who selected the starting team for the fourth consecutive year, Gretzky's Los Angeles teammate, Luc Robitaille, a left wing, finished first over all with 279,202 votes.


Judge Extends Order That U.S. Protect Dolphins
LEAD: A Federal district judge has extended his order for American tuna fishing boats to carry Government observers to see that efforts are made to prevent the killing of dolphins that become caught in the boats' nets.


Hershiser Complains
LEAD: He may be a sentimental hero to Dodger fans, but the way Orel Hershiser sees it, to the Dodger management he is just another business asset that may be getting too expensive to keep.
The pitcher, who was named as the most valuable player in both the National League playoffs and the World Series, told a Los Angeles radio station that although he wanted to remain with the Dodgers he had become so disenchanted with negotiations for a new contract that he was beginning to think of becoming a free agent after next season and moving to a new team.


Cuomo Plan Angers Board Members
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's new budget plan is out, and Charles Massie of Syracuse has a problem with it.


Students Are Recalled With Sobs and Silences
LEAD: In the arena where Syracuse University has celebrated its greatest victories with deafening roars, there were muffled sobs and eerie silences today as more than 10,000 people gathered to share an excruciating loss.
Four weeks after 35 Syracuse students were killed aboard Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, today's grief was new and raw, as the families of the dead students exchanged snapshots of the children they had lost.


Metro Matters; Now Hear This! Or Is the Honking Too Loud?
LEAD: ''Come Blow Your Horn'' is the name of a Neil Simon comedy, but in New York City it might as well be an invitation.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Personal Health
LEAD: Perhaps you remember as a child having a mouthful of food that you absolutely hated and couldn't begin to swallow.
Or perhaps you had a throat so sore and swollen that even water had trouble getting through.
Now, try to imagine having a more serious variation of the problem, perhaps all the time, every day, every time you try to eat or drink.


Church's Chicken To Be Auctioned
LEAD: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said its board had decided to put the company up for auction to maximize its shareholders' value.
The San Antonio-based company said its advisers would be soliciting proposals from interested bidders in the next 30 days.
Each interested party will be required to sign a standstill agreement not to rebid for the company within a year if its offer is unsuccessful, a


Treasury Official Says Bush Is Unfazed by Dollar's Gains
LEAD: A senior Treasury official indicated today that the Reagan Administration and President-elect George Bush are unconcerned about the rise of the dollar in recent weeks, including a new spurt today.


Illinois Town Suffers With Stockton
LEAD: More than 70 parents accompanied their children to the Hubbard Woods Elementary School in this Chicago suburb today, where reading and arithmetic lessons gave way to discussions about random violence against children.

Manning on Mend
LEAD: Danny Manning, the Los Angeles Clippers rookie forward, was released from Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, Calif., yesterday, four days after undergoing reconstructive surgery on his right knee.
Manning will undergo a rehabilitation program at the Kerlan-Jobe Orthopedic Clinic for the next 9 to 12 months, the Clippers' general manager, Elgin Baylor, said.

Kennedy rode down Pennsylvania Avenue in his inaugural parade and was so appalled at the tawdry state of the boulevard connecting the Capitol to the White House that he set in motion plans to revive it.

Corrections
LEAD: A list in Sports Pages yesterday, showing schools' and conferences' votes in two ballots on Proposition 42 at the N.C.A.A. convention, misstated or omitted some votes.
The University of New Mexico voted no on the first ballot and yes on the second; it did not vote yes twice.
The Southwestern Athletic Conference voted no, not yes, on both ballots.


Estonia Votes to Make Its Language Official
LEAD: The legislature of Estonia approved a law today giving Estonian precedence over Russian as the official language of the republic.

LEAD: Steve Jones, who says he is not nervous about it, can become the first man in 11 years to win three consecutive tournaments on the PGA Tour.
All he has to do is beat 143 other tour pros in the Phoenix Open, which begins Thursday and ends Sunday at the Tournament Players Club of Scottsdale.
No one has been able to put together three consecutive tour victories since Gary Player won the Masters, the Tournament of Champions and the Houston

Not Quite a Maze, Perhaps, but Amazing Nonetheless
LEAD: IT doesn't matter that neither design is a bona fide medieval maze or an authentic Renaissance parterre.
But hidden among the bricks and concrete of Manhattan, two carefully composed boxwood gardens aspire to emulate these historical forms.
Despite limited space, the city folk who created them enjoy an elegant year-round pattern of green.

LEAD: As a philosophical comedy, Pirandello's ''Enrico IV'' (at the Roundabout Theater Company) deals with the limits of logic and the possibilities of artifice.
In keeping with other Pirandello plays, it encapsulates a truth within an illusion.


Carlucci Urges Growth in Military Spending
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci made a final appeal to Congress today for resuming the growth in military spending that was halted late in the Reagan Administration.
He said that the Soviet Union still was a threat and that national security could be impaired if military budgets were cut or frozen.


Bounties and Vans: Jersey Copes With Labor Shortage
LEAD: For Keith J. Esmark, general manager of the Holiday Inn here, dealing with the lowest unemployment rate in the metropolitan region means doing everything from paying bounties for new workers to bringing in employees from as far away as Staten Island and Easton, Pa.
At times, short of staff, he has even had to cook breakfast for guests.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The Federal Reserve said it would allow banking companies to raise money for corporations in the bond market.
The decision breaks down part of the wall that has separated banking and the securities business since 1933 - the Glass-Steagall Act. [ Page A1. ] The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in November, to $12.5 billion, as exports declined and imports surged to the second-highest level on record, the Commerce Department reported.


Esquire Campaign
LEAD: Esquire magazine has a new trade campaign that begins Monday and is about as far removed from advertising as it can get.
The magazine is running three editorial pages, without any ad copy or sales chatter at all, in Adweek.
It will continue the campaign through February.
W.
Randall Jones, Esquire's publisher, called it ''a subtle sell.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation yesterday introduced its new Micro A computer, a machine the company says provides the power of a mainframe computer in a desktop machine.
The Micro A uses advanced semiconductor and packaging technology, called Scamp for Single Chip A-series Mainframe Processor.
The Scamp is a two-by-two-inch device that packs mainframe power in a single chip,

LEAD: India said today that it had agreed to allow the Israeli Consulate in Bombay to expand its activities and represent the interests of a small group of Jewish families in the southern state of Kerala, where Jews have been living for more than a thousand years.

LEAD: Amid growing concern over its trade gap with the United States and Europe, Japanese officials reported today that the country's trade surplus had widened in December to $9.65 billion, a record monthly imbalance.


Life at the Top: Even the Weather Is Different
LEAD: ''YOU'RE the top!
You're the Colosseum,'' the song lyric goes.
But the Colosseum stands only 160 feet tall, and the forgotten-but-not-gone New York Coliseum is a mere 102.
With apartment buildings climbing 50, 60 and even 70 stories, the top is closer to the clouds than the Romans or Cole Porter ever dreamed.

Anna Sokolow Choreographs Lessons in Sorrow
LEAD: Anna Sokolow has steadfastly moved to her own drummer.
A leading American modern-dance choreographer, she has had a long and influential career teaching young dancers and actors how to make every moment count emotionally.
And her dances have addressed the alienation of modern life with memorable intensity.


Developer Drops Plan For Philadelphia Mall
LEAD: A developer is abandoning his $120 million Penn's Landing mall and office project along the Delaware River about three months before its scheduled groundbreaking, calling it ''an expensive mistake.''


Bruce Chatwin, 48, Travel Writer And Author of 'Songlines,' Dies
LEAD: Bruce Chatwin, a British author whose first book, ''In Patagonia,'' published only a decade ago, established him as one of his generation's ranking travel writers and an elegant literary craftsman and storyteller, died Tuesday in a hospital in Nice, France.
He was 48 years old and had been in failing health for more than five years.

Bessemer Securities Acts to Get Aggressive
LEAD: The Bessemer Securities Corporation, a staid Wall Street investment firm owned by the Phipps family, said yesterday that it planned to get more aggressive and hired a new president and chief executive, Ward W. Woods Jr., as a first step.


Kings Road Chief Out
LEAD: Kings Road Entertainment Inc., a small film maker that has been unprofitable since going public in 1986, said Tuesday that its chairman and chief executive, Stephen J. Friedman, had been dismissed.
The company said a management restructuring was planned.
Kings Road has made about 20 films, including ''Slapshot,'' ''All of Me,'' and ''Enemy Mine.


Hoyas Top Providence
LEAD: Georgetown, playing its second consecutive game without Coach John Thompson, beat Providence, 80-77, tonight.
Charles Smith scored 35 points, including a go-ahead basket with 5 seconds left.

LEAD: In a major price-fixing settlement, the Panasonic Company has agreed to return as much as $16 million to consumers to end charges by New York State that it threatened retailers with a loss of supply unless Panasonic products were sold at prices dictated by the company.

LEAD: Brewers of two of Canada's most popular beers, Molson and Carling O'Keefe, are merging their North American operations to reach for a bigger share of the United States beer market.

Combustion Engineering Pact
LEAD: Combustion Engineering Inc. and Paris-based Alsthom S.A. announced plans today to combine their steam-boiler businesses in a joint venture that would have combined revenues of about $2 billion.
Combustion Engineering and Alsthom would own roughly equal shares in the joint venture, which is subject to approval by each company's directors and regulatory agencies in the United States, France, Canada and the European Community.


The Soviets Still Leave Reagan Uneasy
LEAD: Reflecting on his tenure, President Reagan said today there had been ''no change'' in his skepticism about the Soviet Union although he felt that remarkable progress had been made in relations between Washington and Moscow.

LEAD: Tony Granato had just put the puck past Ed Belfour of the Blackhawks to secure a 6-4 triumph for the Rangers and complete the third hat trick of his wondrous rookie season.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  FIGURE SKATING  Fadeyev in Lead: Aleksandr Fadeyev, the former world champion from the Soviet Union, took the lead yesterday after the original program of the men's competition at the European championships in Birmingham, England.
With a routine that included some interesting arm-shaking and body-wiggling choreography with a difficult triple axel-double toe-loop combination, Fadeyev moved ahead of the figure leader, Richard Zander.

A.T.&amp;T.-Dialcom
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Dialcom Inc. said that they had established the first commercial link between two domestic electronic mail services employing a new international standard designed to simplify computer-to-computer communications.
The new standard, known as X.400, is a set of guidelines specifying the format, delivery and receipt of electronic messages recommended by an international standards body.

Weapon Used by Deranged Man Is Easy to Buy
LEAD: The Soviet-designed military assault rifle that a deranged man used to kill five schoolchildren in California and wound 30 others can be purchased as easily as an ordinary rifle or shotgun, Federal officials said yesterday.


Bribes and Babies
LEAD: ''Boys don't like it too much when you have to take your baby on dates.'' It sounds like a line from a TV situation comedy.
In fact it comes from real life, from a Denver 17-year-old named Rita Lafoya, and the situation she describes is nothing to laugh at.
Miss Lafoya is the mother of a 20-month-old boy, which is hard, she says, ''because most of my freedom is gone.

Australian Trade Gain
LEAD: Australia's broadest measure of trade improved in December, when the current account deficit fell to $941 million (Australian), or $809 million (United States), from $1.54 billion (Australian) in November, the Government said today.
The current account measures trade in goods and services and is the nation's broadest measure of trade.

John Loder, 90, British Actor
LEAD: John Loder, an actor whose tenure of more than 30 years in British and American movies was credited largely to his good looks and his imposing physique, has died in England.
He was 90 years old and had homes in London and Buenos Aires.

''They're the ones with all the money.''

LEAD: Amanda Acquisition Corp., Burlington, Mass., a subsidiary of High Voltage Engineering Corp., said it had extended its $35-a-share offer for Universal Foods Corp. to Feb. 1 from Jan. 17.


AIDS Treatment Is Found Effective in Monkeys
LEAD: An experimental substance that is thought to prevent the AIDS virus from infecting cells has dramatically suppressed AIDS-like viral infections in monkeys.


Boston Questions 11 Firefighters On Claim to Be Part of a Minority
LEAD: City officials have questioned the assertions of 11 firefighters that they are members of minority groups and thus are qualified for preferential treatment in hiring and promotions, according to a city report released Tuesday night.


When Amateurs Are Professionals
LEAD: It's no secret that many athletes who play big-time college sports are essentially mercenaries hired to win championships and fill stadiums.
From time to time the N.C.A.A. makes a fuss about minimum academic standards.
But this is hypocritical nibbling around a larger truth: athletes rarely get a solid education because that's not why they're there.


Irving Boroff, 80, Ex-Head of Special School
LEAD: Irving M. Boroff, a retired New York school principal who devised innovative programs to deal with disruptive and other problem pupils, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Coney Island Hospital.
He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, President-elect Bush's inauguration and, because of the first two, a three-day work week.


Reviews/Television; When a Teen-Ager Takes a Stand
LEAD: This afternoon's ''Taking a Stand'' should be considered required viewing for Ronald Reagan.
Last week, the President wondered aloud if some civil-rights activists haven't been exaggerating the degree of racial prejudice in this country.
The recent turmoil in Yonkers alone should have been enough to give him pause.

Suspended 5 'Down Here On Business'
LEAD: rrFrom a dock on Biscayne Bay, the United States Customs speedboats roar off to chase the cocaine smugglers.
On Miami Avenue, a store sign, apparently in descending order of importance, blares: ''Lotto, Checks Cashed, Guns and Ammo, Hardware.'' Along Interstate 95 through downtown, blue flares and blue lights atop police cars block ramps near the Overtown area, seething from the fatal shooting Monday night of a speeding motorcyclist by a policeman.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the MCI Communications Corporation misstated some of the company's price reductions.
The cost of sending electronic messages and domestic facsimile documents has been reduced as much as 75 percent.
Under one plan, the cost of sending an electronic message will be 25 cents for each of the first 40 messages of no more than 7,500 characters.

Fido, Captured in Paint
LEAD: WHAT do Lady Emma Hamilton, Emily the pug and Otto and his mother have in common?

Review/Pop; A Keyboardist Steps Out Into The Foreground
LEAD: Rod Williams, the keyboardist who performed with his group at the Knitting Factory on Monday night, is one of the many musicians in New York who toil in the background, but shouldn't.
With other people - he is the regular keyboardist for the singer Cassandra Wilson - he is an empathetic accompanist, stabbing away at chords when needed, adding lush solos on cue.


U.S. Trade Gap Widens Sharply As Imports Soar
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit widened substantially in November, to $12.5 billion, as exports fell and imports surged to their second-highest level, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: FLOWERS do not grow and grass is markedly absent at ''Theatergarden Bestiarium,'' a show at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Long Island City, Queens.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush today announced his intention to nominate a New York pharmaceutical executive, Bruce S. Gelb, as director of the United States Information Agency, which oversees the Voice of America and international cultural programs.


Review/Photography; An Evans Show, 50 Years Later
LEAD: Fifty years after the publication of his ''American Photographs'' and 14 years after his death, Walker Evans (1903-1975) remains a beacon for contemporary photographers.
Unlike the other modernist masters who photographed in the 1930's - Alfred Stieglitz, Paul Strand and Ansel Adams among them - Evans seems relevant to our post-industrial, post-modern age.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company will shortly announce a major reorganization that includes the appointment of a new chief executive, Wall Street analysts and executives said yesterday.

Building Dreams With Toy Blocks
LEAD: NORMAN BROSTERMAN does not consider himself a toy collector. ''These things are much more than toys,'' he said, referring to the 265 sets of children's architectural building blocks that crowd the closets of his Upper West Side apartment. ''They represent the whole history of architecture.
You have to wonder which architects played with which ones when they were kids.


Shift by Rockport
LEAD: The Rockport Company, which is based in Marlboro, Mass., and is a subsidiary of Reebok International Ltd., has temporarily returned to Chiat/Day after a yearlong relationship with Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey &amp; Schmetterer.
Creative differences led to the divorce.
Chiat/ Day handled Rockport's advertising for about a year, until January 1988.


Close to Home
LEAD: NOW that the Holland Hotel is finally closed there aren't so many of them around Times Square: the big-bellied girls in their makeshift maternity clothes.
But they're elsewhere in the city, as many as there ever were, so young sometimes I wonder whatever drove them to sex.
Surely not lust; it must have been a rite of passage.

LEAD: President-elect George Bush, seeking to put a distinctive stamp on his Presidency, reinforced his campaign pledge today to make education a top priority of his Administration.
