Texas Eastern, Coastal to Meet
LEAD: The Coastal Corporation, which has bid $2.6 billion for the Texas Eastern Corporation, said that a meeting between officials of the two companies has been arranged for this weekend.
Coastal said it owns about 4 percent of Texas Eastern's outstanding common stock on a fully diluted basis.


Passing the Blame
LEAD: If at first you don't succeed, blame the assistant coaches.
That seems to be the operative philosophy of the Los Angeles Raiders' first-year head coach, Mike Shanahan, and the team's owner, Al Davis.
When the Raiders finished the season with a 7-9 record and failed to make the playoffs, Shanahan, a former Denver assistant who took over the Raiders last season, dismissed the team's defensive coordinator, Charlie Sumner, and another assistant, Willie Brown.


The Palestinian Menace Has Been Exaggerated; Peace and Ploys
LEAD: To the Editor:


James Marshutz, Advertising Executive, 66
LEAD: James Marshutz, an advertising executive and television producer, died of cancer Jan. 12 at his home in Manhattan.
He was 66 years old.


Heading Off 'Junk Fax' At the Wire
LEAD: Don't fax me, I'll fax you: Under a bill proposed in the Connecticut General Assembly, that would be the official message here to businesses, direct marketers and others who send unsolicited advertisements - ''junk fax'' - over the telephone wires.


San Jose Boycott
LEAD: Ten members of San Jose State's team who demanded the dismissal of Coach Bill Berry were replaced by eight walk-ons for the game last night at Fullerton State.
Four replacements, who joined the four remaining members of the team, are football players, including the tailback Johnny Johnson.
Only one walk-on, 6-foot-9-inch Craig McPherson, a transfer from Santa Clara, has college experience.

Digital Equipment Net Falls 15%; Sun and Microsoft Gain
LEAD: Even though it posted an earnings decline of 15 percent, the Digital Equipment Corporation fared well on Wall Street yesterday because those second-quarter results were 25 to 30 cents a share better than analysts had expected.


Sounds Around Town; DUELING DECIBELS
LEAD: Blind Idiot God, B.A.L.L., Reverb Mofos and Rude Buddha at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052).
Rough, brute-force rock -pounding drums, distorted guitars, disheveled vocals - takes the stage tomorrow at CBGB.
Blind Idiot God, at 11:30 P.M., plays bruising instrumentals that embrace dub reggae, hard-rock and Stravinsky; B.A.L.L., at 12:30 A.M., plays grinding, lumbering, sometimes off-handedly funny songs; the Reverb Mofos, at about 1:30 A.M., bash away like a latter-day Steppenwolf.


The Fullback Is a Throwback
LEAD: From September to January he's a flattop kind of guy.
Tom Rathman could not explain why his hair, which grows out when the football season ends, becomes a flattop again each year when it's time to return to work. ''It's just something I do,'' he said.
Rathman is 6 feet 1 inch and 232 pounds, and his appearance reflects a role that is functional and basic.


Buyout Curbs Draw Concern
LEAD: Congress should move cautiously on proposals to restrict leveraged buyouts for fear of stifling economic growth, the House Ways and Means Committee chairman said today.


Show and a Concert of William and Mary
LEAD: The exhibition ''The Age of William III and Mary II; Power; Politics and Patronage, 1688-1702'' continues through Jan. 28 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.
For the first time on display outside the archives of the House of Lords, is the Declaration of Rights, which effectively established parliamentary rule in Britain and is considered the most important document in English history after Magna Carta.


McCaw, Boston Globe Owner Set Changes
LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular telephone operator, and Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe and specialty magazines, yesterday announced plans for separate but related financial transactions that change the structures of both companies.


Lawyer for striking air traffic controllers won back 60 jobs but suffered personal loss
LEAD: More than 11,000 air traffic controllers lost their jobs in their ill-fated strike of 1981.
Jack Solerwitz, the lawyer who represented many of them, arguably lost even more.


6-Year-Old Boy Who Had Knife Is on Suspension
LEAD: A first grader was suspended Wednesday for carrying a knife into the same Bronx elementary school where a 5-year-old student was found with a loaded pistol last week.


Writers Reading
LEAD: As part of the fourth season of the New York Voices readers series of public readings by writers who live in or write about New York, Meg Wolitzer, whoe most recent novel is ''This Is Your Life,'' is to read from her works this afternoon at 12:15 at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza.
Thulani Daivs, a poet and staff writer for The Village voice who wrote the libretto for the opera ''X, the Life and times of malcolm X'' and Mark Richard, a writer and photographer, are to read next Friday at the smae time and place.


To Flop Or Not To Flop?

America does not stand still.

LEAD: Murray Chris-Craft Inc. will close next Friday, ending a 50-year presence as a manufacturer of pleasure boats.

Exit the Music Man

In a few more hours, President Reagan will snap off a parting salute and be gone.
Come noon, it will be George Bush's day, city and Government.

For the moment, Ronald Reagan is still President and he remains, to the end, both amazing and comfortable; it's a fit time to contemplate why.

LEAD: A year after announcing that it was leaving the agency business, Trout &amp; Ries is leaving New York City as well.
Jack Trout and Al Ries are packing up some of their remaining employees and establishing their marketing-strategy consulting operation in Greenwich, Conn.
With their books and articles, the partners had established themselves as doyens of positioning when they lost the United Jersey Banks account in late 1987, an event that hastened their move out of advertising.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $2.2 billion, to $284.59 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 137 institutional funds increased by $998.2 million, to $73.93 billion.
The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $2.9 million, to $90.17 billion.

Dealers said that moves by several European countries to raise domestic interest rates were ignored by the bond market, as were several economic reports that would usually be considered positive for the market.

LEAD: As might have been expected, when a bumbling bank robber dropped the $2,900 he had just stolen from Redlands Federal Savings on Tuesday, passersby quickly gathered to grab what was blowing in the wind.
What they caught they returned to the bank.
All but $20 was turned in, said Sgt.
Dan Castellini.

He plays only occasionally, but keeps his mouth closed.
The Rangers, from management to minor leaguers, admire his unfailing stoicism.
What they appreciate even more, though, is that when he does play, he gives them no reason to complain.

With 8 Hands and 25 Strings, a Quartet Makes Music
LEAD: The classic guitar, with its gentle voice and its ability to play contrapuntal music, is usually regarded as a solitary instrument - the province of the soloist.
But throughout the instrument's modern history, guitarists have teamed up as duets, trios and even, if more rarely, quartets, in order to take on music that makes demands greater than two hands and six strings can negotiate.

Review/Music; Four Conducting Contestants Show Their Stuff
LEAD: Four nervous but assured conductors, all Americans under 35 years of age, took their turns on the podium at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.
Each led the American Symphony Orchestra in bits of Beethoven's ''Egmont'' overture as well as Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' and Mozart's ''Jupiter'' symphonies; each accompanied an aria by Leonard Bernstein and rehearsed a difficult stretch of Aaron Copland's Orchestral Variations.

Aldo DeDominicis, Broadcaster, 85
LEAD: Aldo DeDominicis, who founded the first television station in New England, died Tuesday at Hartford Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Cheshire, Mr.
DeDominicis and a partner, Patrick Goode, financed and built what is now WTNH-TV in New Haven in 1948.
Earlier in the 40's, Mr.
DeDominicis was a co-founder of WNHC-AM in New Haven and bought stations in New Britain that he renamed WRCH-AM and FM.

LEAD: Chilly nights and winter white sales mean the time is right to shop for a down comforter.
The cost of a queen-size comforter can range from $89 to $900, depending on the quality of the down, the ratio of down to feathers, the quality of the fabric shell and the intricacy of the stitching.
Here are the main indicators of quality; all should be listed on the literature provided with the comforter, or available on request.

Bridge; Youthful schooling in the classics leads to an elite post interpreting tournament play.

Seattle Mayor Will Not Run
LEAD: Mayor Charles Royer announced Thursday that he will not seek a fourth term because he ''needs new challenges and new growth'' but said he had no specific plans for the future.
Mr.
Royer, 49 years old, a former journalist who was elected Mayor in 1977, won re-election in 1981 and a third term in 1985.

LEAD: The depth chart now says that Charles Haley plays left outside linebacker.
The force that his 6-foot-5-inch 230-pound body regularly creates in opposition backfields suggests something more powerful than the San Francisco 49ers have produced at the position throughout the 1980's.

String Soloist Ensemble
LEAD: The violinist Gidon Kremer and an ensemble of string soloists will play a concert of chamber music at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight.
The program includes the American premiere of Sofia Guaidulina's ''Rejoice'' for violin and cello, Schubert's Five Minuets and Six Trios, Alfred Schnittke's String Trio, and a group of Johann Strauss waltzes, arranged by Alexander Weinmann.

4 Down, 104 to Go
LEAD: Kirk McCaskill and Jose Guzman, pitchers, and Geno Petralli and Steve Lake, catchers, settled their arbitration cases yesterday.
McCaskill, 8-6 last season with a 4.31 earned-run average, settled with the California Angels at $400,000, a raise of $138,000.
Guzman, 11-13 with a 3.70 e.r.a., settled with the Texas Rangers at $425,000, a raise of $255,000.

THE 41st PRESIDENT: Fashion; Following a Tough Act With Impeccable Taste
LEAD: Nancy Reagan is a tough fashion act to follow, but Barbara Bush has already shown that she has star quality.
The clothes she wears as she takes center stage for the inaugural festivities demonstrate that she has excellent taste and an understanding of what is both appropriate and flattering to a woman of her age and size.


Beatrice Lillie, Comedienne And Lovable Eccentric, 94
LEAD: Beatrice Lillie, who during a half-century theatrical career was often called ''the funniest woman in the world,'' died yesterday at her home in Henley-on-Thames, England.
She was 94 years old.

London Broker Layoffs
LEAD: Two London stockbrokers announced today that they were curtailing trading activities and eliminating 43 jobs in the latest cutbacks since the 1987 stock market crash.
Warburg Securities, the stockbroking arm of the big London merchant bank Warburgs, said it was withdrawing from some Eurobond market-making, or wholesale dealing, activities and cutting 15 jobs.

Air Canada-Boeing
LEAD: Air Canada said it plans to buy seven 747-400 passenger and cargo aircraft from the Boeing Company.
The first three aircraft, including associated spare parts and equipment, are valued at about $600 million (Canadian), or about $506 million (United States).
They will be delivered to Air Canada between December 1990 and May 1991, the airline said.


Soviets Print Excerpts Of Attack by Zhukov On Stalin's War Role
LEAD: Pravda today published previously secret sections of the memoirs of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov that sharply criticize Stalin's war leadership and blame him for the annihilation of thousands of Soviet citizens.

Shad to Leave As Envoy
LEAD: John S. R. Shad, the United States Ambassador to the Netherlands, will leave his post next month, the American Embassy said today.
His departure comes amid speculation that he might be named chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

Marcos Hearing Adjourned
LEAD: A hearing into whether Ferdinand E. Marcos is too ill to be arraigned in New York on racketeering charges was adjourned yesterday until next month.
More medical testimony on Mr.
Marcos's health is expected to be heard Feb. 9 by Judge John F. Keenan in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
The former Philippine leader, who was indicted last October, is in a hospital in Honolulu, where, his lawyers say, he is being treated for pneumonia, asthmatic bronchitis and a heart ailment.

A Curator Is Leaving The Getty
LEAD: In a staff change that may signal a shift in its attitude toward the collecting of paintings, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has announced the resignation of its paintings curator, Myron Laskin, and his replacement by George Goldner.

Julia E. Collier, 37, Executive at Christie's
LEAD: Julia E. Collier, head of the collectibles department of Christie, Manson and Woods International Inc., the auction house, died Thursday after being struck by a truck.
She was 37 years old and lived in Manhattan.

More Ado About Abortion
LEAD: The Missouri abortion case the Supreme Court has accepted for review doesn't warrant the commotion it has evoked on all sides.
As abortion cases go, it's no legal landmark.
But Missouri, at the Justice Department's urging, has asked the Court to use the case as a vehicle for overturning the 1973 Roe v.


Jockey Donations
LEAD: About 20 members of the Jockeys' Guild riding at Aqueduct will donate their fees on losing mounts today to the Disabled Jockeys Fund of the Guild.
Eddie Maple, Eastern director of the guild, who coordinated the effort, estimates that about $3,500 will be generated from about 70 rides.


Wardair Delays Aircraft Orders
LEAD: Wardair Inc., a Canadian passenger airline that agreed this week to a buyout by a rival domestic carrier, said it was putting on hold a $600 million (Canadian) order for 14 aircraft until the two companies determined a future business strategy.


JEWS IN U.S. FIGHT A VISA FOR ARAFAT
LEAD: The major umbrella organization of American Jews says it will urge the Bush Administration to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to enter the United States to speak before an Arab-American convention in April.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the 1989 season of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., misattributed the opera ''La Straniera.'' It is by Bellini, not Rossini.

50th Goal for Lemieux
LEAD: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins became only the second player in National Hockey League history to score 50 goals in less than 50 games in the first period of tonight's 7-3 loss to the Winnipeg Jets.
Pat Elynuik, a rookie, had two goals and three assists for the Jets.


Inmates Set Fires at Prison South of Capital
LEAD: Inmates set fires in a prison south of Washington tonight, and the authorities said an unknown number of inmates were free within the complex.


Coping: With Furnishing a Home Office
LEAD: Telecommuting - working at home for a client or employer who may be miles away - has become a fact of life for more than 14 million people, according to the American Home Business Association, a professional organization.
The work offers convenience and flexible hours, but to do the job right, home-office equipment must be chosen with care.

Florida High Court Refuses To Put Off Bundy Execution
LEAD: The State Supreme Court refused today to postpone the execution of the killer of a 12-year-old girl, rejecting defense lawyers' plea to let lower courts decide whether he was sane when he was tried.


MAN IN THE NEWS: Otto George Obermaier; Defender Who Would Be Prosecutor
LEAD: Early in his career, Otto G. Obermaier prosecuted Mafia dons, drug kingpins and nefarious Wall Street schemers.
Later, he defended people accused of insider-trading, tax evasion and other white-collar crimes.
In the lawyer's parlance, he has walked both sides of the street.

Preserving Organs for Transplant
LEAD: A surgeon and a biochemist at the University of Wisconsin Medical School in Madison won patent approval this week for a chemical solution that preserves human organs several times longer than present compounds, improving the chances of successful transplants.

Chamber Symphony
LEAD: Kevin McMillan, a baritone, is to be the soloist with the New York Chamber Symphony in Bach's Cantata No. 82 (''Ich habe genug'') and arias from Handel's ''Rinaldo,'' at 8 o'clock tonight at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The program, which will be conducted by Leopold Hager as part of the orchestra's Baroque series, also includes two concertos from Vivaldi's ''Estro Armonico'' and works by Telemann and Corelli.

AFGHAN CAMPAIGN SAID TO INTENSIFY
LEAD: The Soviet Union is using a new, heavier bomb against guerrilla forces for the first time in the Afghan war, State Department officials say.


Italy's Economy Grows
LEAD: Italy's economic expansion, driven by booming consumer demand and strong industrial investment, is continuing to gather pace, according to official data issued today.
The National Statistics Institute said Italy's gross domestic product, the measure of economic performance excluding foreign trade, grew 3.9 percent year-to-year in the third quarter of 1988, up from 3.3 percent growth in the second quarter.

Because of slips in Mr.
Bush's delivery, two sentences - indicated by italics - are taken from his prepared text.

Review/Music; The Bass Clan Does Its Individual Things
LEAD: The Bass family came into the Greenwich House on Saturday night and settled in without a moment's hesitation.
Martha Bass, the gospel singer and matriarch of the clan, brought her daughter, Fontella Bass, and her son, David Peaston, in for a rocking, friendly show that moved easily from rhythm-and-blues to prim gospel numbers to black pop.


Adjustable Rate Rises to 8.58%
LEAD: The average interest rate on one-year, adjustable-rate mortgages rose to the highest level in more than two and a half years this week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.

F.

Kaare Kristian Nygaard of Scarsdale, N.Y., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs.
Johannes Nygaard of Lillehammer, Norway.
The Rev.

4:30 A.M. Bell In Philadelphia
LEAD: Based on the premise that money never sleeps, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange began pre-dawn trading today in foreign currency options and futures.

Muller Scores With 35 Seconds Left in Overtime
LEAD: The way things have been going for the Devils lately, with only a victory in five games, a tie against one of the league's elite teams would have sufficed.
But the Devils had victory on their minds when they went into overtime against the Capitals here tonight.


Dollar Slides On Central Banks' Sales
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday after another round of concerted dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve and other central banks.
It then slipped a bit more after President Bush's inaugural address.

Frank B. Smithe, 96, Amateur Ornithologist
LEAD: Frank B. Smithe, an amateur ornithologist credited with setting color standards for the science, died Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. after becoming ill recently.
He was 96 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

LEAD: The First Lady, dressed in what has already become known as ''Barbara Blue,'' swept through a gilded railroad station tonight for her first inaugural ball.


Keeping Children Safe In Others' Homes
LEAD: Every morning, thousands of New Yorkers leave their children with a neighbor.
Only a few do so sure that the city holds the care-giver to minimum standards of suitability and safety.
Why don't more parents recognize the need?


Stenmark to Retire
LEAD: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, the top-winning skier in World Cup history, will end his career April 8 with an international exhibition race against competitors of the last 15 years, according to reports in Stockholm yesterday.

Bessie Stolzenberg, Teacher, 95
LEAD: Bessie Stolzenberg, a social studies teacher in Manhattan for almost 40 years and an early advocate of women's suffrage, died of heart failure Thursday at her home in Rego Park, Queens.
She was 95 years old.

LEAD: A brief report by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday misstated Fairchild Industries' response to a takeover offer from the Carlyle Group.

LEAD: The new series ''Dolphin Cove,'' filmed entirely in Australia, is CBS's latest effort to establish an early-evening beachhead in the Saturday ratings.
This one - created by Michael Bendix, Allen Marcil and Peter Benchley - could tickle the notoriously fickle fancies of younger viewers.

LEAD: USAir Group Inc. said it had been engaged in talks with Eastern Air Lines Inc. to buy some of Eastern's gates and routes at Philadelphia International Airport, but it said no agreement had been reached.

LEAD: A man said to be a Queens drug dealer was convicted yesterday of menacing a South Jamaica man whose home had been firebombed after he had complained to the police about neighborhood drug dealers.


Piedmont Jet Loses Engine in Chicago
LEAD: The right engine of a Piedmont Airlines Boeing 737 fell off in a takeoff from Chicago's O'Hare Airport today, scattering debris on the runway that delayed flights for hours at the nation's busiest airport.
The plane landed safely on its second engine and no one was injured.

Let the Yen, Pounds and Marks Pour In
LEAD: In the recent election campaign, a number of responsible voices claimed that foreign investment in the United States was both big and bad.
An understanding of the facts, however, indicates quite the opposite.
Foreign investment is modest and, by and large, good.
Indeed, in the world where commerce is becoming increasingly globalized, the citizenship of the owner of funds is an emotional red herring.


Prosecution Calls Steinberg A Brutal Killer
LEAD: The prosecution portrayed Joel B. Steinberg yesterday as the brutal, ''repulsive'' killer of Lisa Steinberg and as a scheming, evasive defendant who tried to conceal her murder with lies and deceit.
Failing that, prosecutors said, he blamed Hedda Nussbaum for the death.

Frederick M. Stern, 84, Gruntal Chairman
LEAD: Frederick M. Stern, a Wall Street broker for more than 60 years and the chairman emeritus of Gruntal &amp; Company, died of complications after a stroke on Thursday at Montefiore Hospital.
He was 84 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

A ''Catch-22'' On Health Care in the Home
LEAD: Americans now spend more than $1 out of every $10 on health care.
How we put this money to the most cost-effective use is one of the most important questions facing individuals and political leaders today.


Rightists Blamed in Killing of 12 in Colombia
LEAD: The slayings this week of 12 members of a judicial commission that had apparently uncovered evidence on previous massacres has focused outrage on violent right-wing paramilitary groups and prompted a two-day protest strike by the nation's judges and court workers.

LEAD: My day always becomes wonderful/when I see your/pretty face smiling so sweetly. . . .
Such free-verse sentiment, printed against a background of pastel artwork, is a kind of signature for Blue Mountain Arts, a greeting-card company founded here in 1971.

THE INDIAN MUSEUM'S LAST STAND
LEAD: I have followed with interest and concern the plight of the Museum of the Amerian Indian.
Those negotiating its fate should look for a solution that will insure the museum's ability to preserve its collection and maximize the accessibility of the collection to the widest audience.
I believe there should be two facilities: a larger building in New York City, such as the Custom House, and another in Washington.

LEAD: A British Airways Boeing 757 carrying 82 people made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport today after one of its two engines developed problems in flight, the airline said.

Of Fraud, Markets, and the Future
LEAD: On Thursday it was disclosed that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had posed as commodities traders as part of a two-year investigation of the commodity futures markets.
Typical of the violations they reportedly discovered was ''bucket trading'' - where brokers and traders arrange deals in secret to purchase commodities for clients at prices that are too high.

Banks and Bonds: A Barrier Falls
LEAD: New powers for banks were granted by the Federal Reserve, which approved giving them limited authority to underwrite corporate bonds.
The action is the most significant yet in breaking the barriers that the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 put between banking and the securities business.
Bankers have long complained that the law restrictsed them as securities firms encroached on the banks' traditional businesses.

Correction
LEAD: An article in the Education Life section on Jan. 8, headed ''The Financial-Aid Numbers Game,'' depicted the use of 401(k) plan contributions erroneously as a method to reduce income reported on aid forms.
For the forms, such retirement funds are considered untaxed income.
Money paid into rollover pensions may be excluded from consideration.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Railroad a Peril for Moose
LEAD: Railroad locomotives have killed 61 moose in Alaska so far this winter, as against 329 from November to April a year ago.
The Alaska Railroad keeps moose kill figures in that five-month period because it is then that deep snow drives the moose from their summer range in the mountains down toward firm footing on or near the cleared railroad tracks.

WINGING IT
LEAD: The fin is back.

Some 30 years ago, the fin became a symbol of modern efficiency and power.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Montreal

It's this blend of the Old World and New France that makes Montreal intriguing.

LEAD: DO not delay mailing orders for seeds and plants to be sure of getting first choices.

Stamford's Old Town Hall May Have a Future in Art
LEAD: FOR the last quarter-century, the Old Town Hall, a designated national landmark in downtown Stamford, has stood virtually empty and very much out of place, a Beaux Arts anachronism in the midst of what has become a business district of modern corporate towers.

A Better Way to the Beach in Puerto Rico
LEAD: THE best road to the best beach in Puerto Rico - and one of the best in the world - isn't the main one.
The car rental agency in San Juan may tell you that Route 3 east from San Juan is the best way to reach Luquillo Beach - and they'd be half-right.
Route 3 is two-lane highway, and if a bit more beat-up than the average Interstate, it's fast and direct.

Perfect Stews to Warm a Winter Day
LEAD: STEWS are the most inviting and practical of winter food.
They can be made in one pot, cooked a day or more in advance and are economical, since cheaper cuts of meat are used.
They are also warming and filling on a cold day.
Here are some hints for making perfect stews: Use cheaper cuts of meat.
They will have less fat and more flavor.

LEAD: It is the destiny of Ferruccio Busoni's music to be perpetually revived and re-examined, never established in the repertory yet not forgotten, either.
The composer guaranteed such a state of affairs; whatever cravings he had for popular success were more than gratified by his long career as a piano virtuoso, and he composed his music for a self-selecting audience of the curious and intelligent.


A Warning Signal Is Flashing
LEAD: Since the first week of December some short-term interest rates have moved up so sharply that they now exceed the rates on long-term securities.
In the past, such an occurrence, known on Wall Street as an ''inverted yield curve,'' has often been followed by a recession and falling stock and bond markets.


Tough Year for 'Market Timers'
LEAD: Last year was a tough one for the so-called ''market timers'' - money managers who frequently move back and forth from stocks to cash, depending upon their reading of economic or technical indicators.
Their approach, which some academics have questioned, is designed to take advantage of rallies while missing market downturns.

LEAD: In recent years, the name of Idi Amin has cropped up mainly as a symbol of a tyranny nearly as bizarre as it was brutal.
Once the self-proclaimed President-for-Life of Uganda, whose whim meant death to thousands and exile to hundreds of thousands, he fled in 1979 and was given sanctuary in Saudi Arabia - on condition that he stay out of the public eye.

The Case of the Curious 'Corner'
LEAD: The stock ''corner'' flourished in the age when it was every man for himself, and when insider trading was accepted as a normal practice.
Corners grew rarer and less profitable in the 1920's, and were supposed to have disappeared entirely until a series of transactions made it appear that a corner is now in the works.


Perfect Stews to Warm a Winter Day
LEAD: STEWS are the most inviting and practical of winter food.
They can be made in one pot, cooked a day or more in advance and are economical, since cheaper cuts of meat are used.
They are also warming and filling on a cold day.
Here are some hints for making perfect stews: Use cheaper cuts of meat.
They will have less fat and more flavor.

Masked Revels of a Belgian Mardi Gras
LEAD: IN the freezing predawn darkness of Mardi gras in the Belgian town of Binche, a drummer and two costumed men dance along a lamp-lighted alley to round up fellow celebrants for the day's procession.
The Binchois call this precarnival dawn ''the best moment.''


Ryder Golf on USA Cable
LEAD: For the first time, the USA Cable network will televise the Ryder Cup matches back to the United States, Sept. 22-24, according to a source close to television negotiations for the biennial professional golf match between the United States and European teams.


4 Musicians Scheduled For Off Stage Series
LEAD: Keith Jarrett, James Levine, Steve Reich and Wynton Marsalis will take part in the Lincoln Center Off Stage series of snacks and discussion beginning in March.
Each program begins with a wine-and-cheese reception at 5:30 P.M. and is followed by a talk and a question-answer session with the guest.

LEAD: Tom Savage scored 23 of his season-high 33 points in the second half, when Rutgers shot 80 percent from the field, and the Scarlet Knights defeated Duquesne by 102-87 today in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

LEAD: Twenty-eight years after his first two-bit bet at the race track, the double life of lies and deception caught up with an insurance executive whose gambling debts had climbed into the hundreds of thousands of dollars.
The business he had built went bankrupt.
His marriage ended in bitter divorce.
Often, he considered killing himself.


2 San Jose Policemen Slain, as Is Their Killer
LEAD: A homeless man chased down and shot a policeman to death Friday, then mortally wounded another before being killed by other officers in a noontime gun battle on the street.


COASTAL LEGACY
LEAD: To understand the food of the Carolina Low Country, you have to know first a little geography and then a little history.
The Low Country is that narrow stretch of South Carolina coastline that runs from Pawleys Island in the north, southwest into Georgia, and inland 80 miles or so to the Fall Line, as Carolinians call the dramatic divide where the Sand Hills rise abruptly from the coastal plain.

He was 70 years old and lived in Manchester Center, Vt.


21 Injured in Nebraska Bus
LEAD: A bus carrying a high school basketball team went out of control on a steep road and overturned Friday night, injuring 21 people, the authorities said.
The bus crashed while coming down a hill in a canyon area and came to rest in a ditch about seven miles south of this western Nebraska village.
A 16-year-old boy was hospitalized in serious condition with a head injury.

Fads come and go, styles change.

My cautionary tale may serve to limit the trauma to the innocent among us.

Should Every Emigre Really Be Equal Under the Law?
LEAD: CONGRESS did away with quotas based on national origin when it overhauled the immigration law in 1965.
And in 1980 it abolished the presumption that anyone fleeing Communism was a refugee.
But experience in the last few months shows that it is much easier to write an evenhanded law than to carry it out in the face of political pressures reflecting special concern for particular groups of emigres.

The funds will help defray the cost - estimated at $45,000 - of restoring the wood on the entrance doors and their portico.

Prospects; The Trade Gap Widens
LEAD: The trade figures for November showed a sharp and unexpected widening of the trade deficit to $12.5 billion, from $10.3 billion in October.
The cause of the increase was a surge in imports and a decrease in exports.
The question for the analysts is whether the growth in the deficit is an aberration or a trend.

LEAD: As the Super Bowl today closes another National Football League season, Pete Rozelle ends his 29th year as commissioner, a period in which the league has grown from a mom-and-pop operation of a dozen teams to a cultural institution of 28 franchises worth as much as $80 million each.


TV VIEW
LEAD: If something appalling goes on long enough, people become inured to it.
Witness the state of American television, where, due to the peculiar exigencies of commercial network economics, we do not even blink when a scene of the Rev.
Martin Luther King Jr. being assassinated is followed by a commercial for an underarm deodorant.

LEAD: GEORGE BUGLIARELLO, the president of Polytechnic University in downtown Brooklyn, seems happy now to tell the story of being offered his job in 1973 and turning it down at first, not because of the school's faculty, finances or academic standing, but because of the urban blight surrounding its campus.

A Turn-of-the-Century Tale Resonates Through a Lifetime
LEAD: MY father-in-law died recently at the age of 96, and of all the memories I have of him, his telling of one small happening in his early years, which he kept in his memory for all of his life, has stayed with me for all of mine.
Perhaps that is because in the telling he revealed some part of himself that was not apparent, that told me something about the little boy who later became the ''Pater Familias'' whom I so loved and admired.

Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility
LEAD: AIDS has come to Long Island.
It's been here since nearly the beginning, of course, but much like the early turn of autumn leaves, few took notice.

POP VIEW
LEAD: On Jan. 12, The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominations for this year's Grammy Awards, to be presented on Feb. 22 at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles.
In the three decades since Domenico Modugno's ''Nel Blu Dipinto Di Blu (Volare)'' was voted both record and song of the year and Henry Mancini's ''Music From Peter Gunn'' was chosen best album, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has grown from a small group of musicians and executives centered in Los Angeles and New York into a 6,000-member organization with chapters in seven cities.

THE INDIAN MUSEUM'S LAST STAND
LEAD: The founder of the Museum of the American Indian, George Heye, started the collection literally by taking the shirt off the back of a Native American.
I say, give every object in the museum back to its rightful owners, the Native Americans themselves.
Let them decide what they want to share and what they need for the spiritual nourishment of their nations.

A CONTESTED ELECTION: Dr. Anatoly N. Solovyev, Doctor, Soviet Union
LEAD: Anatoly N. Solovyev, 45, is chief doctor at a big hospital in the center of Moscow.
Neither his wife, who is also a doctor, nor his son, who is studying to be a doctor, is a party member.
He joined the party in 1970 and recently defeated two other candidates in an election for the Moscow City Council.


People's Choice: 49ers
LEAD: Just as they were in 1982, when they defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 26-21, the San Francisco 49ers are the team the American public wants to see win the Super Bowl.

LEAD: After eight years, the civil war has returned to the capital and this seeming oasis is beginning to feel like a city under siege.

LEAD: True to his word, Charles Z. Wick, the departing director of the United States Information Agency, is moving back to California, where he will be close to his friend, former President Ronald Reagan.
But Mr.
Wick is not turning his back on the capital completely.

Reagan appointed him to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts's board.The board meets three or four times a year.

LEAD: Laura Riordan has been named publisher of House Beautiful.
She succeeds Marcia Miller, who resigned from the Hearst magazine in November over policy differences.
For the last six years, Ms.
Riordan has run her own company, Marketing Concepts, where her clients included Conde Nast's Vogue and Vanity Fair.

LEAD: Thirty boxes of stolen books that turned up on a library doorstep Jan. 3 have been traced to a woman who died last year.
The boxes returned to the Thornhill Branch County Library yielded 4,369 books and magazines worth about $28,000, a library spokeswoman, Jo Ann Rogers, said Friday.
The mystery was solved when a lawyer for the woman's estate called and asked the library to pick up the remaining books, Ms.

Mario Cuomo of New York emphasized the urgency of reducing waste volume and recycling re-usable components, but added pointedly that incineration and landfill would also be necessary ''for the foreseeable future.'' Then he argued that decisions on solid waste facilities were best made by local governments.

Adventure Time on the Rocks
LEAD: TO imagine what it is like to be an ice climber, think of yourself perched along the face of a frozen waterfall.
Picture the waterfall as a cascade of glass chandeliers overhanging a rock wall.
You are picking your way up slowly.
In your hand is an ice hammer, and a piton or ice screw for securing a belay rope to the top.

Report Details Cheaper Source For Bomb Fuel
LEAD: The chronic difficulties in producing a critical gas for the nation's nuclear weapons could be solved for about a third the cost of the proposal being backed by the Energy Department, according to an executive report prepared for the department.


Britain's Inflation Rises
LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 6.8 percent in December, from 6.4 percent in November, the Government said Friday.
The Department of Employment said its retail price index was up three-tenths of 1 percent in December from the previous month.
Market expectations had been for an annual rate of 6.7 percent to 7 percent and a monthly rate of three-tenths of 1 percent to one-half of 1 percent.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about bank earnings described Citicorp inaccurately.
Citicorp, the parent company of Citibank,is the largest banking company in the United States, not the largest bank.


Motorola, LSI Post Profits
LEAD: Belying reports of an electronics industry slowdown, Motorola Inc. reported on Friday record results for the fourth quarter and the year that ended on Dec. 31.
The LSI Logic Corporation, meanwhile, reported lower earnings for the quarter but higher profits for the year.

LEAD: The violinist Gidon Kremer has built a bankable reputation on an ability to deliver performances that lead listeners off the beaten path, whether by including unusual cadenzas in war-horse concertos, or by programming new and provocative works.
He took the second approach on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, when he presided over a chamber-music concert with Annette Bik, a violinist; Tabea Zimmermann, a violist; Thomas Demenga, a cellist, and Alois Posch, a bassist.

Brazil Trade Surplus Up
LEAD: Brazil posted a record $19.09 billion trade surplus in 1988 amid large export drives by steel and soybean producers, according to official figures released Thursday.
The country's exports rose 22 percent, to $33.78 billion, while imports dipped 2 percent, to $14.70 billion, from 1987 levels.

Cut your running to a mere 20 miles a week.

It is the Motorola 68000; the 68020 is used in the Macintosh II.

No Headline
LEAD: Dr.
Kathryn Hinnant, the Bellevue pathologist, and Steven Smith, the man charged with her murder and rape, were both in Columbia, S.C., last April.

Rover Group Chairman Taking Cadbury Post
LEAD: After 14 years as chairman of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., Sir Adrian Cadbury is stepping down.
Sir Adrian, who will be 60 in April, the normal retirement age for directors, will formally take his leave after the annual meeting in May.
He will be succeeded by Sir Graham Day, chairman of Rover Group P.L.C.

Where G.I.'s Died, a Beach Is Brimming With Life
LEAD: Nero, who was born here and might be considered somewhat biased, liked this town so much that he would come back in the summer, living in a villa that he had built on a sheer cliff overlooking the Tyrrhenian Sea.
Caligula was also born here.
There are people who wonder how it is that Antium, as it used to be called, managed to produce two Roman emperors of such enduring infamy.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Persistent Idealism: Ivan T. Berend, Economist, Hungary
LEAD: A respected intellectual, Ivan T. Berend, 58, is an economic theorist and a member of the Central Committee of Hungary's Communist Party.
He is a former rector of Karl Marx University in Budapest and president of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.
He has traveled widely in the West and studied at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Contempt for American Values: Jean-Pierre Quilgars, Factory worker, France
LEAD: Jean-Pierre Quilgars, 33, was dismissed from his job at the Renault factory in Boulogne-Billancourt, a Paris suburb, two years ago.
He said he was one of 10 party members and unionists dismissed for organizing protests against layoffs.
Renault also prosecuted them for various crimes, like theft.
All 10 were acquitted and are fighting to be rehired; three have won reinstatement.


South Bronx Rallies for a Firehouse
LEAD: Martin Rogers said he remembers Superbowl Sunday in 1988 well.
Not because of the game, he said yesterday, but because of what he called the ''sneaky'' way that New York City closed a Brooklyn firehouse.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Flourishing of the Arts: Henryk Kliszko, Party adviser, Poland
LEAD: Henryk Kliszko, 39, is an adviser to various Polish party groups, including the official labor unions.
A Marxist theoretician, he joined the party as a student in 1962 because he believed that membership was the most effective way to change the system.
If just a few years ago Polish youth was very unwilling, very cynical about anything called socialism or Marxism, well at the moment of Gorbachev coming to power this changed, especially with the youth of the intelligentsia, who were very frustrated.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Sense of Rectitude: Mario Benedetti, Auto mechanic, Italy
LEAD: An auto mechanic for more than 30 years, Mario Benedetti, 54, has a garage next to a big gas station where he employs his son and one other mechanic.
He is a painter and an avid reader, and he has been active in Italy's Communist Party since his youth.
No one else in his family has joined the party - proof, he says, of the freedom of choice that Communists allow.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
West German inflation can be held at around 2 percent in 1989, Helmut Haussmann, the Economics Minister, predicted in a radio interview.
The Government's economic report for 1989, scheduled to be published Tuesday, is expected to include a forecast that the inflation rate will be 2.5 percent.
Figures for December put year-on-year inflation for 1988 at 1.6 percent.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; A Place for Profits: Waldemar Zaprzaluk, Plant manager, Poland
LEAD: One of the new breed of Polish managers, Waldemar Zaprzaluk, 40, has been a member of the party since he was 20.
He appears to have no Marxist idols, and is proud to be running his pencil factory - which was nationalized in 1946 when the Communists took power - the way its capitalist owner ran it before the war.


Celebrity Prisoners Share a Spartan Space
LEAD: It is a small place: only 13 beds, a picnic table and a television set.
The men who live there watch ''Good Morning America'' or the ''Today'' show in the morning and the 6 o'clock news in the evening.
The way officials describe it, it is almost like living in a fraternity house.

The films, ''Zou Zou'' (1934) and ''Princess Tam Tam'' (1935), are subtitled in English.

Soundings From East and West: Faith in the Face of Upheaval; Endurance of the Party: Georges Marchais, Party leader, France
LEAD: Georges Marchais, 68, has been general secretary of the French Communist Party since 1972.
He was drawn to the party through trade-union activity after World War II.
IN MY LIFE AS AN ACTIVIST, I went through many difficult periods but also many fairly exulting ones.
Let's say that in the period during which I was a member of the party, and just a member of the party, after 1947, I think the Communist Party -and this is how I felt it - can be very proud of the role it played in our country to end colonialism.

LEAD: Hans-Alfred Rosenthal, 64, is the director of the Institute of Virology at Humboldt University in East Berlin and a frequent visitor to the West.
During World War II, he worked at forced labor, was arrested by the Gestapo and later freed,and spent some time in hiding.
He joined the party in 1946, a year after he was liberated by Soviet soldiers.

LEAD: The Southmark Corporation, whose two top officers resigned under pressure from dissident creditors last week, said Friday that its directors had hired Drexel Burnam Lambert Inc. to advise the company on the sale of all or part of its assets.

LEAD: A picture on Jan. 14 showing a model of a condominium, hotel and shopping complex planned for First Avenue and 60th Street was provided in error by the developers' press office.
It showed the original proposal for the project.
As approved by the City Planning Commission, the building was changed significantly, and its height was reduced by 189 feet.

Review/Television; Nuclear Arms and the Superpowers
LEAD: A 13-hour documentary is public television's equivalent of a nuclear explosion.
Although no program can live up to the blast of a title like ''War and Peace in the Nuclear Age,'' the series that begins tonight at 10 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 49 makes a considerable impact.

49ers Win Super Bowl On Last-Minute Score
LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers drove 92 yards in the final minutes and scored a touchdown with 34 seconds left to defeat the Cincinnati Bengals, 20-16, yesterday in Super Bowl XXIII.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the shooting of two New York City police officers in Brooklyn Friday misstated the circumstances under which they tried to arrest a murder suspect.
They arrived at 82 Hancock Street, where the suspect was hiding in a friend's apartment, with a warrant issued for the man's previous address, where they had earlier searched in vain.


A Stronger Savings Regulator
LEAD: The regulatory system that has been widely blamed for allowing the savings and loan industry to collapse is today in much sounder shape, according to analysts, industry executives and regulatory officials.


Handling Past Wrongs: Bayardo Arce, Politician, Nicaragua
LEAD: Bayardo Arce's responsibility in Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista National Directorate is to tend to the party structure.
He is sometimes classed among the country's more radical leaders.
A 39-year-old former journalist, he used his newspaper job before the Sandinistas took power as a cover for revolutionary activities.

LEAD: Michael Lepiner, president of Telecom Entertainment, producers of programs for commercial television, died of pancreatic cancer Sunday at Mt.

Citicorp Had Loss in '88 In Global Equities
LEAD: John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, said yesterday that the bank holding company had losses $100 million to $200 million in its global equities business last year.


NOMINEE OF BUSH'S IS SAID TO OPPOSE BANNING ABORTION
LEAD: Dr.
Louis W. Sullivan, President Bush's choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services, has been telling members of Congress that he does not want the 16-year-old Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion to be reversed.
This puts him in conflict with Mr.
Bush, who today told abortion protesters in forceful terms that he favors reversal of the abortion ruling.


Losing Streak Ends
LEAD: The trainer Oscar Barrera broke a personal losing streak extending back to last May 16 when Home by Nine won Aqueduct's ninth race yesterday with Richard Castillo aboard.
Barrera had not had a winner among 130 consecutive horses he saddled going into yesterday's last race.
Jose Martinez, aboard the runner-up, Poster Run, alleged interference by Home by Nine but the claim was disallowed.

Reassessment of the Soviet Model, Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, Artist, Mexico
LEAD: Arnoldo Martinez Verdugo, 63, was general secretary of the Mexican Communist Party from 1963 until 1981, when the party became part of the Unified Socialist Party of Mexico.
An artist and former presidential candidate, he has twice been elected to the Chamber of Deputies.
In 1982, he was the Unified Socialist Party's presidential candidate, winning less than 1 percent of the vote.


C.F.T.C. Insists It Had Role All Along
LEAD: Asserting that it has not been asleep as a regulator, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had been participating in the Government's investigation of trading at two Chicago commodity exchanges for more than two years.

Kemper Plans Restructuring
LEAD: In a significant restructuring move, the Kemper Corporation said today that it would divide its Kemper Group into two units to improve its performance and to raise the company's stock price.
The transaction was valued at between $280 million and $300 million.
Joseph E. Luecke, the


Careers; Difficulties For Women Lawyers
LEAD: SINCE women were first admitted to the bar in New York State 102 years ago, discrimination against them has weakened.
But for many women lawyers it remains.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. How and why does a cat purr?
A.
Most researchers agree that the purr results from vibrations in the muscles of the larynx and in the diaphragm, according to Dr.
Leslie L. Cooper, a veterinarian specializing in animal behavior.


Red Wolves Reintroduced On Gulf Isle
LEAD: The effort to reintroduce the red wolf to the wild is expanding with the introduction of a pair of the animals to a wilderness area on Horn Island, in the Gulf of Mexico off the Mississippi coast.

Rice's Career Is Moving At a Most Incredible Pace
LEAD: When Jerry Rice was attending Mississippi Valley State, a college without rich playboys, he drove a Datsun 300ZX, a car popular with playboys on other campuses.
He said he earned much of his money as a summertime hod carrier, handling bricks for his father for $200 a week.


China Will Launch U.S.-Built Satellite
LEAD: A Hong Kong company signed a $30 million contract today to fire an American-built satellite into space on a Chinese rocket - the first time China will launch a foreign-built satellite.

LEAD: Christian Lacroix, whose stunning first collection two years ago inspired many other fashion houses to pursue new design areas, continues to be a pathfinder.
His spring and summer collection opened the couture showings Sunday with verve, color and the excitement of the unexpected.

Salvador Dali, Pioneer Surrealist, Dies at 84
LEAD: Salvador Dali, pioneer of European Surrealism and for more than half a century one of the best-known and most bitterly contested figures in the international art world, died yesterday at Figueras Hospital in Figueras, Spain.
He was 84 years old.

Cynicism About the Free Market: Gustavo Espinoza Montesinos
LEAD: Gustavo Espinoza Montesinos, 47, has been a member of the Central Committee of the Peruvian Communist Party since 1966.
A former teacher, he is part of the United Left bloc in Peru's congress, the second-largest bloc after that of the Government party.
He has not been arrested since 1979, but has often been beaten in protests.

Garlic and Cancer
LEAD: Garlic and onions, food items that have often received mixed reviews in this country, have been credited in China with a benefit that has nothing to do with taste or odor.
A new study shows that they reduce the risk of stomach cancer.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Meteorite Umbrella
LEAD: Edward Teller has a new idea for those jaded by ''Star Wars'': a space-based defense against large meteorites.
Speaking recently at George Washington University, Dr.
Teller, the physicist who led the nation's hydrogen bomb team, said an international project could in effect render meteorites - called meteoroids before they enter Earth's atmosphere - impotent and obsolete at a cost of just $100 million or so.

School Official Admits Guilt in Bribery Case
LEAD: A vice president of the Newark Board of Education pleaded guilty today to Federal charges that he had solicited a $3,000 bribe from a teacher who was seeking a job as a vice principal.
United States Attorney Samuel A. Alito Jr. said an investigation of similar reported abuses was widening.


The (900) Numbers to the Stars
LEAD: Fans of the popular rap duo D.J.
Jazzy Jeff and Fresh Prince don't have to wait for a new album or local concert appearance to keep in touch with their heroes.
By dialing (900) 909-5333, they can hear the latest chapter in the duo's continuing adventures from the performers themselves.
Two-minute pre-recorded messages change daily.

LEAD: A statewide coalition of labor unions and local governments called today for a delay in the planned cut of $400 million in state income taxes this year, instead of layoffs or deep cuts in spending.

Chang Yu-Yi Is Dead; Bank Official Was 88
LEAD: Chang Yu-Yi, vice president of the first women's bank in China from 1927 to 1937, died Saturday of cardiac arrest in her sleep at her home in Manhattan.
She was 88 years old.
Miss Chang was a member of a family that was influential in China before the Communist takeover in 1949.
She was the sister of Chang Chia-ao, who became chairman of the Bank of China, and Carsun Chang, a philosopher who became a high official in the Nationalist Government of Chiang

Intrepid Explorer of Tangled Files
LEAD: IN 1520, the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan navigated the treacherous straits that now bear his name.
His expedition around the world, which he did not live to complete, was beset by boredom, stark terror, anguish, blinding fog, hallucinations of horrible monsters and many cruel and capricious acts of a malevolent universe.

Louis, from Federated Department Stores.

LEAD: Japan's Nikko Securities Company International Inc. laid off 18 traders, salespeople and research staff members, abandoning the business of selling United States equities to American investors, a source close to the firm said Friday.

Reviews/Theater; Sadness as Life Slips By in Chekhov
LEAD: When Stanislavsky first read Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' written especially for the Moscow Art Theater, he was disappointed.
There were no real characters, the director complained, only hints of them.
Yet nearly a century later the characters who inhabit Chekhov's drawing rooms and gardens in provinical Russia speak more clearly to the eternal yearnings and frustrations of the human condition than those in a hundred contemporary plays.

A Moral Claim in Africa: Mzala, Writer, South Africa
LEAD: Mzala, 33, goes only by one name, and says his first name ''got lost'' when he was growing up.
A member of the South African Communist Party, he writes for journals of the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party.
Mzala, who has lived in exile in Britain since 1987 and is studying at Essex University for a doctorate in sociology, was detained several times by the South African authorities, the first time when he was 15.

Reviews/Music; The Opera That Made Rossini's Reputation
LEAD: The bel canto revival - the restoration of operas by Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and the young Verdi - has been one of the three or four most influential postwar operatic movements.
The Lyric Opera's current production of Rossini's ''Tancredi'' is arguably a state-of-the-art specimen - critical edition, uncut score, first-choice cast -and so Saturday evening's performance prompted as many thoughts about the bel canto scene in general as about the particular merits of ''Tancredi.

LEAD: In the last few months silver has surged into the forefront as a favorite metal for jewelry and fashionable bits of trimming. (Yes, gold-toned Chanel-style jewelry is still the rage, too.) Silver first became chic in the mid-1970's when Tiffany &amp; Company started selling Elsa Peretti's bold, original bracelets and belt buckles.

Fines for Tesoro
LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of San Antonio has been ordered to pay more than $56 million to the Energy Department for regulatory violations between 1973 and 1981, the company said today.
According to the agency's final order, Tesoro has 30 days to make an initial payment of $25 million, after which six annual payments of $5.2 million will be due.

Temptation for the Freethinker: Roberto Freire, Politician, Brazil
LEAD: Roberto Freire, 46, is on the 12-member Executive Committee and the 63-member Central Committee of Brazil's Communist Party.
He holds one of three Communist seats in Congress.
Mr.
Freire, who comes from Recife, in Brazil's poor northeast, turned to politics in 1961. ''What finally led me to Communism was my disbelief in religion,'' he said.

LEAD: Govinda Pillai, 62, is a a member of the board of the Kerala State Film Development Corporation.
He is formerly editor of a Communist newspaper.
We don't oppose the opening of Soviet society.
They have to stop this process of people leaving the scene only when they die. . . .
But what I don't like is the sense of the messianic: The Great Gorbachev has come to give the movement a human face!

The Pied Piper of Shoreham
LEAD: Long Island faces a paradox of power, political and electrical, of national consequence.
Its generating capacity has so narrow a margin of safety that blackouts could begin this summer.

LEAD: WITH little public attention, the Securities and Exchange Commission is moving toward a sharp reduction in the amount of financial disclosures that many companies will have to make to raise capital in the United States.

Review/Television; 2 New Shows About TV
LEAD: ''Time period premiere'' is what ABC calls it.

Wobbling of the Party Line: Safdar Hashmi, Theater Director, India
LEAD: Safdar Hashmi, 35, a founder of the pro-Marxist Students Federation of India at Delhi University in 1970, was a playwright, actor, director and leading figure in Indian street theater.
He was beaten to death by a street gang early this month after refusing to stop production of a street play.
The play supported a candidate running against a member of the Congress Party.

Accord for Henke
LEAD: Tom Henke settled with the Toronto Blue Jays on a one-year contract for $975,000 yesterday, avoiding a second successive arbitration hearing.
Greg Gagne of the Minnesota Twins also settled his case, agreeing to a one-year contract for about $550,000.
Last year, Henke asked for $1.025 million and Toronto offered $725,000, the figure picked by the arbitrator, Raymond Goetz.


New Project Will Renovate The Garden
LEAD: A $1.3-billion plan to replace Madison Square Garden with an office complex and build a new arena west of the present site on the West Side of Manhattan has been abandoned in favor of a $100-million renovation of the Garden, public officials and real-estate executives said yesterday.


Persistence of Class Conflict: Saifuddin Chowdhury, Politician, India
LEAD: Saifuddin Chowdhury, 36, a member of the Communist Party of India - Marxist, says he was 15 or 16 when he decided to join the party.
He said he was a fugitive from the police and the Congress Party in Bengal from 1972 to 1977, when the Congress Party tried to destroy the Communist movement in the state.


Hospitals Get Orders To Reduce Crowding In Emergency Rooms
LEAD: The New York State Health Commissioner yesterday took four actions to reduce overcrowding in emergency rooms in New York City, including the installation of a citywide data bank to keep track of how many emergency room beds are available from moment to moment.


Man Sought in Bank Robberies Is Arrested
LEAD: A man wanted by the F.B.I. in 30 bank robberies was arrested yesterday by a Metro-North police officer who heard over his hand radio of a robbery in progress at a bank he was near.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday, with an article about hard times in Zambia since the decline of the copper industry, located the scene incorrectly.
It was in Ndola, Zambia, not Nairobi, Kenya.

LEAD: In 1922, a young actress named Margaret Buckley swallowed five bichloride of mercury tablets, then calmly strolled to the opulent Capitol Theatre on Broadway in New York City.
There, succumbing while the theater orchestra played ''Espagna'' before the feature, she moaned, ''I had high ideals, but I couldn't live up to them.

To Treat Child Abuse, Let Pediatricians Identify High-Risk Cases; Parent Education
LEAD: To the Editor:


East Germany to Cut Its Armed Forces by 10,000
LEAD: The East German leader, Erich Honecker, announced today that his country would reduce its armed forces by 10,000 and also cut military spending by 10 percent.


A Search for Clues to 'Dark Ages' of the Cosmos
LEAD: SCIENTISTS believe they are on the verge of major discoveries about the ''dark ages'' of the universe, the critical period from three minutes after the explosive moment of creation until the appearance of enormous galaxies.
They hope to answer one of the most perplexing questions in cosmology: how primeval particles, hurtling apart from the Big Bang, managed to combine into atoms, which then clumped together to eventually form stars, galaxies and clusters of galaxies in the evolving universe.

For Smith, after all, the glory of competitive markets lay in their capacity to direct private greed to public benefit.

Lloyd Gets Go-Ahead
LEAD: Commissioner Jay Ramsdell reversed an earlier decision yesterday and gave Lewis Lloyd permission to play for Cedar Rapids in the Continental Basketball Association immediately.
Ramsdell had refused to admit Lloyd to the league last November, saying that the former Drake guard had not shown over a long period that he had overcome the cocaine problem that brought his ban from the National Basketball Association two years ago.


James F. Collins, Is Dead at 85; General Headed Red Cross in War
LEAD: James F. Collins, a four-star general in the United States Army who in retirement served as president of the American Red Cross in the Vietnam War, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.
He was 83 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

LEAD: Paul D. Wolfowitz, a former senior official in the State Department who is now Ambassador to Indonesia, is expected to be named to a high policy position in the Defense Department, Administration officials said Monday.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Capitals 4, Kings 4: Scott Stevens and Dave Christian scored in the final 49 seconds of regulation last night as Washington overcame a three-goal deficit in the final 13 minutes 22 seconds for the tie at Landover, Md.
With Washington behind by 4-3, Larry Murphy stopped a clearing pass by the Kings' goalie, Glenn Healy, behind the Los Angeles goal and centered the puck to Christian, who put a wrist shot just inside the right post with five seconds remaining for the tie.

Toshiba Unit Starts Making Telephones
LEAD: The Toshiba Corporation said it had begun assembling cellular car telephones in the United States.
A Toshiba spokesman said that the company's Toshiba America Inc. subsidiary began production last week at its plant in Irvine, Calif., which assembles 10,000 to 12,000 mobile telephones a month, using Japanese components.

Layers and layers of a barrier that medical science little understands now separate the child from the world, and the world from the child.

At Last, Food for the Starving in Sudan
LEAD: Thousands face death by starvation in the southern Sudan.
The Khartoum regime of Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi won't let relief agencies fly in food lest it feed non-Islamic rebels.
Until now, Washington scarcely uttered a peep for fear of pushing the Khartoum Government further into Libya's orbit.

LEAD: Carl F. Jellinghaus, a retired executive editor of The Record newspaper in Hackensack, N.J., died of congestive heart failure yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 71 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

LEAD: A prosecution witness has given new evidence further implicating a state-owned engineering company and the Imhausen chemical company in the construction of a chemical plant in Libya, Stern magazine says.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a four-tenths of 1 percent monthly decrease in the ''short interest'' for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation today rejected a sweetened $3.2 billion bid from Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc., calling it inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders, but Shamrock immediately said it would pursue its offer for the instant-camera company.

LEAD: National Credit Card Trust 1989-1 is offering $1 billion of credit-card-backed securities, due in 1994, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: Sherman Douglas scored 19 points as 14th-ranked Syracuse snapped a three-game Big East Conference Closing streak tonight by defeating Boston College, 72-60.

Several agencies formerly did the ads, which have about a $16 million budget.

At the Nation's Table
LEAD: ''OFTEN imitated, never duplicated'' boasts the sign at the shop where Irving and Edith Gorsky have been selling pepperoni rolls, a Youngstown favorite, for 18 years.
The sandwich is baked daily at the West Gate Deli &amp; Food Carry Out, the Gorskys' small storefront bakery-delicatessen on this city's west side.

LEAD: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, has selected a handful of experienced diplomats and intelligence officers to help him coordinate foreign policy and national security affairs for the new Administration.


3 Rescued From Mine That Collapsed in Peru
LEAD: Rescuers found three buried miners alive today and heard faint tapping inside a dilapidated gold mine where as many as 200 men were trapped in a cave-in, officials said.


Agreement on Drug Testing
LEAD: Olympic officials of East Germany and the United States have agreed to develop a joint anti-drug program, similar to the one being put together by the United States and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Saying that he and President Bush had a ''gnawing feeling'' about the surge of corporate takeovers, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he was studying ways to curb the use of high-yield ''junk bonds'' to finance such deals.

Arianespace's $3 Billion Order
LEAD: Arianespace, Europe's commercial space transport company, said it planned to order 50 Ariane 4 launching vehicles for about $3 billion from its industrial partners next month.
The Ariane 4 rockets will be used to put satellites into orbit between 1991 and 1999.


MAI Basic Move
LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc. asked a Federal District Court judge to lift an order blocking its $20-a-share bid for Prime Computer Inc.
In court documents responding to a judge's concerns, MAI Basic said Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was confident it could raise $875 million to finance the takeover.
Prime, based in Natick, Mass., said it would fight to keep the court order in place.

LEAD: City and state officials around the nation vowed today to continue their efforts to aid minority contractors, despite the Supreme Court's decision on Monday to invalidate a Richmond law that channeled 30 percent of public works funds to businesses owned by minorities.

LEAD: In June Murdoch Magazines will introduce Sports Travel, a trade magazine catering to sports-minded travel planners, athletic directors, promoters and travel agents.

Book Notes
LEAD:  Awaiting the Other Shoe


Corrections
LEAD: A bank earnings listing in Business Day yesterday bore an erroneous company name.
The earnings, listed between those of New England Bancorp and Neworld Bancorp, were those of NBB Bancorp of New Bedford, Mass., not NBD Bancorp of Detroit.
A corrected version appears in the listing today.


Indonesia Patent Law
LEAD: Indonesia proposed legislation today to protect foreign patents after Washington announced trade sanctions on Thailand last week for refusing to do so.
The State Secretary, Major General Moerdiono, said Indonesia's first patent law would include protection of pharmaceutical brand names, one of the more widely pirated items in developing countries.

LEAD: George Knudson, whom Ben Hogan once described as having the sweetest swing in professional golf, died of cancer today.

Arthur S. Hirsch, Judge, 80
LEAD: Arthur S. Hirsch, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died of heart failure Sunday at Villa Maria Nursing Home in Bay Harbor, Fla., where he was visiting.
He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Even So, Affirmative Action Lives
LEAD: The Supreme Court has made it harder for states and cities to give minorities an edge in competing for public works contracts that long went only to whites.
Harder, yes, but not impossible, for the Court once again has struck down one affirmative action plan while announcing rules by which others may survive.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: WHEN I think of Baltimore-style crab cakes I think of Obrycki's Crab House, a rollicking fish restaurant in a former row house on East Pratt Street in Baltimore.

A Peripatetic President: Election Over, He Runs
LEAD: At 1:30 P.M., the announcement came over the loudspeaker in the White House press room: ''The travel pool should assemble in 10 minutes for a 1:50 movement.''


Kaisertech's Chairman Is Replaced by Maxxam
LEAD: In a surprise move, Kaisertech Ltd.'s new owner, Maxxam Inc., has ousted James S. Pasman as chairman and chief executive.


Statoil Plans Job Cuts
LEAD: Norway's state-owned oil company, Statoil S.A., the nation's largest concern, said today that it planned to shed jobs over three years to cut costs.
Statoil has been hit hard by lower crude prices and by cost overruns at a refinery project in western Norway.

Coffee Prices Fall Sharply; Bigger Brazil Supply Seen
LEAD: Coffee futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
The March contract dropped 6.34 cents, or 634 points, during the trading session.


Cliburn Plans Concert, His First in 10 Years
LEAD: Van Cliburn plans to perform with the Philadelphia Orchestra on June 19 in his first major concert in more than a decade.


RAIDERS SURRENDER AT ARGENTINE BASE
LEAD: Armed civilians holding out at an Argentine infantry barracks surrendered to the army today after a daylong assault in which at least 36 people were killed and scores wounded, the Government said.


Review/Music; Anniversary Flute Recital
LEAD: John Solum's flute-playing, teaching, concert-organizing and recording have spanned more than three decades, and to celebrate the 30th anniversary of his New York recital debut, he came to Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon.


Lacking Garbage, a Jersey Incinerator Is Losing Money
LEAD: Mechanically, Warren County's incinerator has worked just fine since opening here last July.
Financially, it has stumbled.
Amid a waste-disposal crisis across much of New Jersey, the state's first county incinerator doesn't have enough garbage.


Morley Drury, Former Football Star, 85
LEAD: Morley Drury, an all-America running back at Southern California in 1927, when he became the first Trojan to rush for 1,000 yards in a season, died Sunday at the age of 85.


Gotti Pleads Not Guilty to Assault Charge and Is Released on Bail


Accounts
LEAD: * 3M Corp. to Chiat/Day Advertising, San Francisco, for Scotchguard brands.


36,000 Farmers Fail to Seek Restructuring of Debt With U.S.
LEAD: More than 36,000 farmers have failed to meet a deadline for declaring an interest in restructuring overdue debts to the Government, an Agriculture Department official said today.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose again yesterday as market participants reacted positively to what essentially was a pessimistic outlook from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.


City Officials Sign Foster-Care Contract
LEAD: New York City said yesterday that it had signed a new contract with private groups that provide foster care for some 20,000 children.
The contract is intended to improve placement and assure that the agencies abide by a Federal court decision requiring ''meaningful access'' to birth control.


'89 Milk Output Forecast
LEAD: Last year's drought is still having a lingering effect on the nation's dairy farmers, but an Agriculture Department report said on Monday that 1989 milk output could still set another record.
Production rose to a record 145.3 billion pounds in 1988 because of an increase of almost 3 percent in milk output per cow.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Much-Deserved Honor
LEAD: In an unusual mark of bipartisan esteem, Connie Gerrard, one of the capital's political long-distance runners who worked as a press assistant in the White House for 25 years, serving five Presidents, will be honored at a party at the Ritz Carlton Hotel Friday night by the 12 White House press secretaries for whom she worked.


Israeli Troops on Night Patrol Kill Arab Man
LEAD: Israeli troops on a night patrol in the occupied West Bank shot and killed a Palestinian man with a plastic bullet on Monday and wounded a second person, Palestinians and the army said today.


More Than 100 Subpoenas Served on Commodity Firms
LEAD: Subpoenas were served today on virtually every clearing firm on the nation's two largest commodity exchanges, in what appears to be the broadest search for information since an inquiry into possible trading fraud was disclosed last week.


Newton Goes Home
LEAD: C. M. Newton, basketball coach at Vanderbilt since 1981 and a member of Kentucky's top-ranked team in 1951, yesterday was named athletic director at Kentucky.
He will begin his duties on April 1, succeeding Cliff Hagan, a former Kentucky basketball star who resigned Nov. 15, after 13 years as athletic director, amid an investigation of the Wildcats' basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Our strategy continues to be centered on moving toward, and ultimately reaching, stable prices - that is, price levels sufficiently stable so that expectations of change do not become major factors in key economic decisions.
Current inflation rates, by that criterion, clearly are too high and must be brought down.


House in '88 Rated Most Liberal in 40 Years
LEAD: Americans for Democratic Action, the liberal advocacy group, said Monday that the House of Representatives last year had the most liberal record since the organization began rating Congressional voting records in 1947.

Legislators Refuse Ethics Panel Request
LEAD: The leaders of the State Legislature, citing the separation of powers doctrine, refused yesterday to testify about campaign finance reform before Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's special ethics commission.


Surprise for Mullen
LEAD: The phone in Brian Mullen's Edmonton hotel room rang at 9 A.M. yesterday, which struck the left wing for the Rangers as curious.
Michel Bergeron, his coach, was on the other end asking him whether he had heard the news, which struck Mullen as downright ominous. ''He thought he'd been traded,'' Bergeron said of Mullen.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Inflation is unacceptably high, Alan Greenspan said, raising the possibility of higher short-term rates.
The markets responded favorably to his anti-inflation stance. [ Page A1. ] Criminal charges against Drexel Burnham Lambert were filed by the Government.
The details indicate a broader range of illegal activities than had been disclosed.


Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday for the first time in three weeks at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

Radionics Agrees To Be Acquired
LEAD: Radionics Inc. reached an agreement with Expamet International P.L.C. under which the London-based company will begin a tender offer of $20 a share, or about $88 million, for the security equipment maker.
Radionics' shares rose $6.125 today, to $19.625, in over-the-counter trading.

LEAD: Gainesville, Fla., is tentatively offering $100 million of tax-exempt subordinated utility system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.4 percent for an issue due in 2013, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.

Bridge
LEAD: On most bridge deals, a good player can inspect a 52-card diagram and decide with reasonable assurance whether a given contract will succeed with the best play by both sides.
But his verdict may be wrong.
How would you rate South's chances of success in five clubs doubled?


65th Birthday Party for a Voice of Liberal Opinion
LEAD: The advertising slogan proclaims that only 1 in 8,000 people in this country has ever read an issue of The New Leader (circulation about 20,000), which is celebrating its 65th anniversary today as a pathbreaker, a truthteller, a scarred survivor.
All the same, the slogan says, ''You've been influenced by it.


Opportunity For Bush
LEAD: The proliferation of all kinds of Soviet-American exchanges in the last couple of years is staggering.
Where once they involved a small number of experts, usually carefully vetted by Moscow, now people are jaunting back and forth to take a joint look at almost every imaginable issue.


Koch Imposes 2-Month Hiring Freeze
LEAD: The Koch administration said yesterday that it will impose a two-month partial hiring freeze and warned that New York City would face its toughest budget in this decade if the state spending plan proposed by Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo is adopted.
