LEAD: When Jayson Williams, the high-scoring center for St.
John's, and John Turner, Georgetown's rugged forward, were ejected for fighting in a game Monday night, Connecticut and Seton Hall got the best of it.
Under Big East rules, each player will be suspended for his team's next conference game.
That means Williams will miss the St.


Washington Talk: Briefing; A Judge's Passion
LEAD: Like everyone else, Washington officials have their private passions.
For David Harfeld, an administrative law judge, it is musical comedy.
Beginning Saturday, Judge Harfeld will be host of a local weekly radio program, ''Curtain Up,'' that will feature the scores of musicals ''that you probably never heard of, but where great stars made their musical comedy debuts.


The Ranger Rookie Born to Be a Pro
LEAD: Tony Granato dropped into the seat of the airplane, spread a blanket over himself and barely got the plastic window shade closed before his eyelids slid shut as well.
As the plane rumbled through the late afternoon sky and the Badlands of South Dakota slipped by underneath, Granato curled up in a ball and slept deeply.

Willie Wells, 82, Dies; Star in Negro Leagues
LEAD: Willie Wells, a shortstop who batted .358 over his career in the Negro leagues from 1924-45 but never played in the major leagues, died last Sunday.

New Chairman for Landmarks Panel; David Fenton Michie Todd
LEAD: At the age of 73, David F. M. Todd is about to take a long journey across a short space - from one side of the table at which he has been sitting for four years, as a flintily independent member of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, into the chairman's post.


At the Nation's Table
LEAD: LOW in fiber and high in saturated fat, the chef's special each Thursday night at the Wayside Restaurant here is an old-timer's dream and a nutritionist's nightmare.
The special, salt pork and milk gravy, is a traditional New England supper that fans say can be found at no other restaurant in the area.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers have signed Shelton Jones, the former St.
John's star, to a contract for the rest of the season.

City Mark for Anderson
LEAD: Kenny Anderson, considered the nation's best high school player, scored 40 points yesterday and became New York City's top-scoring schoolboy player ever.
In leading Archbishop Molloy to a 73-61 victory over Xaverian in Brooklyn, Anderson raised his career point total to 2,377.
Anderson, a 6-foot-2-inch guard who will attend Georgia Tech next season, entered the game needing 15 points to break the record of 2,351 set by Duane Ivory of Our Savior Lutheran in the Bronx from 1982 through '86.


Twins Sign Puckett
LEAD: Kirby Puckett avoided salary arbitration by signing a one-year deal with the Minnesota Twins yesterday.
Puckett, the All-Star center fielder, had asked for $2.15 million, while the Twins had offered $1.9 million.
General Manager Andy MacPhail and Puckett's agent, Ron Shapiro, said the two sides met in the middle.


Chairman Is Retiring At American Standard
LEAD: American Standard Inc., known for its plumbing fixtures and which has gone private through a leveraged buyout, said yesterday that William B. Boyd was retiring as chairman, president and chief executive.

LEAD: When Saifuo Khodzhaya was found on Monday, after an earthquake shook this tiny village and a landslide buried it in mud and clay, he was dead, crushed when the roof of his house fell.
His arms were stretched through a window, and in them lay his 6-day-old daughter, alive and crying.

LEAD: Can performances by the Miles Davis Quintet, the Art Ensemble of Chicago or Bon Jovi be considered chamber music?
That was one of the questions raised this week during a panel discussion called ''Chamber Music in the 20th Century,'' part of Chamber Music America's 11th national conference.
And it was a notion that did not seem to raise any hackles among the conference's participants, representatives of a field normally regarded as conservative.

LEAD: Hitachi Ltd. filed a Federal lawsuit accusing Motorola Inc. of patent infringment on a microprocessor.

LEAD: SINCE the summer of 1976, when I was convalescing from an illness, my younger daughter and I have watched a soap opera.
I had never seen one before that July: turning on ''Days of Our Lives'' was a way to break an otherwise shapeless day into segments.
The other ways were a) to talk on the phone in the morning, b) nap from 2 to 3, c) wobble outside to view the filming of ''Kojak'' episodes on my street.

Molson, Carling
LEAD: The Molson Companies and the Carling O'Keefe Breweries, a unit of the Australian-based conglomerate Elders IXL Ltd., said they would close seven of 16 breweries across Canada in the next three years after completing the proposed merger of their North American beer operations.
The companies would eliminate 500 full-time jobs and slash their payrolls by another 900 employees through attrition and early retirement incentives.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; English Role In Hispanic Marketing
LEAD: VISTA magazine, an English-language Sunday newspaper supplement whose material is intended for Hispanic audiences, is expected to turn its first profit this year, a success it owes to the increasing use of English marketing by advertisers trying to reach Hispanic consumers.


Boy Seized With .32 at School
LEAD: A 14-year-old student who was showing off his unloaded .32-caliber Beretta pistol to a fellow student yesterday during a school fire drill in the Bronx was arrested, the police said.
The student, who was not identified because of his age, was charged as a juvenile after his 2:35 P.M. arrest at Junior High School 127 at 1560 Purdy Street in the Westchester section, said a police spokesman, Sgt.


Pro-Life? Or Pro-Death?
LEAD: On the President's first day in office, he lost no time in congratulating foes of safe, legal abortion for their extraordinary valor on the part of fetal - if not human - life.
In a phone call to anti-abortion demonstrators, President Bush made it absolutely clear that his vision of a gentler America does not include any gentleness for women of childbearing age.


Pitt, in Big-Game Mode, Registers Another Upset
LEAD: Early in the second half tonight, P. J. Carlesimo shed his suit jacket and knelt in front of Seton Hall's bench with a worried look on his face.
The Pirates' coach sensed his team was in trouble.


3 CONCERNS RAIDED BY BONN IN INQUIRY
LEAD: West German customs officials today raided 3 companies and 12 private homes in search of evidence that Libya received aid in building what is said to be a poison-gas plant.


Tower Tells Hearing Panel He'll Accept Military Cuts
LEAD: John G. Tower, President Bush's choice to be Secretary of Defense, sought today to dispel concern about his consulting work for military contractors and past support for huge military budget increases.


Small Rise In Yields
LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, but the increases were smaller than those of the previous week.


Woman Who Will Be Bishop Acts to Avoid a Radical Image
LEAD: The Rev.
Barbara C. Harris sought yesterday to soften her image as a political and theological radical as she prepared to become the first female bishop of the Episcopal Church.


MITCHELL DETAILS DEMOCRATIC GOALS
LEAD: George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, today set bipartisanship in foreign policy and the establishment of a ''new social contract'' between the Government and its citizens as the major objectives of Senate Democrats in the 101st Congress.


Review/Opera; 'Postman' in Washington
LEAD: The Washington Opera has revived ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' the 1982 operatic adaptation of James M. Cain's famous and twice-filmed novel of ruthlessness, frustration and violence in Depression-era California.


Clarence Norris, The Last Survivor of 'Scottsboro Boys', Dies at 76
LEAD: Clarence Norris, the last survivor of the ''Scottsboro Boys'' rape case, which became a symbol of racial injustice in the Deep South in the 1930's, died Monday at Bronx Community Hospital after a long illness.
He was 76 years old.


HEALTH: Medical Training; A New Specialty in Emergency Care Causing Fierce Debate in Hospitals
LEAD: In a major change over the past 10 years, emergency rooms in many American hospitals have begun to rely on a corps of doctors trained in an entirely new medical speciality: emergency room medicine.


Independent Oil Nations May Back OPEC Pact
LEAD: Oil traders were closely watching developments in London today for signs that oil-producing countries that are not OPEC members may join in an effort to keep prices high.


Probert Suspended
LEAD: Bob Probert, the Detroit Red Wings' forward, was suspended for the second time this season when he arrived 25 minutes late for the team's game last night against the Buffalo Sabres. ''He showed up at 6:10 P.M. and he was supposed to be here at 5:45 P.M.,'' said Bill Jamieson, director of public relations for the Red Wings.


Cross-Country Skiing to the Inn
LEAD: Cross-country skiing usually involves traversing trails that go in loops that eventually take skiers back to their starting point.
Cross-country skiing can, however, lead to a destination and, even better, to a cozy, country inn that offers a warm fire, a comfortable bed for the night and home-cooked meals.


Agreement Reached on Indian Museum Shift
LEAD: Negotiators from New York City and the Museum of the American Indian in upper Manhattan said tonight that an agreement had been reached to shift the museum's holdings to the Smithsonian Institution.
The Smithsonian would build a new museum on the Mall in Washington and also operate a large adjunct museum at the United States Custom House in lower


Susan Sontag, as Image and as Herself
LEAD: The first exhibit - as Susan Sontag might begin if she were writing an essay about herself - is a thin volume entitled ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' which adds itself to a growing collection of volumes sharing a widely recognized characteristic.
They all strive to be on the cusp of cultural discovery.


Savings Unit Rescue Plan
LEAD: The nation's largest savings and loan trade association proposed a plan on Tuesday that would call on taxpayers to rescue hundreds of insolvent savings institutions.
The plan would reduce the long-term cost of the rescue to the healthy segment of the industry.


Jordan Hits 10,000 But Bulls Fall to 76ers
LEAD: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls scored the 10,000th point of his career tonight, but the Bulls lost to the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-108.


Doctor Loses Practice Over Genital Surgery
LEAD: A gynecologist who had performed surgery to alter women's genitals can no longer practice medicine in the United States, the Ohio Medical Board said today.


American Express Reports $231 Million Net in Quarter
LEAD: The American Express Company said yesterday that it earned $231 million, or 54 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1987.


Federal Farm Credit Banks In $2.4 Billion Offerings
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday announced the interest rates on three consolidated systemwide bond issues totaling $2.4 billion, which were offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers and dealer banks.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Whalers 3, Blues 3: Paul MacDermid of Hartford scored with 11 minutes 9 seconds left as the Whalers battled the St.
Louis Blues to a tie in Hartford last night.
MacDermid broke in free from the blue line off a pass from Dean Evason and converted a backhander to give the Whalers the tying goal with his 10th of the season.


Drexel Expected to Dismiss Milken as Part of a Plea Deal
LEAD: Michael R. Milken, the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s ''junk bond'' operations, is expected to be dismissed within the next two weeks as part of an agreement between the Government and the firm that was disclosed yesterday.


Salvadoran Leader Rejects Rebel Plan on Election
LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte tonight dismissed a proposal by the Salvadoran guerrillas laying out conditions for their participation in presidential elections, saying it amounted to a ''proposal of war.''

In China, Only Foreign Students Know Comfort
LEAD: To the Editor:


King Glorious Will Miss Derby Because of Injury
LEAD: King Glorious, the undefeated California colt who had been rated the early second choice for the Kentucky Derby May 6, is no longer being pointed for the race because of a minor knee injury, his trainer said today.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: ACOUSTICAL tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used to cover new and replacement ceilings.
Although they are excellent for absorbing sound, they are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean.
Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.


Bundy Toll May Be 50, Prosecutor in Case Says
LEAD: The prosecutor who sent Ted Bundy to the electric chair said today that the killer might have slain 50 young women, a toll that investigators have sought to prove for years.


Bush Weighs User Fee on Savings Deposits
LEAD: President Bush said today that his Administration was considering imposing a user fee on depositors at savings and loan associations, commercial banks and credit unions in an effort to raise billions of dollars to solve the nation's savings crisis.


DISARMING OF 5 MX'S IN '88 IS REPORTED
LEAD: An MX missile came loose from its support and fell as much as a foot inside its underground silo last year, causing the Air Force to remove that missile's 10-warhead payload and those of four other MX's found to be defective, according to an article published today.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the acquittal of a woman in the death of a New York City police officer misstated the charges in some editions.
She was charged with second-degree manslaughter, not first-degree.

Parceling Things Out
LEAD: The white minority Government that used to rule Rhodesia and its black successor in Zimbabwe have one attitude ironically in common.
Both like to run a dirigiste economy, effectively deciding who can do what kind of business.


Two Who Fell Far Land in Same Place
LEAD: On the synthesizer keyboard, Denny McLain played the Motown tune ''Stop!
In the Name of Love,'' which was made popular by the Supremes more than two decades ago, when McLain was one of baseball's best pitchers.


Review/Jazz; A New Spin on the Old Sounds of Swing
LEAD: In the late 1930's and early 40's when the big swing bands dominated popular music, the John Kirby Sextet provided a novel contrast to the bands' heavy drives.
With its light-voiced front line of alto saxophone, clarinet and trumpet, the Kirby group had a crisp, brisk, tightly arranged approach to swing.

LEAD: Meineke Discount Mufflers, known for its ''I'm not gonna pay a lot for this muffler'' campaign, has assigned its $20 million account to Lintas: Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, a unit of Lintas:USA.
The agency search began three months ago, initially with some 100 agencies.

LEAD: *
Campeau Corp., Toronto, a Canadian retailer, said its 1988 sales were better than the flat results projected last April.


CHINA AND VIETNAM REPORTED IN PACT
LEAD: China and Vietnam have agreed on a broad outline for a Vietnamese troop withdrawal from Cambodia by the end of September, a Vietnamese diplomat here said today.


U.S. Considers Relaxing Rules At Its Reactors
LEAD: The Department of Energy is considering reducing its safety requirements so it can speed the reopening of the troubled reactors at its Savannah River Plant, the chairman of a safety advisory panel said today.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported, as expected, the first annual loss in its 104 years in business.

LEAD: There is a spacious room on the second floor of the Old Executive Office Building with a splendid view of the White House.
One of its first occupants, if not the first, was Redfield Proctor, the Secretary of War under President Benjamin Harrison a century ago.


Durable Orders Up Brisk 6.4% in December
LEAD: New orders for durable goods rose by 6.4 percent in December, a much stronger gain than had been expected.
Analysts said yesterday that the report was a sign that the economy was entering 1989 with plenty of momentum for continued growth.

LEAD: Among the world leaders who sent congratulatory messages to President Bush was Najibullah, the President of Afghanistan.

LEAD: The City Council has banned polystyrene foam, joining a growing number of communities in which the substance, commonly used in fast-food packaging, is unwelcome.

Sunday at the Community House of the Church in the Gardens, 15 Borage Place, Forest Hills, Queens.

LEAD: The Supreme Court probably does not leap to mind as the place to shop for souvenirs.

LEAD: In the first of what could be several friendly takeover deals outside the country, the Stone Container Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., a big Canadian paper and packaging company, for $2.6 billion in cash.

Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

Kean Chooses Nominee For Attorney General
LEAD: Gov.
Thomas H. Kean today said he will nominate Peter Perretti Jr., a partner in a Newark law firm, as state Attorney General.
Mr.
Perretti, 57 years old, would succeed W. Cary Edwards, who resigned last week to consider a possible run for governor.


HAWK IS BACK AGAIN, AND SO IS RINGO STARR
LEAD: Two new weekly series are making their debuts this weekend.
On commercial television, ABC is offering ''A Man Called Hawk'' on Saturdays at 9 P.M.
This is a spinoff from the canceled ''Spenser: For Hire,'' and is based on a character created by Robert B. Parker, author of the ''Spenser'' detective novels.

LEAD: Minnesota upset top-ranked Illinois, 69-62, tonight as Willie Burton scored 20 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to spark a first-half spurt that sent the Illini to their first loss of the season.

LEAD: The State Department reacted positively today to a proposal by guerrillas in El Salvador despite President Jose Napoleon Duarte's statement that it amounted to a ''proposal of war.''

LEAD: The credit ratings have been reduced on $3.7 billion of the debt of E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company and the debt of its Du Pont Overseas Capital N.V. unit, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.

LEAD: ''Black and Blue,'' the new revue at the Minskoff, is a festive tribute to great black American jazz and blues artists as only a madcap pair of Argentine set and costume designers could have imagined it.


Fairies' Godmother
LEAD: If ever a memory deserved the masks of comedy and tragedy, surely remembrance of Bea Lillie does.
Beatrice Lillie, who died last week at her home at Henley-on-Thames at the age of 94, embodied the comic spirit on stage while suffering tragedy in her private life as Lady Peel.


Honda Develops Traction System
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company has developed what it said was the first automatic traction-control system for front-wheel-drive cars.
The company said it had solved the problem of maximizing traction during acceleration on slippery surfaces while retaining enough of the tires' lateral force to turn sharp corners.


Hype And Reality
LEAD: After many soppy eulogies on the air and in print, as Ronald Reagan's eight years in the Presidency finally came to a close, the Supreme Court has given the nation a hard look at the real Reagan legacy.

Review/Music; Playing With Ideas, in Different Voices
LEAD: There was a bit of esthetic tension onstage at the Blue Note on Monday night.
The saxophonist Kenny Garrett and the pianist Geri Allen, who have known each other since they were children in Detroit, play with different musical voices.
Mr.
Garrett is an old-fashioned blistering soloist whose playing is infused with soul and blues ideas that often reach exultant climaxes, fervent as a gospel performance.

Chester Hammond, 77, A Retired Industrialist
LEAD: Chester Hammond, a retired industrialist who served as a millitary aide to Franklin D. Roosevelt, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at the Maplewood Manse Rest Home in Peterborough, N.H.
He was 77 years old and lived in Peterborough.


A.C.L.U., Though Buoyed by Surge of Recruits, Still Frets Over Presidential Campaign Fallout
LEAD: Precariousness is a way of life for the American Civil Liberties Union, but even by that standard 1988 seemed like a disaster.
Through Labor Day only 15,000 new members had enlisted, which did not even cover attrition.
The stock market crash, the defeat of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court and the end of the Reagan era all made for malaise.

LEAD: A Long Island man whose pregnant wife is in a coma said today that he wanted to be appointed her guardian so he could authorize an abortion in an attempt to help her recover.


Globex Trading System Gains
LEAD: Members of the New York Mercantile Exchange have authorized their board to pursue negotiations to join the Globex electronic trading system for futures and options contracts, the exchange announced yesterday.
It said the vote by members was 392 to 122 in favor of the proposal.

LEAD: The apartment is completely bare, except for a table and chairs in the middle of the living room and beds covered by green blankets in the bedrooms.

LEAD: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the 88-year-old Iranian leader, is ''in good health,'' works hard and sometimes performs marriage ceremonies, his daughter says.

He was 81 years old.


U.S. Orders More Inspections Of Engine Mountings on Jets
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that airlines increase their inspections of bolts holding engines to Boeing 737 jets to prevent recurrences of the episode Friday in which an engine fell off a plane taking off in Chicago.

LEAD: An optimist would say the Nets almost pulled off a great comeback tonight.

LEAD: In response to growing outrage over rising property taxes in New Jersey, Gov.
Thomas H. Kean proposed today that the state take over from the counties the costs of the welfare and state court systems to save those who pay property taxes more than $320 million.


Dallas Office for DDB
LEAD: DDB Needham Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, said it would open a Dallas office, exclusively to service the $20 million American Airlines international account that the agency retained after a six-week competition with Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon &amp; Eckhardt, Dallas.
Bozell will continue to handle the $120 million domestic account.

LEAD: The way mathematics is taught and perceived in the United States needs a major overhaul because most students leave school without enough skills to meet job demands or to continue their education effectively, prominent mathematicians, scientists and engineers said in a report today.

Farley Extends Bid
LEAD: Farley Inc. said it was extending for the ninth time its $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid for West Point-Pepperell Inc.
The new deadline is next Wednesday, a week later than the previous deadline.
About 15.7 million shares of West Point-Pepperell common stock had been tendered by shareholders, which gives Farley about 62 percent of Pepperell common stock.

LEAD: What do you look for in a Soviet film that, like the American television series ''The Day After'' in 1983, depicts the ultimate human drama -death and survival after the nuclear holocaust?
There are those in the West who have long suspected that the Soviet Government, always carefully controlling its own peace movement, wanted to encourage greater fear of the nuclear catastrophe among other people than among its own citizens.

Selfish, Sanctimonious Anti-Smokers
LEAD: Recently, I boarded a flight from Boston to New York.
As I sat down, the attendant announced that the flight was scheduled to take less than two hours (it actually took four hours) and consequently ''in accord with Federal Aviation Association regulations this is a nonsmoking flight.'' A large number of the passengers cheered and applauded.

LEAD: Hundreds of anxious telephone calls are coming into the offices of Long Island health officials in the wake of three unrelated deaths from meningitis caused by the meningococcus bacterium, but officials say there is no cause for alarm.

LEAD: CBS won two of broadcast journalism's highest awards yesterday when ''60 Minutes'' received the Alfred I. du Pont-Columbia University Gold Baton and the ''CBS Evening News'' received a Silver Baton for its coverage of the Persian Gulf in the final weeks of the Iran-Iraq War.

U.S. to Allow Hanoi Official To Attend Capitol Reception
LEAD: The United States has allowed a Vietnamese official to visit Washington, the State Department said today.


Bugged Embassy in Moscow Gets Chance for a New Life
LEAD: An American trade group has offered to buy the unfinished United States Embassy building in Moscow as office space, State Department officials said today.
Washington halted construction on the building last year after concluding that it had been embedded with enough eavesdropping devices to turn it into an eight-story microphone.

LEAD: The New York State Health Department has begun the first statewide program in the nation to reduce the rate of Caesarean births.

Paris Coiffures Recall the 30's
LEAD: Coiffures, many of them revivals, have attracted attention at the round of couture fashion shows for spring and summer this week.
In recent seasons, simple French knots and buns have prevailed, giving the models a well-groomed look that did not distract from the clothes.
This time the hairdo is part of the atmosphere, recalling the grand days of the couture in the 1930's.

The Greenhouse Effect Is for Real
LEAD: A team of Government scientists report no sign of a warming trend in the average temperatures in the United States over the last century.
Does that mean the greenhouse effect, the feared heating of the earth's atmosphere by burning coal and oil, is just another false alarm?
The answer, unfortunately, is an emphatic no.

Making clothes that help women look pretty and feel secure is also an accomplishment.
Because he is so skilled at designing clothes that are flattering and familiar without looking strange, Hubert de Givenchy received a standing ovation this morning from an international audience of retailers and customers.

Nicaragua Devalues
LEAD: In a move to salvage Nicaragua's war-ravaged economy, the Government devalued its currency Wednesday for the second time in a month.
Managua has increased the official cordoba exchange rate 13 percent, to 2,300 cordobas to the dollar from 2,000, the official daily Barricada said.
The currency was devalued from 920 cordobas to the dollar on Jan.

France Trade Gap Wider
LEAD: France recorded a trade deficit of 33 billion francs ($5.3 billion) in 1988, its largest annual trade deficit in five years, the nation's customs office reported today.
The 1988 performance was slightly wider than the gap of 31.5 billion francs in 1987, but less than the deficit of 48.9 billion francs reported in 1983.


No Time to Change U.S. Defense Policy
LEAD: Transition is the key word these days in Washington - and, according to many observers, in international affairs as well.
There is a widespread sense that 1988 was a watershed year in international affairs - a year that marked the beginning of a ''new era,'' requiring a radically new approach to relationships with our allies as well as our adversaries.


Wilson's Agent Reacts
LEAD: The agent for Stanley Wilson of the Cincinnati Bengals, the running back suspended before the Super Bowl last Sunday because of drug use, said yesterday that the Bengals might have contributed to Wilson's relapse into cocaine use by not closely monitoring his nonfootball activities in Miami. ''I can't say they're totally to blame, but there are things you have to do under the simplest form of rehabilitation that weren't done,'' said Reginald Turner of Los Angeles, the agent.


Oakland to Pay Raider Legal Fee
LEAD: The city of Oakland and the Los Angeles Raiders reached an out-of-court settlement today in which the city will pay $3 million for the team's legal fees over a four-year period.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Germain Leads: Dot Germain, who last won a tournament in 1980, birdied the last two holes yesterday to finish with a 4-under-par 68 and a one-shot lead after the opening round of the LPGA Oldsmobile Classic in Boca Raton, Fla.
Germain sank a 15-foot putt on her 17th hole to pull even with Jody Rosenthal, Dottie Mochrie and Beth Daniel and made a 10-footer on the final hole to take the lead.(AP)

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the proposed Congressional pay raise misstated the position of Common Cause on the proposal.

In Brooklyn
LEAD: The tenor Carlo Bergonzi is to be the soloist with the Brooklyn Philharmonic and Il Piccolo Teatro del Opera chorus in arias by Verdi, Puccini and Donizetti at 8 tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section.
Lukas Foss is to conduct the program, which also includes Verdi's rarely heard ''Hymn of the Nations'' and Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini'' Overture.

LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation said today that its earnings rose 16.8 percent, to $151.5 million, in the fourth quarter and that it planned to open 600 restaurants this year.


Biggest British Privatization
LEAD: Shares in Britain's electricity industry will be sold off in four stages to avoid overloading the stock market with London's largest privatization to date, the Energy Secretary, Cecil Parkinson, said on Wednesday.

LEAD: Within six months of going on the market, the largest low-rise development of middle-income condominiums to be built in the Bronx is selling so well that the developers have raised their prices and are planning another increase in the spring.

LEAD: A plan of reorganization that the board of Allegheny International had recently endorsed came under attack in Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh yesterday from two suitors, creditors and a competitor.

Scott Undergoes Test
LEAD: Byron Scott of the Los Angeles Lakers, who has been suffering from internal bleeding, underwent urological tests yesterday and will miss tonight's home game against Charlotte.
Team doctors recommended that the 27-year-old guard not play until the condition clears.
Scott, in his sixth National Basketball Association season is the club's third-leading scorer with an average of 19.4 points.


The New Medicare: No Catastrophe
LEAD: Older Americans cheered last year when Congress broadened Medicare health insurance.
Now that they have examined it closely, some of the cheers have turned to harsh complaint.
Payments for Medicare coverage under the new catastrophic-illness plan seem to be increasing more than the added benefits are worth.

Oboe Quartet
LEAD: The Odyssey Chamber Players are to perform the world premiere of Thomas Flaherty's Oboe Quartet at 8 tonight at the Brooklyn Music School, 126 Felix Street, Fort Greene section.
The program also includes a Haydn Flute Trio (Hob. XV:15), and the Brahms Piano Quartet No. 1 in G minor (Op. 25).
The Odyssey Chamber Players are Wendy Rolfe, flutist; Mark Hill, oboist; Miriam Lockhart, clarinetist; Mowry Pearson, violinist; Lois Martin, violist, and Jeffrey Szabo, cellist.

5 in Bronx Indicted in First Cases In Inquiry on City's School Boards
LEAD: In the first criminal charges since the investigation of New York City's community school boards began last year, four school board members and a former district superintendent from the Bronx were indicted yesterday on charges ranging from theft of school property to bribe-taking.


Changes Asked in 24 A-Plants
LEAD: The protective containment vessels on nearly one-quarter of the nation's commercial nuclear reactors should be modified to reduce the risk of rupture in a major accident, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.


At Weill Hall
LEAD: Mary Ann Hart, the mezzo-soprano who won third prize in the 1987 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, is to sing Dominick Argento's ''Diary of Virginia Woolf,'' Ravel's ''Chansons Madecasses'' and music by George Gershwin and Irving Berlin at 8 tonight at Weill Recital Hall.
Tickets are $12.


Top Bush Economist Sees Growth As Slower Than Reagan Projected
LEAD: The man chosen by President Bush as his chief economist, Michael J. Boskin, disassociated himself today from President Reagan's final forecast for the economy and predicted somewhat slower growth this year.


U.S. AGENCY SUING ACCOUNTING FIRMS ON SAVINGS AUDITS
LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed today that his agency had lawsuits pending against three of the nation's largest accounting firms for failing to detect fraud and mismanagement that contributed to insolvencies at various savings and loan associations.
Insolvencies at savings institutions are costing the Government billions of dollars.


Stockton Takes Lead With a 65 in Pro-Am
LEAD: Dave Stockton was the best there was around the greens during the height of his career, when he won the PGA Championship in 1970 and 1976.
But the 47-year-old former wizard of the wedge and putter has only occassionally played in PGA Tour events in recent years.


Law Degree Wanes as Passport to Business Job
LEAD: Lawyers, once marketable commodities as business executives, have been devalued in the corporate marketplace.
Personnel executives and business school administrators say a job seeker's legal training is as likely to be seen now as a liability as an asset, and lawyers trying to switch careers say they are often typecast as narrow-minded, confrontational and unimaginative.


President's Successor Is Chosen at Raytheon
LEAD: The Raytheon Company, the electronics company that had $8.2 billion in sales last year, has named Dennis J. Picard, 56 years old, as its next president.


Affirmative Action Booms in Atlanta
LEAD: Before 1973, when this city started its first affirmative action program, less than 1 percent of city-financed construction went to minority contractors.
Today minority contractors win 37 percent of city contracts, a dizzying demonstration of affirmative action progress that has spilled over to the private market as well.


Jordan Tops All-Star Vote
LEAD: Michael Jordan and Magic Johnson finished 1-2 in fan balloting for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, and Atlanta placed two players in the starting lineup announced yesterday.
The game will be played Feb. 12 at the Houston Astrodome.


Robert Rienow, 79, Author and a Professor
LEAD: Dr.
Robert Rienow, a retired professor of political science at the State University of New York at Albany and an author and environmentalist who had warned about the depletion of natural resources, died on Sunday in a fire that destroyed his farmhouse in Selkirk, N.Y.
He was 79 years old.


Greenspan Shuns Curb On Buyouts
LEAD: The recent wave of leveraged buyouts and other forms of corporate restructuring has probably crested, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today.
He urged Congress to shun legislation to restrict such transactions.

LEAD: MIM Ltd., the British investment firm, said it held a 6.9 percent stake in Southdown Inc., a oil and gas development company in Houston.

Michael Gilbert, Pediatrician, 69
LEAD: Dr.
Michael Gilbert, a pediatrician and one of the founding physicians at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I.
He was 69 years old.
Dr.
Gilbert was born in Brooklyn and graduated from Washington &amp; Lee University and New York University Medical School.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $737.2 million, to $285.34 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 137 institutional funds increased by $1.05 billion, to $74.99 billion.
Those of the 226 general-purpose funds were down by $240.8 million, to $89.92 billion.


Clark Triples Salary
LEAD: Will Clark tripled his salary yesterday, agreeing to a one-year contract for $1.125 million with the San Francisco Giants.
Clark, eligible for arbitration for the first time, made $345,000 in 1988, when he batted .282 with 29 home runs and a league-leading 109 runs batted in.
The first baseman had asked for $1.2 million in arbitration and the Giants had offered $900,000.


Sister Helen M. Ingraham, Educator, 101
LEAD: Sister Helen Madeline Ingraham, who in 1919 founded Emmanuel College, the first Roman Catholic college for women in New England, died Tuesday.
She was 101 years old.

William A. Ott, Newspaper Publisher, 61
LEAD: William A. Ott, president and publisher of The San Jose Mercury News, died of cancer Thursday, He was 61 years old.


Senate Panel Moves Swiftly To Approve Trade Nominee
LEAD: The nomination of Carla A. Hills as the United States trade representative sailed through the Senate Finance Committee today after a confirmation hearing in which she said she would not hesitate to impose sanctions on countries that do not ''show results'' in reducing trade barriers that Washington deems unfair.


Soviets Buy U.S. Grain
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought another 25,000 metric tons of United Sates wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said today.
The wheat was part of an authorization of more than two million tons under the Export Enhancement Program.
Counting some left over from a previous arrangement and a newly authorized two million tons this week, the Soviets have more than 2.01 million tons still available under the program.

Carroll Sidelined
LEAD: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' starting center, will miss the game against Philadelphia tonight because of an acute lower back strain.
Carroll suffered the injury during a 112-109 loss to Sacramento Thursday night.
Roy Hinson will start.
Carroll, averaging 15.2 points and 8.8 rebounds, will be re-examined on a day-to-day basis.


Faberge Exhibit for Soviets
LEAD: The first major exhibition in the Soviet Union of the work of Peter Carl Faberge, jeweler to the czars, is to open Feb. 8 at the Museum of Applied Arts in Elagin Palace in Leningrad.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about indictments of five New York City school officials carried an incomplete description in some editions for Silver Burdett &amp; Ginn, depicted as the target of a bribe attempt, and omitted any comment from the company.
Silver Burdett is a publishing company, and its comment is reported today on page 31.


Coping: With Film Processing
LEAD: Getting film developed and printed used to be a simple matter.
You took your exposed rolls to the neighborhood drugstore, where they were put in envelopes and sent off.
Two weeks or so later, you picked up the printed and developed negatives.


For Aged, Night Falls Are Most Common
LEAD: To the Editor:


G.N.P. Increases by 2%
LEAD: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent in fourth quarter of 1988, reduced 1.1 percent by the summer's drought.
Page 35.


Jill Burns Is Married To Frederick Kemper
LEAD: Jill Burns and Frederick William Kemper, 1988 graduates of Brigham Young University, were married yesterday at the Washington Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Bishop Morgan Bates performed the ceremony.


Olympia &amp; York
LEAD: Olympia &amp; York Developments Ltd. said it was considering taking 49.9 percent of the BCE Development Corporation, a subsidiary of BCE Inc., the Canadian telephone company.


Study Notes Fare Rises at Hub Airports
LEAD: Airlines that dominate schedules at airports serving as hubs for connecting flights have in recent years raised their fares at those locations considerably faster than the national average, the Transportation Department said today.


2 Queens Men Charged by U.S. In Bomb Scheme
LEAD: A college student and a bank teller were arrested and charged in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with the attempted bombing at a surgical supply company that uses dogs in its research.

A Decent, but Incomplete, Homeless Plan
LEAD: In his State of the City address this week, Mayor Edward Koch recognized that New York's ''quality of life suffers a serious decline'' because of the homeless camped out in public.
His commitment is encouraging.
But the program he proposes won't address the most serious part of the problem - the homeless who are mentally ill.


No Headline
LEAD: When Harold E. Ballard suffered a heart attack a year ago, shares in Maple Leaf Gardens Ltd., the company that owns the Toronto Maple Leafs hockey team and the arena where they play, jumped $3.50 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Six months later, when Mr.
Ballard entered the hospital for a quintuple heart-bypass operation, the stock rose again, by $2.75 a share.


New Transit Police Contract
LEAD: New York City and the Transit Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a $55 million contract that will increase wages by 18 percent over three years.
The contract is retroactive to July 1, 1987.
Robert W. Linn, director of the city's Office of Labor Relations, said the pact was patterned on one reached with the city police last May.


Johannesburg Lawyers Condemn a Judge's Ruling
LEAD: The Johannesburg Bar has taken the rare step of formally condemning a judge's decision that let a white farmer avoid jail after he killed a black laborer who ran over his dogs.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about an offer to purchase the unfinished United States Embassy building in Moscow referred incorrectly, in some copies, to a halt in construction.
Work was halted in 1985, not last year.

TV Satellite Merger
LEAD: Two television satellite transmission companies, Bonneville Satellite Communications and Wold Communications Inc., have agreed to merge, the companies announced today.
The privately held concerns declined to disclose financial terms other than to say that Salt Lake City-based Bonneville would own 60 percent of the new entity and Wold, of Los Angeles, would hold 40 percent.


Truck Crash Kills 50 Haitians
LEAD: Fifty people, including three children, were killed today and 46 injured when a military truck loaded with Haitian workers on their way to Dominican sugar fields flipped over.
The truck was bound for the Jaina refinery. ''The driver was speeding and it looked like he fell asleep,'' said a survivor, Louis Raphael.

Schuller Wins Prize
LEAD: Gunther Schuller, the 63-year-old American composer, has been named the winner of Columbia University's William Schuman Award.
The prize of $50,000, for lifetime achievement in American musical composition, was presented Thursday evening in a ceremony at the university.
The award, named for the American composer, was established in 1981 through a gift to Columbia from the Bydale Foundation.

WCI Holdings
LEAD: The WCI Holdings Corporation, formerly the Wickes Companies, has sold four apparel businesses to Taren Holdings, a corporation formed by Odyssey Partners and James I. Spiegel.
The price was not disclosed.
The companies acquired are Catalina, Cole of California and Colonial Apparel - all of which were part of Wickes's Kayser-Roth Corporation subsidiary - and the Mode O'Day women's apparel retail chain with 350 stores.

No More Killing Fields in Cambodia
LEAD: Americans agree on two goals in Cambodia: First, Vietnam should end its occupation and let Cambodians choose their own government.
Second, no solution is morally tolerable if it permits a return to power by Pol Pot and the mass murderers of the Khmer Rouge.
Now a whirl of diplomacy has brought the first goal in sight.

Christopher Matthew Long, an instructor pilot at Reese Air Force Base in Texas, were married yesterday at St.
Mark Chapel in Baltimore.
The Rev.
Michael Carrion performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

BRAND OR GENERIC?
LEAD: Brand-name prescription drugs can cost nearly twice as much as their equivalents, and about half of all brand-named drugs have generic equivalents.
Once a pharmaceutical company's patent for a drug has run out, competitors may seek approval for their own versions from the Food and Drug Administration.


The Drive for a Fire-Safe Cigarette
LEAD: The Surgeon General has estimated that smoking-related diseases kill 390,000 Americans a year.
But there is another way that cigarettes can kill - through the fires they start.
While overshadowed by the health issue, fire abatement is gaining new momentum, partly because of new findings that it is feasible to create a less fire-prone cigarette.

LEAD: Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said in a television interview broadcast yesterday that he wants to meet with President Bush and that he seeks a new and better relationship with an often hostile United States.

LEAD: Alexander &amp; Baldwin Inc. repurchased 4.4 million of its shares for $38 a share, or $168 million, from the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation Inc.
The foundation also entered into a standstill agreement that stipulates that Mr.
Weinberg's companies refrain for seven years from buying more A.&amp;B.

Patents; Computer Recognizes 5,000 Spoken Words
LEAD: Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc. of Waltham, Mass., won patent approval for a computer program that allows a desktop computer to recognize as many as 5,000 spoken words.
The computer can also be trained to recognize the pronunciation of a particular speaker.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the Army's effort to eliminate contract fraud described an out-of-court settlement with the N. W. Ayer advertising agency incorrectly.
In paying $700,000 to cover what the Army considered excessive labor costs, the agency admitted no wrongdoing.

LEAD: Valentino, Rome's leading designer, showed his couture collection here for the first time on Thursday evening, and won the city over.

Caray Named Winner Of Ford Frick Award
LEAD: Harry Caray, the broadcaster for the Chicago Cubs who has been describing major league baseball games since 1944, when he did his first play-by-play for the St.
Louis Cardinals, was named yesterday as the winner of the Ford Frick Award, presented annually by the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Caray, 68 years old, will be honored in July at the annual induction ceremonies at Cooperstown, N.Y., joining a dozen other broadcasters, including Mel Allen, Red Barber, Vin Scully and Curt Gowdy.

LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, passing through the 1.85 level against the West German mark despite dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve and European central banks.

Wheeling Chief Quits And Sells 34% Stake
LEAD: The chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation sold his 34 percent stake yesterday and resigned from the company, it said.
Wheeling, one of the nation's largest steelmakers, said that the chairman, Lloyd C. Lubensky, had given no reason for the actions.


Great American
LEAD: Great American Management and Investment Inc. said it had filed suit in Federal court in Indianapolis seeking to void the $163 million merger agreement between the Ransburg Corporation and Illinois Tool Works Inc.
Great American, a Chicago-based manufacturing and financial services concern, accused Ransburg's directors of violating their fiducicary responsibiliteis.

LEAD: Less than three weeks remain for thousands of Soviet troops still in Afghanistan to withdraw through mountain passes dotted with hundreds of potential ambush sites, many of them occupied by thousands of Afghan guerrillas.

John McCallum Jr., Musician, 36
LEAD: John McCallum Jr., a pianist and musical director for Off Off Broadway and touring theatrical productions, died of a heart attack Monday at his home.
He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Youth Held in School Shooting
LEAD: The police today arrested a teen-age suspect in the shooting of four students outside a high school here Thursday.
The suspect, Rodney Reardon, 18 years old, of Washington, was charged with assault with attempt to murder.
It was initially believed that the shooting, in which the victims were only slightly wounded, had been the work of one young gunman, accompanied by another youth.


Insurance Company Will Pay For Experimental AIDS Drug
LEAD: One of the nation's biggest private health insurers will offer coverage for an experimental drug treatment that is thought to prevent a deadly form of pneumonia in AIDS patients.


Vault Mark in Doubt
LEAD: The International Amateur Athletic Federation is awaiting documents from the Soviet Union to begin the process of officially recognizing a pole vault of 19 feet 8 1/4 inches by Rodion Gataullin, which would be a world indoor record.
Gataullin, a silver medalist at the Seoul Olympics last year, cleared the height at a meet in Leningrad, according to a report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, on Monday.

LEAD: Gary Burley, a former Cincinnati Bengals defensive lineman who has befriended Stanley Wilson, the suspended Bengals running back, said yesterday that Wilson was feeling better and was talking with Burley daily by telephone from his family home in Carson, Calif.
Wilson was declared ineligible for the Super Bowl after suffering a drug relapse in Miami.

LAROUCHE RECEIVES 15-YEAR SENTENCE
LEAD: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist who three times ran for President, was sentenced today to 15 years in prison for scheming to defraud the Internal Revenue Service and deliberately defaulting on more than $30 million in loans from his supporters.


Thomas Sopwith, Aircraft Pioneer In 2 World Wars, Is Dead at 101
LEAD: Sir Thomas Sopwith, whose companies built the British Sopwith Camel plane of World War I fame, died yesterday at his manor house outside Winchester in southern England.
He was 101 years old.
His son, Thomas, said he died of old age after a ''marvelous life.'' He was an aircraft designer, yachtsman and aviator as well as an airplane manufacturing executive.


Thon Sent to Phillies
LEAD: The San Diego Padres sold the contract of the shortstop Dickie Thon to the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Thon, 30 years old, was signed by the Padres as a free agent last February and played in 95 games, hitting .264.
He would have become a free agent if the Padres had not completed a deal by March 15.(

LEAD: About 47 pounds of cocaine was discovered Tuesday on an Eastern Airlines jet that had stopped at Miami International Airport on the way from Colombia to New York, officials said.

LEAD: The collapse of last year's agreement on the Museum of the American Indian means that instead of a New York museum with a Washington satellite, it will become a Washington museum with a New York satellite.
That's a blow to New York pride.
But the collection finally will have a decent home and the proposed satellite will give New Yorkers access to twice as much of the museum's huge collection as they have now.

The Biggest Diplomatic Openings for Baker
LEAD: THE late President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was fond of saying that the United States didn't hold just 90 percent of the cards in international affairs, it held 99 percent.
Mr.
Sadat's statement was an exaggeration, but it reflects a perception still widely shared around the globe.
So James A. Baker 3d began his first week as Secretary of State looking out on a world that is scrutinizing his every wink and nod for signs of how he intends to play his opening hand.


Corrections
LEAD: Two captions on page 27 of of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about movie music, are reversed in some copies.
The performer shown in dark glasses is Brian Eno; John Lurie is shown without glasses.
The caption on the same page about ''La Boheme'' misidentifies the male singer.
He is James Busterud.


TRAVEL ADVISORY

Hands Pose for Their Portraits
LEAD: THE HUMAN HAND HAS BEEN A recurring subject in photography - in part because, in an esthetic sense, photography renders the idea of ''the hand'' vestigial.
Unlike other methods of representation, including drawing and painting, photography cannot claim to be an art of line, stroke or touch.
To take a picture, all the hand need do is press the shutter button.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall.
This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall.
I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.

LEAD: Five ranch workers have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of killing more than 40 wild horses and burros.

THE GIFTED
LEAD: When my closest friend from college got married, the basement of her parents' home looked like Tiffany's storeroom the day after Christmas.
Long folding tables were piled with open pastel boxes of china, crystal and silver carefully nestled in wrinkled tissue paper and bubble wrap.
A neat row of file boxes sat at the head of the first table, containing a master guest list with notations and gift cards stapled next to each name.

LEAD: THOUGH Rudyard Kipling lived only five of his 70 years in Lahore, they were the most crucial years of his development as a writer.

How Madeline Kahn Works for Laughs
LEAD: ANGEL-FACED MADELINE KAHN frowns. ''Laughter is a strange response,'' she says. ''I mean, what is it?
It's a spasm of some kind!
Is that always joy?
It's very often discomfort.
It's some sort of explosive reaction.'' She flashes a devilish smile and then adds musically: ''It's very complex.'' And you laugh.

FICTION
LEAD:  LUCID STARS.

This is underscored by the mortality rates for Medicare patients in New York-area hospitals, which were published in The New York Times in December.

Review/Jazz; A Patchwork On the Piano
LEAD: Compositions seem to crumble under Andrew Hill's hands.
His piano style is a patchwork of approaches -ringing chords and quick jabs and stride piano oom-pahs, skittering runs and skewed be-bop lines, melodies fractured by pauses and asides - cobbled together in asymmetrical fits and starts.
His own themes are just as eccentric, barely announcing themselves as ballads or hard-bop before veering away.

Discovering Old Germany In Bamberg
LEAD: A MEANDERING river, lined with old houses; a tall, four-towered cathedral on the hill, and next to it a great Baroque palace: today Bamberg still looks like a late 18th-century engraving of one of those little German towns that time had apparently forgotten.
The texture of life - except for the inconveniently numerous cars - still belongs to an easier, sleepier time; from the dark, wood-paneled taverns serving the local white wine, beer and sausages to the impressive antique shops, all here speaks of the past.

'Lawrence' Seen Whole
LEAD: FIRST LOVE BETWEEN A PERSON and a film can be as intoxicating as first love between two people.
It can mean just as much crazy behavior, just as many sleepless nights.
As a young adolescent, I became so desperately obsessed with a certain film that I saw it over and over, spent years studying the life of its hero, regarded him as a kind of role model and even dragged my family on a long, dusty pilgrimage to a place where he had lived.

FICTION
LEAD:  ALL OUR GAMES.
By Erika Mitterer. (Camden House, $24.95.) In the Austria of the Anschluss, 16-year-old Helga Wegscheider zealously embraces Hitler's message, convinced of the justice of his design for Europe.
Like her fiance, an SS soldier, she devotes herself passionately to the Nazi cause.
But at home something else is taking shape, outside the scope of Helga's bedazzled vision: her brothers hold secretive Bible-group meetings, her parents' conversation is sprinkled with cryptic remarks.

Max Ernst's Adventures in Collage
LEAD: THE PERFECT COLLAGE, LIKE the perfect crime, is the one that goes undetected.
Almost anyone who takes a little trouble can put two unrelated images together with an effect that is amusing or disturbing (or both).
It is the privilege of genius to suggest - as Max Ernst was able to do over a period of more than 50 years - that the wildest of incongruities can bespeak both a higher logic and a successful reordering of the experiences of every day.

LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall.
This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall.
I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.


Redecorating for the Computer Generation
LEAD: Companies are sparing no expense to dress up their offices.
This year, factory sales of office furniture are expected to rise to $8.4 billion, double the $4.1 billion in revenues posted in 1982, the Business and Institutional Furniture Manufacturing Association, an industry trade group, reported.


Even Now, Hong Kong Is Unpracticed In Democracy
LEAD: ON almost every distant rock of empire - in India, in Africa, in the Caribbean - Britain tried as it withdrew from its possessions to leave a democratic system as its legacy.
But in Hong Kong, which is to be handed over to China in 1997, the British Government is critical of a democratic movement that has sprung up on its own, and it seems determined not to introduce a fully democratic system in the remaining years of its rule.

LEAD: James Gleick's article ''Why Can't a Robot Be More Like a Man?'' (Dec.11), exhibited a fine touch of realism, technological insight and humor.


A Salvaged Coin From the Colonies
LEAD: ON Feb. 7, Christie's will auction a New England shilling, one of the many coins from the salvaged ship H.M.S.
Feversham lost in 1711.
One of the rarest coins of the auction, the plain New England shilling is also one of the first coins minted in the English American colonies.

The Sweet Prosciutto Of San Danieli, Italy
LEAD: AL VECIO MULIN (the old mill) in Gradisca d'Isonzo, about six miles from the Italian-Yugoslav border, is always crowded with local residents who stop in to share a bottle of wine and some typical Friuli fare.
The owner, Bruno Spessot, who turned the 200-year-old mill into an informal inn 25 years ago, offers top-quality hams, sausages and other cold cuts along with the local Montasio cheese and, from the nearby Collio wine region, tocai, pinot grigio and merlot.

Exhibition of Puppets Is Coming to Columbia
LEAD: An exhibition of puppets and masks from the Brander Matthews Dramatic Museum is to be on display in the Low Library Rotunda at Columbia University, 116th Street and Broadway, from Wednesday through Feb. 21.
The show, sponsored by the Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center for Theater Studies, includes Noh masks, dance masks from Java and Thailand, carnival masks from Latin America, French marionettes and shadow figures from several countries.

Venice
LEAD: To the Editor: My wife and I were recently in Venice, and although we had been forewarned, we found the high prices staggering.

New Curb on Ozone Pollution
LEAD: The Department of Environmental Protection today lowered the limit on vapor-producing ingredients in gasoline sold in New Jersey between May 1 and Sept. 15 to control worsening ozone pollution.
The new order limits volatility - a measure of gasoline's polluting potency - to nine pounds per square inch, compared to the 11.5 the state has averaged in recent summers, the department said.

They are the Six Cuckoos.

LEAD: THE trend toward ethnic take-out food continues unabated, attesting to our national hunger for dining diversity and for decent food that is reasonably priced and quickly prepared - by someone else.

LEAD: As a result of the Yankees' determination to enter the 1989 season with the best possible pitching staff, seven pitchers, including some whose careers had seemed all but over, are getting a new chance to make their mark on the majors.
They have been invited to try out at the Yankees' major league training camp even though the team has 17 pitchers on the roster.

LEAD: THE past and the future are colliding on Broadway this year, and nowhere so dramatically as on West 45th Street.
As the construction of hotels, office buildings and retail space sets the stage for the new Times Square that will greet the 21st century, a close-up look at the projects in construction along a single street shows how the crosscurrents of law, business and public policy shape the growth of the city.

LEAD: RECENTLY, I read an article discussing how adolescence takes longer to go through these days.
According to the researchers, not until children reach their mid-20's are they able to properly separate from their parents and accept them as human beings.
Since our children range in age from 25 to 33, we know something about this phenomenon.

LEAD: When Clemson takes on Duke in Durham, N.C., today, don't be surprised if Dennis Hopf is wearing the cleanest Tiger uniform.

He was pressed into service for today's game to help fill the void created by the surprise suspension of seven Clemson players, including two starters, apparently for skipping study hall.

Mr.

FICTION
LEAD:  HEART SONGS: And Other Stories.
By E. Annie Proulx. (Scribners, $16.95.) The men in E. Annie Proulx's nine stories, who have come to northern New England to seek self-renewal by grouse hunting, trout fishing or folk singing, are as harried by misery as the people who live there.
Cut off from their spouses or harassed by their mothers and sisters, they are shy, battered, depleted men.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 1 with an article about Egypt identified a tomb incompletely and misstated its location.
It is that of Sennedjem, a necropolis worker, and is near the Valley of the Kings.
A map of Cairo with the article omitted the site of the newly opened opera house.
It is on the island of Gezira.

Four experts look at the implications of the Court's decision for minority-owned businesses.

Question Of the Week; Is the Big East The Best Conference?
LEAD: According to a recent poll by The Associated Press, the Big East had four teams in the Top 20.
Only the Big Ten had more.
The four ranked teams from the Big East were Georgetown, Syracuse, Seton Hall and Providence.
Together, those teams lost only eight games, all to other Big East teams.
Outside the Big East, the combined record of these teams was 46-0.

LEAD: The French have launched a yearlong celebration of their Revolution's bicentennial.

The Bush View on AIDS: Money Will Tell Much
LEAD: AS he prepares his own battle plan for the war on AIDS, President Bush will be pulled in opposite directions.
Advocates for victims of the epidemic see a larger AIDS budget as a logical extension of the President's recent signals that he will pursue a gentler brand of Reaganism.
At the same time, some conservatives argue that the epidemic is being used to promote a liberal agenda that includes sex education, contraception, free needles for addicts and more rights for homosexuals.

If so, the 47-year-old partner in a major Washington law firm will be the first black to lead a major American political party.

Stephen, Vienna's geographic and historic center, a bulging structure of concrete, glass and bright metal is nearing completion amid a fierce debate.

Crunch Time
LEAD: ON SEPT. 20, 1985, AGENTS FROM the United States Customs Service and the Secret Service seized more than 25,000 imported, counterfeit watches from illicit distributors in South Florida.
Twenty-six people were subsequently arrested and convicted of trafficking in counterfeit merchandise.
However, it was more than three years before the case, known as Operation Stopwatch, wound down.

Hence the Mac IIx.

Mayflower Replica Repaired
LEAD: After a month of refurbishing, the Mayflower II is back in its berth at Plimoth Plantation. ''It came back yesterday, and it looks absolutely gorgeous,'' Troy Creane, a spokeswoman for the plantation, said Wednesday.
The replica of the Pilgrims' ship, visited by about 300,000 people a year, undergoes major repairs about every two years.

UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
LEAD: Eleanor Bergholz's grim story of psychological despair while ''under the shadow of cancer'' describes in detail her unusual, one-year siege of toxicity from the relatively mild CMF regimen for breast cancer.
Less than 20 percent of patients receiving CMF suffer the intense toxicity she describes.
Her negative attitude is evident in the use of the term ''poisons'' for chemicals that are, indeed, lifesaving.

New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  WIDOWS, by Ariel Dorfman.
Translated by Stephen Kessler. (Penguin, $7.95.) In a land resembling both contemporary Chile and ancient Greece, the unrecognizable bodies of the ''disappeared'' begin washing ashore, tormenting the living with memories of the terror of the secret police. ''The plot resounds with the moral thunder of classic drama, specifically that of 'Antigone' and 'The Trojan Women,' '' Alan Cheuse said here in 1983.

UNDER THE SHADOW OF CANCER
LEAD: As the spouse of a cancer victim, I found Eleanor Bergholz's article very informative.
I had many questions about what my wife was experiencing.
She withdrew from me, keeping her pain and depression to herself, just as Ms.
Bergholz did.
I believe she thought she was saving me from suffering.
After reading this article, I was better able to understand what my wife was going through.

Fending Off The Bats
LEAD: WHEN bats moved into Lorraine Disburger's house in New London, N.Y., last summer, she moved out.
The normally nocturnal bats were everywhere, even at midday: between the walls, beneath the floorboards, behind the curtains, scratching and wheezing and squeaking and swarming. ''It was like that movie 'The Birds,' '' she said at the time.

Pas de Deux
LEAD: To the Editor: Nothing reminds me more of the old Alphonse and Gaston routine than the Whitney's duo of Breuer and Graves  [ ''The Whitney Paradox: To Add Is To Subtract,'' Jan. 8 ] .
The two Frenchmen of old, simultaneously gesturing grandly in order to allow the other to pass first, always wound up slamming into one another as they both conveyed false gestures of yielding while truly feeling entitled to enter a room before the other.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. At the end of last summer, I moved a small chest away from the wall and discovered a lot of mildew on the wall.
This is not an outside wall (the living room of another apartment is on the other side) and there are no water pipes inside the wall.
I no longer keep the chest flush against the wall and the mildew has not reappeared, although this part of the wall does look darker in some spots.

The End of Ideology

Museums That Span Mexico's History
LEAD: WHEN Mexico City had money, about a century ago under the brief rule of Maximilian and later under President Porfirio Diaz, it was spent on luxurious parks, vast esplanades and a grand avenue designed to rival the Champs-Elysees.
Today these remnants of elegance remain in the city's center, and it is here that three museums of exceptional quality - the Templo Mayor (Great Temple) Museum, the Franz Mayer Museum and the Centro Cultural - have recently opened.

From Bad to Worse on S &amp; L's
LEAD: The Bush Administration, barely a week old, has already managed to throw more confusion into the savings and loan crisis.
Incredibly, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has floated the notion of a ''user fee'' on bank and savings accounts to pay for insolvent savings and loan institutions.
Predictably, he scared anxious S &amp; L depositors, who started pulling their money out, and angered depositors everywhere.

Being Senior Judge Pays For Former Chief Justice

A Mugging and a Mob Evoke Debate in Brooklyn
LEAD: There is a tradition in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a tradition almost as old as the sidecurls, beards and broad-brimmed hats that the Hasidic men who live there wear.
The tradition is that when someone cries ''Chaptzum'' - the Yiddish equivalent of ''Grab him!'' - everyone obeys.

Reviews/Music; Enveloped in Busoni
LEAD: Liszt taught us that virtuosity could be a purely musical tool.
To its virtues, Busoni added excess.
As a compositional device, excess upends our musical values, and indeed Busoni's music leaves us unprepared and threatened, like passengers who have unwittingly chosen a rowboat in which to face a tidal wave.


RICO: Assault With a Deadly Weapon?
LEAD: Wall Street is not a racketeering enterprise, say brokers and financiers; then why are they being treated like mobsters?
Prosecutors and civil litigants who once were content to file stock fraud charges now invoke the law known as RICO, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act passed by Congress in 1970.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Dec. 20 about racial discrimination in the Navy erroneously characterized, in some copies, the jobs open 30 years ago to minority sailors.
They served in a variety of jobs, not solely as mess stewards.

Bridge
LEAD: Diplomats must have determination and stamina.
Exemplifying this in the World Team Olympiad last October in Venice was Alberto Calvo, Panama's Ambassador to Japan.
He played every one of the 540 deals in the qualifying stage, at a steady rate of 60 a day.
Two of his teammates, Jeff Hand and John Maduro, were put to the same test, and a fourth, Gerry Cooklin, played 520.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Saturday about the sentencing of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, characterized the charges incorrectly.

Oil Rig Count Climbs
LEAD: The number of working rotary oil rigs in the United States rose by eight, to a total of 797, in the week ended last Friday, Baker Hughes Inc., a Houston based oil services company, said yesterday.
The rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not the number producing oil.
A year ago there were 964 active rigs.

Powerful New Ataris
LEAD: NEIL Harris, for years an executive of the Atari Corporation, likes to say that the Atari and the Amiga live in the ''ghetto'' of personal computing.
Users in the mainstream - that is, users of I.B.M.-compatible and Macintosh computers - prefer to pretend that Atari and Amiga do not exist, even though the machines are better in some ways, and are more cost-effective for many users.


Gibson Greetings Head Will Retire on Feb. 28
LEAD: Thomas M. Cooney, who built Gibson Greetings Inc. into a major player and kept his job through several changes of ownership, plans to retire as chairman on Feb. 28.


Sports People: FIGURE SKATING; Kadavy Still Injured
LEAD: Caryn Kadavy, who dropped out of the 1988 Olympic figure skating competition because of the flu, has withdrawn from the national championships, scheduled to begin next week in Baltimore.
Kadavy, who was regarded as a co-favorite with Jill Trenary, has been suffering from a stress fracture in one ankle and a pinched nerve in the other.

LEAD: It all seems a bit ridiculous now, rather like looking back on a childhood squabble in the schoolyard in which both sides engaged in bluff and threat rather than real fighting.

Molson in U.S. Goes to Lintas
LEAD: The Martlet Importing Company in North Hills, L.I., has tapped Lintas:New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to create advertising for Molson beer in the United States.
The budget is in the $10 million to $12 million range.
After a monthlong competition, the agency bested two other New York-based agencies, Wells, Rich, Greene and Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Advertising, the incumbent, which had handled the account for four years.

LEAD: Radiation from the core of the Milky Way that mysteriously ceased after 1980, has resumed, according to data obtained from two high-flying balloons over Australia.

Firm to Acquire Crosby Associates
LEAD: Alexander Proudfoot P.L.C., a British management-consulting firm, said it would acquire an American counterpart, Philip Crosby Associates Inc., for $9.50 a share, or $67 million.
Crosby's shares soared $1.75 today, to $9.375, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 23 percent gain was the second largest of the day.

Schering-Plough Drug Is Approved
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said it had approved the use of a hormone-blocking drug made by the Schering-Plough Corporation to help slow the progress of prostate cancer.
The drug, flutamide, is to be sold under the name Eulexin.
The F.D.A. said a National Cancer Institute study found that patients taking flutamide in combination with leuprolide - a drug already on the United States market - survived an average of 34.9 months, or nearly 25 percent longer than patients taking leuprolide alone.


Curt George Segeler, Scoutmaster, 88
LEAD: Curt George Segeler, a retired chemical engineer and a Boy Scout leader for almost 66 years, died of cancer on Jan. 22.
He was 88 years old and lived in Brooklyn.


Robert Knudsen Dies; Photographer Was 61
LEAD: Robert LeRoy Knudsen, a White House photographer from 1946 until 1974, died of a heart attack Friday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland.
He was 61 years old and lived in Annandale, Va.


BRIEFS
LEAD: A. M. E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., said its employee stock ownership plan was considering making an offer to buy the company, which earlier agreed to be acquired for $13.75 a share by AOAG Inc.


Many Donors to Neediest Cases Earmark Gifts
LEAD: To help an older person remain at home, June Bruce of Great Neck, L.I., sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
She requested, as she has for the last 24 years, that her contribution be directed to the Community Service Society of New York.


U.S. Shuts Kabul Offices But Storm Prevents Exit
LEAD: The United States formally closed its embassy in Kabul today amid fears of a breakdown of law and order in the Afghan capital.


Another Hershiser Shutout
LEAD: Holding a microphone in front of the dais at the New York Baseball Writers dinner, Pat Cooper was working the room.
With a glance at Dallas Green, the comedian wondered how long the Yankees' new manager would last in the dugout.


Hartford Court Upholds Removal of Life Support
LEAD: Connecticut's highest court, taking up the first major challenge to the state's right-to-die law, ruled today that the family of a comatose accident victim may legally remove the feeding tube keeping her alive.


Brown's Path Clear For Leader of Party As Contender Quits
LEAD: Former Representative James Jones withdrew today from the race for chairman of the Democratic National Committee, leaving Ronald H. Brown the only candidate and a certain winner.

LEAD: Global Motors Inc., the American importer of the Yugo, filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy law yesterday, and the car's Yugoslav manufacturer petitioned the court for permission to operate Global while it is being reorganized.

Sayer is quite real.
And with both the economy and customer expectations inflated, the check he will award is part of a $10 million prize.

Ortega Unveils Austerity Plan For Nicaragua
LEAD: Taking dramatic steps to shore up Nicaragua's rapidly deteriorating economy, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced a tough austerity program today.
Officials said the program would slash the national budget by nearly half, requiring the discharge of up to 35,000 public employees and military personnel.


Ying-Ying Is Dead
LEAD: Ying-Ying, believed to be the world's most prolific panda in captivity outside China, has died, apparently after a bout of depression over the death of her mate.
Ying-Ying died Sunday, a zoo official said, after her lifelong mate, Pe-Pe, died in October.


New G.M. Van
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is developing an extended version of its Chevrolet passenger van that could be used for commercial hauling, an executive vice president, Lloyd Reuss, said.
But Mr.
Reuss refused to comment on a report that the longer van would be introduced in the fall.
Metalworking News also reported that the van would seat 17 people -two more than can be seated by the longest Ford van on the market.


Salomon Suffers 'Junk Bond' Defections
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. suffered another round of defections yesterday when four members of the ''junk bond'' department, including the head trader, resigned from the firm.

LEAD: Thomas and Paula Pilkington won a lottery.
Their prize was their dream: the chance to buy a new, three-bedroom house for $56,000, one-third the average price of a house on Long Island.
They turned it down.

G.M. Saturn Dealers
LEAD: A group of 26 men Sunday became the first franchised dealers for the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary.

LEAD: All Americans would be guaranteed basic medical services and all but the poorest citizens would be required to help share the costs under a national health care system proposed today by a private commission.

LEAD: Senior Administration officials said today that they would urge President Bush to approve an increase in Federal deposit insurance premiums paid by banks and other lending institutions to rescue troubled savings and loan institutions and to back away from a proposal for a fee on savings deposits.

LEAD: Random drug testing for key personnel, including astronauts, will start in March at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the chief of the agency has announced.

LEAD:  GOLF  Mochrie Wins Playoff: Dottie Moch-rie sank a 2-foot putt for par on the fifth extra hole of the L.P.G.A.
Oldsmobile Classic yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla., ending a sudden-death playoff with Beth Daniel, whose last shot lipped the cup and failed to fall.
Mochrie and Daniel, both former Furman University students who starred at the school in different decades, played four holes of the playoff before officials suspended play because of darkness Sunday night at Stonebridge Golf and Country Club.

New Technology From Du Pont
LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company said it had developed proprietary technology for compounds that in some cases can replace fully halogenated chlorofluorocarbons, which are used to service refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment.
Du Pont said the three-component blends have an ozone-depletion potential about 97 percent less than that of chlorofluorocarbon-12, one of the products suspected of depleting the earth's ozone layer.

LEAD: An examination of Pervis Ellison's injured left knee yesterday revealed that the University of Louisville basketball star had suffered no serious damage.
Dr.
Rudy Ellis, the team's physician, said a special X-ray machine that can see through the knee confirmed that Ellison sprained the medial collateral ligament.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.Where does the air supply come from for extended space missions?
A.
On past space flights, the components of breathable air, oxygen and nitrogen, were brought up in canisters.


Smithsonian Votes Plan for an American Indian Museum
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution today approved a plan to build a major museum of the American Indian on the Mall in Washington and to place a substantial adjunct to it in the Custom House in lower Manhattan.


Reign of the Feather
LEAD: Feathers are flying - out of the stores, that is.
Ostrich plumes, at $75 a dozen, in black or ivory, are blowing out of the OMO Norma Kamali store in SoHo.
Garment-district trim suppliers have had a flurry of sales of feathers as a fashion accessory and as an exotic alternative to fur.


Talking Business with Cornstein of Finlay Enterprises; A Bright Outlook For Retail Jewelry
LEAD: Jewelry retailing is undergoing a round of restructuring and consolidation.
A good example was the recent management buyout of Finlay Fine Jewelry, a New York-based operator of leased jewelry concessions in department stores, by an investor group led by Harold S. Geneen, the former chairman of the ITT Corporation.

LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation may keep using the Lexus name for its forthcoming line of luxury cars except in national advertising until a decision is handed down in a trademark-infringement case, a Federal appeals court said yesterday.

Corrections
LEAD: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Jan. 18 misidentified the organization with which David Goldstein is affiliated.
He studied the energy efficiency of large appliances for the Natural Resources Defense Council.


U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry
LEAD: Faced with a Federal investigation of his conduct and overt hostility from his staff, the United States Attorney in Massachusetts, Frank L. McNamara Jr., resigned today, saying, ''The work of this office is far too important to be sidetracked by any controversy.''


Olympic Champion Finds Races Yet to Be Won
LEAD: ''She just hates my airport workouts,'' Bob Kersee said yesterday, nodding toward his wife, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, whose wince seemed to prove her husband right.
Once, at San Francisco International with time to kill before a flight, Bob set up five garbage cans for a hurdle drill.
He wanted Jackie to practice getting her trail leg higher.


Koch's Plan for Staff Cuts Is Assailed
LEAD: Officials said yesterday that New Yorkers would see fewer police officers and firefighters on the city's streets - streets that would be dirtier - if the city imposed the stringent financial plan envisioned by Mayor Edward I. Koch.

'African-American' Favored By Many of America's Blacks
LEAD: A movement led by the Rev.
Jesse Jackson to call blacks African-Americans has met with both rousing approval and deep-seated skepticism in a debate that is coming to symbolize the role and history of blacks in this country.


F.C.C. Licensing Plan
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed putting into place a lottery system to award licenses for new AM and FM radio stations and for television stations.
The system would replace its comparative hearings, in which applicants argue their qualifications.
The commission said that the hearing process was too long, complex and expensive and that it had been a drain on the agency's administrative resources.

LEAD: Iran is determined to complete the petrochemical plant at Bandar Khomeini despite the disruption of construction during the Persian Gulf war.
